Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 3298 words

HEADLINE: The Listings

 BODY:
Movies
Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
&#x2605; 'Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry' (R, 1:31, in English and Mandarin) In December 2008 a 24-year-old American, Alison Klayman, as a favor to a friend, started videotaping the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei. Her timing was dazzling as was her perseverance, as becomes clear in this galvanizing portrait of the artist, his work and his times. (Manohla Dargis)
'The Amazing Spider-Man' (PG-13, 2:16) Five years after Sam Rami directed his third ''Spider-Man'' installment, Marc Webb returns this lucrative franchise to its origins with Andrew Garfield as the spider-teenager and Emma Stone as the girl. Painless but unnecessary. (Dargis) 
&#x2605; 'Beasts of the Southern Wild' (PG-13, 1:33) A blast of joyful, chaotic emotion from the bayou, Benh Zeitlin's dazzling film is a homegrown magic-realist fable of defiance in the face of hardship. A community in a stretch of coastal Louisiana called the Bathtub is menaced by storms and government benevolence. Their ordeal is narrated by a young girl named Hushpuppy (Quvenzhané Wallis ), who lives with her father, Wink (Dwight Henry), and who belongs in the tradition of Huck Finn, Scout Finch, Eloise and other indomitable American child heroes. (A. O. Scott)
'Beloved' (No rating, 2:15, in French) Christophe Honoré's musical melodrama follows, over four decades, the complicated love lives of Madeleine (Ludivine Sagnier in the 1960s and '70s, Catherine Deneuve later) and her daughter, Vera (Chiara Mastroianni). Alex Beaupain's clever pop songs offer more commentary than emotion, but the long, meandering story is full of pathos, comedy and surprise. (Scott)
'The Bourne Legacy' (PG-13, 2:05) Less a thrilling franchise reboot than a solid salvage mission, the fourth installment of the ''Bourne'' spy series replaces Matt Damon with a sympathetic Jeremy Renner, who handles the action persuasively even if the fight sequences lack a sense of regret or even sorrow. As viewers are whisked from location to location, it feels as if the director, Tony Gilroy, is trying too hard to match the accelerated tempo of the previous films. (Dargis)
'Brave' (PG, 1:33) After 17 years of feature filmmaking, Pixar has -- ta-da! -- its first female protagonist, Merida, a brave, ginger-mopped princess who wants to chart her own fate. The animation, as might be expected, is beautiful, but the story is filled with dreary gender clichés. Mark Andrews and Brenda Chapman directed and helped write the script. (Dargis)
'The Bullet Vanishes' (No rating, 1:48, in Mandarin) This period policier from China -- a 1930s buddy movie -- offers forensic clues, rich production values, a droll script and an easygoing chemistry between its leads (Nicholas Tse and Lau Ching-wan). Dig deeply enough and you may find fleeting references to an uncompassionate government. But enjoy it most as an agreeable entertainment. (Andy Webster)
'The Campaign' (R, 1:25) Two nincompoops run against each other for a seat in Congress. It's not a documentary, but a silly, not very outrageous comedy starring Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis. (Scott)
'Celeste and Jesse Forever' (R, 1:31) This wistful romantic comedy about love, marriage and never wanting to say you're sorry stars the appealing Rashida Jones and Andy Samberg as a couple who've split up without moving on or out. Written by Ms. Jones and Will McCormack, it was directed by Lee Toland Krieger. (Dargis)
'Chicken With Plums' (PG-13, 1:33, in French) Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud follow ''Persepolis,'' their animated adaptation of Ms. Satrapi's autobiographical graphic novel, with a live-action rendering of a piece of her family's history. Mathieu Amalric plays Nasser Ali, a melancholy violinist in mid-20th-century Tehran whose romantic and artistic torment fuels an oddly gentle and contemplative melodrama. The large French-speaking cast includes Maria de Medeiros as Nasser's wife and Golshifteh Farahani as the great lost love of his youth. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'Compliance' (R, 1:30) Raising troubling questions about the influence of class and education on our response to authority, Craig Zobel's squirmy psychological horror movie, based on a series of hoaxes at fast-food restaurants nationwide, is a slow-motion punch to the groin. (Jeannette Catsoulis)
'Cosmopolis' (R, 1:48) David Cronenberg directs this cold, funny adaptation of the 2003 Don DeLillo novel starring Robert Pattinson as a zomboid billionaire, one of the limo riding masters of the universe who, over the course of a long day and night, loses a great deal and, by doing so, becomes human. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'The Dark Knight Rises' (PG-13, 2:44) After seven years and two films that have pushed Batman (Christian Bale) ever deeper into the dark, the director Christopher Nolan has completed his postmodern, post-Sept. 11 epic of ambivalent good versus multidimensional evil with a burst of light. (Dargis)
'Ek Tha Tiger' (No rating, 2:13, in Hindi) This Bollywood romance dressed up in espionage clothes has a ''my enemy, myself'' theme that is too tepid to resonate. Starring Salman Khan and Katrina Kaif, the movie feels most engaged during its glass-shattering, rooftop-hopping action sequences. (Rachel Saltz)
'The Expendables 2' (R, 1:43) Sylvester Stallone returns with his band of aging action stars and a ridiculous amount of ammunition and explosives, bent on avenging a comrade's death and keeping some plutonium out of evil hands. A brief appearance by Chuck Norris provides the best moment of self-parody in a movie that could have used a few more of them. (Neil Genzlinger)
'For a Good Time, Call ...' (R, 1:26) This potty-mouthed comedy about two Manhattan women who establish a successful phone-sex business to pay the rent doesn't aspire to be more than a broad, sloppy, old-fashioned sitcom with a sexy gimmick, but the bogus dirty talk is often very funny. (Stephen Holden)
'Hit & Run' (R, 1:40) In this weightless, silly car chase movie, Dax Shepard brings some charm to his role of a sweet-natured, shady goofball in the witness protection program. (Holden)
'Hope Springs' (PG-13, 1:32) While this film about a longtime marriage that's gone dry has modest charms to go with its well-matched and practiced pair of wily scene stealers -- Meryl Streep and Tommy Lee Jones working on screen together for the first time -- the industry will have to do better if it wants to persuade boomers that there's something for them at the local multiplex other than cartoons and clichés. (Dargis)
'The Intouchables' (R, 1:52, in French) In this buddy movie from France, a rich white guy (François Cluzet), paralyzed from the neck down, is cared for by an African immigrant (Omar Sy) who teaches his boss to loosen up and appreciate life. The film's unabashed embrace of racial stereotypes may startle American audiences -- the movie was a huge hit in France -- but there is appealing warmth to the performances and an overall mood of friendly tolerance. It's embarrassing, but not as bad as it might have been. (Scott)
'Lawless' (R, 1:55) A blizzard of gunfire and a riot of Southern accents animate this meandering tale of violent bootleggers in Depression-era Virginia. Tom Hardy croaks like a bullfrog, Shia LaBeouf chatters like a chipmunk and Jessica Chastain pours coffee. (Scott)
'Little White Lies' (No rating, 2:34, in French) Guillaume Canet's disappointing follow-up to his hit noir thriller, ''Tell No One,'' is a two-and-a-half-hour Gallic homage to ''The Big Chill'' and a protracted scolding to a group of self-absorbed overgrown yuppies. The strong ensemble cast includes François Cluzet, Jean Dujardin and Marion Cotillard. (Holden)
'Little Birds' (R, 1:34) Juno Temple and Kay Panabaker play teenage friends living in dysfunctional households on the picturesquely bleak shores of Southern California's Salton Sea in Elgin James's moody, arrestingly shot debut feature. (Scott)
'Marvel's The Avengers' (PG-13, 2:22) Thor, the Hulk, Iron Man, Captain America and a few other mighty Marvel superheroes team up under the supervision of Samuel L. Jackson's Nick Fury in this franchise juggernaut, directed by Joss Whedon. The bantering and riffing among the characters provides some fun, but there is not much heart or imagination in the story or the action sequences. Which seems to satisfy the fans just fine. (Scott)
'The Matchmaker' (No rating, 1:52, in Hebrew) In Avi Nesher's film, which won several awards in Israel, a teenager's coming-of-age story of his experience working for a marital maven helps express the hopes and fears of a country awash in unsettling history. (Nicolas Rapold)
&#x2605; 'Moonrise Kingdom' (PG-13, 1:34) In Wes Anderson's latest, a wondrous storybook tale, a girl and a boy, both 12, run off to a remote inlet on an island where most of the adults seem disappointed and more than a little sad. The two are very serious -- about love, their plans, books, life itself -- and often act older than their age. You wonder what their hurry is, given that here adulthood, with its quarrels, regrets and anguished pillow talk, can feel as dangerous as the storm that's hurtling toward the island, ready to blow it all down. With Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand. (Dargis)
'The Odd Life of Timothy Green' (PG, 1:45) In this baffling exercise in maudlin, whimsical surrealism, directed by Peter Hedges, a childless couple (Jennifer Garner and a miserable-looking Joel Edgerton) are visited by a magic plant in the shape of a 10-year-old boy (CJ Adams). Tears are shed and lessons are learned, the main one being that this would have worked better as a horror movie. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'ParaNorman' (PG, 1:33) This beautiful-looking, charmingly heartfelt 3-D stop-motion animation -- from the studio that produced ''Coraline'' -- centers on an 11-year-old boy who can see ghosts and, with frights and laughter, battles a spirit. Directed by Sam Fell and the movie's screenwriter, Chris Butler. (Dargis)
'The Possession' (PG-13, 1:32) Perched somewhere between ''The Exorcist'' and ''The Unborn,'' this eerily enjoyable tale from the Danish director Ole Bornedal gives a malevolent box to a troubled young girl, throws in the Hasidic rap artist Matisyahu, and stands back. (Catsoulis)
&#x2605; 'Premium Rush' (PG-13, 1:31) The director David Koepp provides about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for in this buoyant dumb-fun, ticking-clock thriller about a bicycle messenger (the dependably appealing Joseph Gordon-Levitt) who has to get from here to there without being taken out by cars or a bad cop (a terrific Michael Shannon). (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'The Queen of Versailles' (PG, 1:40) Lauren Greenfield's documentary follows the shifting fortunes of David and Jackie Siegel, a wealthy Florida couple who dreamed of building the biggest house in America. The movie, which starts out like smirky reality television, turns into something darker and more complex as economic troubles take a toll on the Siegels and the audience becomes better acquainted with them. It's like a Theodore Dreiser novel for our new gilded age. (Scott)
'Red Hook Summer' (R, 2:01) Spike Lee's celebration of African-American resilience in a struggling Brooklyn neighborhood is messy, meandering and bluntly polemical. But it has one crucial element: raw vitality. (Holden)
'Robot & Frank' (PG-13, 1:30) Jake Schreier directed, from a script by Christopher D. Ford, this eager-to-please story set in the near future about an elderly gent (Frank Langella), his robot (voiced by Peter Sarsgaard) and some awkwardly managed truths about old age. Susan Sarandon also stars. (Dargis)
'Samsara' (PG-13, 1:39) Ron Fricke's new film, like its predecessor, ''Baraka,'' is a free-associative tour of the world, a series of striking, sometimes surreal images of nature, work, life and death in the global economy. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'Searching for Sugar Man' (PG-13, 1:26) There are several entrancing mysteries circulating in Malik Bendjelloul's hugely appealing documentary about fans, faith and an enigmatic Age of Aquarius musician known as Rodriguez who burned bright and hopeful before disappearing. Don't wait for the DVD. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'Side by Side' (No rating, 1:39) This timely, fascinating documentary offers a tour -- guided by the affable and thoughtful Keanu Reeves -- of the fast-changing world of digital filmmaking. Informative interviews with prominent directors, cinematographers and editors and glimpses of the latest gadgetry make it a must-see for movie geeks. (Scott)
'Sleepwalk With Me' (No rating, 1:30) The surreal dream sequences in this screen adaptation of Mike Birbiglia's 2008 one-man show -- about a commitment-phobic stand-up comedian with a sleep disorder -- help make this likable movie more than a glorified stand-up act. (Holden)
'Sparkle' (PG-13, 1:56) It is impossible to watch this ramshackle remake of a 1976 movie and not relate its story to the life of Whitney Houston, who portrays the strict church-lady mother of an aspiring singer in late-1960s Detroit. (Holden)
'Step Up Revolution' (PG-13, 1:39) How to stop a greedy developer from gutting a Miami neighborhood? The power of dance, of course. The fourth film in the ''Step Up'' franchise has some dandy flash-mob-style dance numbers, though like its predecessors it is burdened by a predictable plot and unintentionally laughable dialogue. (Neil Genzlinger)
'Ted' (R, 1:46) Seth MacFarlane, creator of ''The Family Guy,'' takes his provocative humor and his New England-accented voiceover skills to the big screen in this profane, sometimes funny comedy about a talking stuffed animal, the overgrown boy who loves him (Mark Wahlberg), and, somewhat tangentially, the boy's girlfriend (Mila Kunis) who wishes he would just grow up. (Scott)
'To Rome With Love' (R, 1:52) Woody Allen's latest is a mild, silly collection of tales set in the Italian capital, where love is complicated and characters -- both Italian and American -- are baffled, neurotic and always articulate. Mr. Allen plays a semi-retired opera promoter, while Jesse Eisenberg plays the younger Woody Allen type, torn between loyalty to his sensible girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) and her wayward, needy friend (Ellen Page). Alec Baldwin, Penélope Cruz and Roberto Benigni also contribute to this frothy, airy romp through some of Mr. Allen's favorite themes. (Scott)
'Total Recall' (PG-13, 1:58) Colin Farrell, Kate Beckinsale and Jessica Biel star in this chaotic and thoroughly unmemorable science-fiction action movie, loosely remade from a 1990 Arnold Schwarzenegger vehicle and even more loosely based on a story by Philip K. Dick. (Scott)
'2016: Obama's America' (PG, 1:33) Dinesh D'Souza -- the author of the best seller ''The Roots of Obama's Rage'' and a former American Enterprise Institute fellow -- is the host and narrator of this strident documentary, in which Mr. D'Souza enlists a host of interviewees who are almost entirely critical of the president. The film is unlikely to convert supporters of President Obama to an opposite view. (Webster)
'2 Days in New York' (R, 1:36) In this sequel to ''2 Days in Paris,'' Julie Delpy, who wrote and directed, reprises the role of Marion, a French photographer now living with Mingus (Chris Rock), a journalist and radio host. Their hectic, happy bohemian household is thrown into chaos by the arrival of Marion's father (Ms. Delpy's father, Albert), her sister Rose (Alexia Landeau) and Rose's boyfriend, Manu (Alexandre Nahon). The movie is spirited and sometimes hilarious, but turns sloppy and strained when it reaches for deeper emotional insights into its nutty characters. (Scott)
'The Watch' (R, 1:41) Half unfunny potty-mouthed buddy comedy, half spoof of ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers,'' this comic washout starring Ben Stiller and Vince Vaughn is larded with crude phallic jokes. (Holden)
Film Series
Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian Poetic Cinema (Friday through Thursday) With its penchant for folkloric subjects and extravagant stylistics, Ukrainian cinema managed to maintain much of its identity through the years of Soviet domination, as this brief retrospective suggests. The program includes two films by the father of Ukrainian cinema, Aleksandr Dovzhenko -- the 1927 ''Zvenigora'' (Saturday at 4:30 p.m.) and the 1930 ''Earth'' (Sunday at 4:30 p.m.) -- whose influence is obvious on Sergei Parajanov, whose ''Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors,'' perhaps the most celebrated Ukrainian film, will be shown at various times from Friday through Wednesday. And Parajanov left his mark on his cameraman, Yuri Illienko, whose experimental 1965 feature, ''A Spring for the Thirsty,'' screens on Friday at 8:30 p.m. and Monday at 4 p.m. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, (212) 875-5601, filmlinc.org; $13. (Dave Kehr)
From the Pen of ... (Friday through Thursday) This week this series devoted to celebrating the art of the screenwriter features films based on the work of Elmore Leonard (John Sturges's ''Joe Kidd'' and Richard Fleischer's ''Mr. Majestyk,'' both screening on Friday and Tuesday), Don Carpenter (Daryl Duke's ''Payday'' on Saturday), John Fante (Edward Dmytryk's ''Walk on the Wild Side'' on Sunday and Wednesday), and Joan Didion (Jerry Schatzberg's ''Panic in Needle Park'' on Sunday and Thursday), who wrote the screenplay for that film with John Gregory Dunne. Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org; $10. (Kehr)
See It Big (Friday through Sunday) New video restorations of Peter Bogdanovich's 1971 feature, ''The Last Picture Show'' (Friday through Sunday at 7 p.m.), and William Wyler's 1959 whopper, ''Ben-Hur'' (Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m.), are featured this weekend in this series of older films presented on a luxuriantly large screen. Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 37th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718) 784-0077, movingimage.us; $12. (Kehr)
'Swoon' (Thursday) There will be a 20th-anniversary screening of Tom Kalin's 1992 independent feature, one of the founding films -- with Gregg Araki's ''Living End'' and Todd Haynes's ''Poison'' -- in a movement that the critic B. Ruby Rich promptly called New Queer Cinema. A treatment of the Leopold and Loeb murder case, Mr. Kalin's black-and-white film, filled with deliberately anachronistic details, was the first to deal explicitly with the killers' homosexuality, and does so in ways that escape any reductive political reading. The 7:30 p.m. screening will be preceded, at 6:30 p.m., by a pair of short films by Mr. Kalin. BAM Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $12. (Kehr)
PHOTO: CAPTURING THE MARVELOUS: UKRAINIAN POETIC CINEMA: (Friday through Thursday) With its penchant for folkloric subjects and extravagant stylistics, Ukrainian cinema managed to maintain much of its identity through the years of Soviet domination, as this brief retrospective suggests. The program includes two films by the father of Ukrainian cinema, Aleksandr Dovzhenko -- the 1927 ''Zvenigora'' (Saturday at 4:30 p.m.) and the 1930 ''Earth'' (Sunday at 4:30 p.m.) -- whose influence is obvious on Sergei Parajanov. His ''Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors'' (above, with Larisa Kadochnikova), perhaps the most celebrated Ukrainian film, will be shown at various times from Friday through Wednesday. And Parajanov left his mark on his cameraman, Yuri Illienko, whose experimental 1965 feature, ''A Spring for the Thirsty,'' screens on Friday at 8:30 p.m. and Monday at 4 p.m. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5601, filmlinc.org; $13. (Dave Kehr) (PHOTOGRAPH BY SEAGULL FILMS)

HEADLINE: Nomura Seeks to Save $1 Billion By Scaling Back Mainly in Europe

BYLINE: By HIROKO TABUCHI

 BODY:
8:38 p.m. | Updated
TOKYO - Nomura Holdings, the scandal-hit Japanese investment bank, outlined a broad reorganization plan on Thursday that would pare back its business to a shadow of what it held after acquiring parts of Lehman Brothers in 2008. 
Most of the $1 billion in cuts, initially announced last week, will be made abroad. They are driven by a grim outlook for the global economy, Koji Nagai, Nomura's new chief executive, told analysts and investors at the company's headquarters in Tokyo.
Nomura's operations in Europe, which will account for 45 percent of the cost savings, and the Americas, which will account for 21 percent, will take the brunt of the cutbacks, the bank said.
Though Mr. Nagai declined to specify the number of jobs Nomura would eliminate, the company said it would shave $450 million from personnel expenses. Other cuts would come from savings made by optimizing spending on information technology, the bank said.
"We will take stock of the company from the roots upward and rebuild," Mr. Nagai said.
It has been a swift and striking fall for Nomura. For a nominal sum, it bought the Asian and European operations of Lehman Brothers, the American brokerage firm that failed in 2008, and set out to build a global investment franchise.
But that acquisition saddled Nomura with huge personnel costs, and the task of marrying two vastly different corporate cultures undermined efforts to capitalize on Lehman's talent pool.
Many top Lehman executives left Nomura, and it was forced to cut costs and try to end the hemorrhaging of money in its wholesale operations, which include equities, fixed income and investment banking. Nomura's foreign operations have lost money for nine consecutive quarters.
One of the last Lehman executives at Nomura, William Vereker, stepped down this week as joint head of investment banking. He is widely expected to leave the company soon.
Compounding the problems, an insider trading scandal in Japan this year led Nomura to replace its chief executive, Kenichi Watanabe, who had handled the bank's takeover of Lehman and had pushed for global expansion. His successor, Mr. Nagai, had been head of the Japanese domestic securities unit.
Under Mr. Nagai, the bank is narrowing its global aspirations and will focus closer to home in Asia, where it can better leverage its dominant position in Japan, senior executives said.
"When the global economy comes back, the recovery will start in Asia," Atsushi Yoshikawa, Nomura's new chief operations officer, said, "so we place great weight on Asia. But we have no plans to make aggressive investments like the kind we've made in America over the past three years. We intend to make good with what we have."
The latest retrenchment comes on top of a $1.2 billion cost-cutting Nomura struggled through last year. That effort eliminated 1,000 jobs.
The company plans to scrutinize sectors or businesses that perform poorly for two years in a row. Nomura's electronic brokerage unit Instinet, which it bought in 2006, will handle most equities execution outside Japan.
Hisako Ueno contributed reporting.
This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
PHOTO: Nomura also eliminated 1,000 jobs last year as part of a cost-cutting. (PHOTOGRAPH BY SIMON DAWSON/BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HEADLINE: The Listings

 BODY:
Theater
Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.
Previews and Openings
'The Anderson Twins Play the Fabulous Dorseys!' (previews start on Tuesday; opens on Sept. 16) Pete and Will Anderson have each logged time with some of the city's elite jazz and big-band orchestras. Now the two team up, sextet in tow, to bring to life another pair of band-leading brothers: Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey. Expect sibling rivalry, clips of the Dorseys' 1947 biopic and the tunes that helped introduce to the world the likes of Bing Crosby and Glenn Miller. 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 279-4200, 59e59.org. (Eric Grode) 
'Chaplin: The Musical' (in previews; opens on Monday) Silent film has spawned its share of enticing musical theater, including ''Singin' in the Rain,'' ''Mack and Mabel'' and Jerome Robbins's unforgettable Keystone Cops ballet for ''High Button Shoes.'' Now it's the Little Tramp's turn. After being picked to step into Chaplin's oversize shoes for the show's premiere at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, Rob McClure, who starred in ''Avenue Q,'' reprises his role as the title character. Christopher Curtis makes his Broadway debut as composer, lyricist and -- with the veteran Thomas Meehan (''Annie,'' ''The Producers'') -- bookwriter. Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'Detroit' (in previews; opens on Sept. 18) Lisa D'Amour's savage comedy (a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize) about the uneasy friendship between two couples just barely on opposite sides of the have-and-have-not divide had been rumored for Broadway following acclaimed runs in Chicago and London. (After seeing the play in Chicago, Charles Isherwood hailed Ms. D'Amour as ''a potentially important new voice.'') Instead it opens Playwright Horizons' new season in a new production featuring Amy Ryan and David Schwimmer as the suburban couple slipping down the socioeconomic ladder. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. (Grode)
'An Enemy of the People' (in previews; opens on Sept. 27) For the last 60 years, Henrik Ibsen's one-man-against-the-world social drama has had a perfectly good English-language adaptation by someone who knew a thing or two about standing on principle: Arthur Miller. Now Doug Hughes directs a new adaptation of the 1882 classic by the rising British playwright Rebecca Lenkiewicz; Mr. Hughes's cast is led by Richard Thomas and, as the medical officer in possession of some inconvenient truth, Boyd Gaines. Samuel J. Friedman Theater, 261 West 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200, mtc-nyc.org, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'The Eyes of Others' (in previews; opens on Saturday) What's this? No Bulgarian play has ever received a major New York production? That's what the New Ohio Theater claims, and they're looking to rectify that with this world premiere by Ivan Dimitrov. This absurdist piece, which follows the one-upmanship between two office drones, looks to mesh Vaclav Havel-style paranoia with the deadpan mirth of ''The Office.'' New Ohio Theater, 154 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 868-4444, newohiotheatre.org. (Grode)
'Grace' (previews start on Thursday; opens on Oct. 4) Craig Wright has written Michael Shannon everything from comic tours de force (''Mistakes Were Made'') to downbeat ensemble dramas (''Lady''). Where will Mr. Wright's latest play, about a young couple's benighted plan to open a chain of Bible-themed motels, fall on that continuum? Depending on their ages, audiences may be too busy basking in the presence of either Paul Rudd or Ed Asner to notice. Directed by Dexter Bullard (''Bug,'' ''Killer Joe''). Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'If There Is I Haven't Found It Yet' (in previews; opens on Sept. 20) For many, the main draw for this new comedy will be the American stage debut of Jake Gyllenhaal. But Nick Payne's plays have been generating a wave of buzz in London -- his ''Constellations'' received rapturous notices earlier this year -- and among Mr. Gyllenhaal's co-stars in this one is the always welcome Brian F. O'Byrne (''Doubt,'' ''The Coast of Utopia''). It's about an overweight teenager whose troubles at school come to a head when her drifter uncle shows up for a visit. Laura Pels Theater, Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, 111 West 46th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org. (Grode)
'Job' (in previews; opens on Sept. 19) Thomas Bradshaw's unsparing, envelope-pushing dramas (''Burning,'' ''Southern Promises'') rely on some pretty game actors, and this time Mr. Bradshaw has found a semi-captive talent pool in the Bats, the resident acting company of the Flea Theater. There's also his new antagonist: God. That's right, this is a new adaptation of the biblical book of Job. Brace yourselves, Bats. Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 226-2407, theflea.org. (Grode)
'Marry Me a Little' (previews start on Tuesday; opens on Oct. 2) Back in 1980 this two-character revue served as an introduction to a batch of lesser-known Stephen Sondheim songs. Now that several of them have entered the mainstream (the title song is now a permanent addition to ''Company''), the time is right for the Keen Company to revive it. True to form, two Sondheim compositions will be heard for the first time: a discard from ''Sunday in the Park With George'' and a song written for the unproduced film version of ''Into the Woods.'' Clurman Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'Mary Broome' (in previews; opens on Monday) It's been more than 90 years since New York has seen this 1911 Allan Monkhouse comedy about a fateful dalliance between a wealthy young rotter and the family's live-in housemaid. The young cad has been described as the bastard forebear of the Angry Young Men that engulfed the London stage 50 years later; New York audiences can judge for themselves, courtesy of the Mint Theater's latest excavation. Mint Theater, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (866) 811-4111, minttheater.org. (Grode)
'Moo' (performances start on Saturday) More Howard Zinn than Barnum & Bailey, the one-ring traveling circus known as Circus Amok has been juggling politics and pratfalls for more than 20 years. It brings its latest creation, in which not even the big top is immune to Great Recession-era money troubles, to four of the five boroughs, complete with tightrope walkers, clowns and acrobats to go with its agitprop. At various locations; a full schedule is at circusamok.org. (Grode)
'Open Up, Hadrian' (previews start on Wednesday; opens on Thursday) What do you put in a 20,000-square-foot warehouse space in Sunset Park, Brooklyn? An ''immersive promenade'' about the first celebrity gay couple, of course. Javierantonio González's script looks back to the second century, when the title character was the emperor of Rome. And, yes, Hadrian's wall will make an appearance. Will 20,000 square feet be enough? Magic Futurebox, 55 33rd Street, fourth floor, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, magicfuturebox.com. (Grode)
'Red Dog Howls' (in previews; opens on Sept. 24) What an odd career Alexander Dinelaris has cobbled for himself: spiky romantic dramas (''Still Life''), campy musicals (''Zanna Don't!'') and now a generation-hopping exploration of the Armenian genocide. Joining him this time are the inventive director Ken Rus Schmoll and Kathleen Chalfant, whose own career choices have made her the go-to actress for socially conscious drama (''Wit,'' ''Guantánamo''). As for Mr. Dinelaris? It's off to London to work on the stage adaptation of the Kevin Costner-Whitney Houston opus ''The Bodyguard.'' New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. (Grode)
'Red-Handed Otter' (previews start on Wednesday; opens on Sept. 20) For many theatergoers, Ethan Lipton burst onto the scene in March with his Obie Award-winning cycle of economic woes, ''No Place to Go.'' But he has been plugging away as a gimlet-eyed playwright for years, and he follows last spring's ''Luther'' with this offbeat comedy for Playwrights Realm about a dead house cat and the upheaval it causes among a group of overnight security guards. Quincy Tyler Bernstine (''Ruined'') and Matthew Maher (Soho Rep's ''Uncle Vanya'') are part of the five-member cast. Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, West Village, (212) 532-3101, redhandedotter.com. (Grode)
'Strange Tales of Liaozhai' (in previews; opens on Sunday) The title sounds accurate, seeing as one of the two 18th-century Chinese folk tales on display involves magic pigeons and the whole thing is being conjured by the puppeteer Hanne Tierney and her counterweight system of more than 100 strings. And that's not even taking into consideration the original score, written for toy pianos, double bass and ''self-constructed Asian Space Plates.'' Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 352-3101, here.org. (Grode)
'Through the Yellow Hour' (previews start on Thursday; opens on Sept. 27) In his continuing attempt to make Joyce Carol Oates look like a slacker and a cockeyed optimist, the ever-present Adam Rapp has written and directed another dystopian drama. Last seen at the Rattlestick inflicting the bubonic plague and cholera on a single character (in ''The Hallway Trilogy''), Mr. Rapp this time focuses on a woman struggling to stay alive after a cataclysmic attack on the United States. Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, 224 Waverly Place, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, rattlestick.org. (Grode)
'The Train Driver' (in previews; opens on Monday) The Signature Theater's Athol Fugard season ends the way it began: with Mr. Fugard himself directing a story about the tensions and commonalities between a white man and a black man. First came his 1961 masterwork ''Blood Knot,'' and now it moves a half-century forward to Mr. Fugard's most recent play, in which the title character (Ritchie Coster) enlists the help of a gravedigger (Leon Addison Brown) to help expunge his guilt over a tragedy. Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (Grode)
'The Why Overhead' (in previews; opens on Sunday) New plays by Adam Szymkowicz have become a common but no less welcome occurrence in recent years. His latest, courtesy of Zootopia Theater Company, is a workplace comedy that involves a dozen friends, lovers, frenemies and others, all of whom become even less inhibited than usual when their boss vanishes. Access Theater, 380 Broadway, at White Street, fourth floor, TriBeCa, (800) 838-3006, zootopiatheatre.org, brownpapertickets.com. (Grode)
Broadway
'Bring It On: The Musical' An A-list of musical-theater artists -- Tom Kitt (''Next to Normal''), Lin-Manuel Miranda (''In the Heights''), Jeff Whitty (''Avenue Q'') and Amanda Green -- teamed to create this featherweight concoction inspired by the cult-fave movie about rival cheerleaders. The human pyrotechnics in the cheerleading sequences are the highlight (2:15). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Charles Isherwood)
'Evita' This just in: Eva Perón is still dead. That, anyway, is on the evidence of Michael Grandage's unsmiling revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice's 1978 bio-musical, which feels about as warm-blooded as a gilded mummy. Elena Roger, Michael Cerveris and Ricky Martin are the stars of this earnest combination of requiem mass and history pageant (2:30). Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street, (800) 745-3000, ticketmaster.com. (Ben Brantley)
'The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess' As the fatally conflicted Bess, the extraordinary Audra McDonald is a gale force of emotion in Diane Paulus's slimmed-down adaptation of the landmark 1935 opera. Otherwise, despite a likable performance from Norm Lewis as Porgy, this production feels cloudy and mild, only rarely acquiring the majesty of the opera that inspired it (2:30). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (877) 250-2929, ticketmaster.com. (Brantley)
'Newsies' This Disney musical -- adapted from the 1992 movie and inspired by the newsboy strike of 1899 -- markets Urchin Appeal with extra! extra! enthusiasm. Jeff Calhoun directs a cast of comely, if overgrown, ragamuffins. The largely interchangeable songs are by Alan Menken and Jack Feldman (2:20). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (866) 870-2717, newsiesthemusical.com. (Brantley)
'Nice Work if You Can Get It' Every now and then a bubble of pure, tickling charm rises from the artificial froth of this pastiche 1920s musical, directed by Kathleen Marshall and featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin. But mostly the production, starring Matthew Broderick and Kelli O'Hara, registers as a shiny, dutiful trickle of gags and production numbers (2:30). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
&#x2605; 'Once' This gentle musical, set in Dublin, about a love affair that never quite happens -- based on the 2006 movie -- inventively uses songs (by Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova) and dance to convey a beautiful shimmer of might-have-been regret. Staged by John Tiffany and Steven Hoggett (''Black Watch''), the production stars the immensely appealing Steve Kazee and Cristin Milioti (2:15). Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
&#x2605; 'Peter and the Starcatcher' The most exhilarating and inventive example of story theater since the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby.'' This production, about the boy who became Peter Pan, is an enchanted anatomy of the urge to defy gravity. Roger Rees and Alex Timbers direct (2:10). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (800) 745-3000, ticketmaster.com. (Brantley)
Off Broadway
'Brontë: A Portrait of Charlotte' This one-woman show written by William Luce and starring Maxine Linehan is intelligent and well acted, but it rarely sparks the imagination. The show is missing the one thing it needs: a sense of the genius of Charlotte Brontë (1:55). Actors' Temple Theater, 339 West 47th Street, Manhattan; (212) 489-9800, alloytheater.org. (Rachel Saltz)
'Bullet for Adolf' Woody Harrelson and Frankie Hyman's muddled play about one hot, hedonistic Houston summer in the 1980s has the feeling of a series of oft-recited anecdotes swapped, excitedly and incoherently, over the din of a jukebox in a crowded bar. These guys hit Memory Lane packing megaphones. Bring ear plugs (2:20). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
&#x2605; 'Closer Than Ever' Can it be? Intelligent, tuneful material written by and for men and women whose ingénue years were in the 20th century? Four rock-solid singers give Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire's winning 1989 revue a polished revival (1:30). York Theater at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street, (212) 935-5820, yorktheatre.org. (Grode)
&#x2605; 'Cockfight Play' Though that's not the real (unprintable) title of Mike Bartlett's tense, terrific new comedy, it captures the spirit of this feisty, hypnotic and oddly energizing exercise in emotional carnage, directed by James Macdonald. The four-member cast -- Jason Butler Harner, Amanda Quaid, Cotter Smith and Cory Michael Smith -- superbly embodies degrees of sexual ambivalence (1:30). The Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, (646) 223-3010, dukeon42.org. (Brantley)
'Cougar the Musical' Three older women find themselves attracted to younger men, two against their better judgment. The concept seems made for bus tours, but imagination, appealing numbers with original melodies and theme-transcending jokes lift this show well above the level of ''Menopause: The Musical'' and its ilk (1:30). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Anita Gates)
&#x2605; 'Fried Chicken and Latkes' Rain Pryor, the daughter of the comedian Richard Pryor (who died in 2005), stars in this effervescent solo show, which recounts her upbringing in a biracial household (her mother is Jewish) in Beverly Hills, Calif. Ms. Pryor, who sings and portrays a range of characters (including, poignantly, her father in a spot-on impression) is an ebullient performer with a robust singing voice. She lives in Baltimore now, but her outsize personality is built for Broadway (1:30). Actor's Temple Theater, 339 West 47th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Andy Webster)
&#x2605; 'Harrison, TX: Three Plays by Horton Foote' Three short, piquant plays by Horton Foote that enjoyably consider the gracious art and limitations of Southern conversation. For these characters, conversation is sacred, something to put your faith in along with God and country, which doesn't mean that words don't fail them. Pam MacKinnon directs a cast that includes the extraordinary Hallie Foote (1:50). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. (Brantley)
'Heartless' In his murky new play, Sam Shepard revisits themes of identity and rootlessness that he has addressed with more urgency -- and clarity -- elsewhere. The splendid Lois Smith, as a Gorgon-like matriarch, gives this production what life force it has. And Jenny Bacon is hilarious as her aggrieved daughter. Daniel Aukin directs, with lots of air-devouring pauses (2:00). Pershing Square Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (Brantley)
'New Girl in Town' This 1957 musical adaptation of Eugene O'Neill's ''Anna Christie'' assembled an illustrious team of showmen in the producer Harold Prince, the book writer and original director George Abbott, the composer and lyricist Bob Merrill, and the choreographer Bob Fosse. While Gwen Verdon and Thelma Ritter shared a lead actress Tony Award for their roles in that original production, the show has since remained virtually unseen in New York. Charlotte Moore's staging for the Irish Rep makes a viable case for Merrill's tuneful score, without ever fully convincing that the perky musical treatment has any connection to the roiling emotions of O'Neill's play. It's less a forgotten jewel than an intermittently charming curio from the golden-age vaults (1:50). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737, irishrep.org. (David Rooney)
'Old Jews Telling Jokes' With old jokes, a few songs and a little schmaltz, this winning revue is simple, effective entertainment executed with obvious affection (1:20). Westside Theater, 407 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Jason Zinoman)
'Probation' This work by the Cuban-born playwright-director Yoshvani Medina, about recent Cuban immigrants under the sway of a crooked mentor in Miami, offers a kind of dialectic between pro-American and pro-Cuban sentiments. Though it verges on the didactic at times, the production benefits from the appeal of its cast and the searching integrity of its script (1:40). Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 225-9999, repertorio.org. (Webster)
'Silence! The Musical' A silly, coarse musical spin on ''The Silence of the Lambs'' as pitched to obsessive fans (1:30). Elektra Theater, 674 Eighth Avenue at 42nd Street; (212) 352-3101, silencethemusical.com. (Zinoman)
'Sistas: The Musical' The script is obvious, covering virtually every issue that might touch the lives of black women, but Dorothy Marcic's good-natured, low-budget musical is all about the songs. From ''Ain't Nobody's Business if I Do'' to ''Single Ladies,'' you could do a lot worse (1:30). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Gates)
&#x2605; 'Tribes' Nina Raine's smart, lively and beautifully acted play asks us to hear how we hear, in silence as well as speech. This British import considers the passive and aggressive forms of listening within an insular, intellectual family, whose members include a deaf son. David Cromer is the expert director (2:15). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. (Brantley)
Off Off Broadway
'Color Between the Lines' Rock-musical vignettes introduce audiences to many of Brooklyn's abolitionist heroes, including James Pennington, Henry Ward Beecher and a rescued slave named Pinky. Individually, each of these figures is courageous and compelling. But paraded one after another, the stories become repetitive and almost interchangeable, dissolving into a cacophonous set of musicalized book reports. That said, the cast is energetic and impassioned about sharing their reports with the audience (1:30). At various sites in Brooklyn as part of the Brooklyn Beat Festival. For a full schedule, call (347) 762-3281 or visit beatbrooklyn.com. (Catherine Rampell)
'Dreamgirls' The Harlem Repertory Theater's chamber production of this vintage musical about a Supremes-like 1960s singing group is intimate, inviting and strongly staged. The mostly black and Latino cast members' abilities range from powerhouse to shaky, but the story comes through clearly and Dion Millington's rendition of ''I Am Telling You I'm Not Going'' is a knockout (2:30). 133rd Street Arts Center, 308 West 133rd Street, Harlem, (212) 868-4444, harlemrepertorytheatre.com. (Gates)

HEADLINE: Collaborative and Solo, With a Certain Feminist Bent

BYLINE: By MARTHA SCHWENDENER

 BODY:
Collaboration is one of the hallmarks of feminist art and scholarship. The art system doesn't really accommodate this, however. Instead, criticism, art history and institutions are set up to canonize (historically male) individual artists. And for curators, it's considerably easier to work with one artist than a hundred.
Even the Brooklyn Museum's showcase feminist work, ''The Dinner Party'' (1974-79), has a complicated attribution: it was made collaboratively, although the museum stresses that Judy Chicago ''began it alone.'' Hundreds of volunteers helped create the piece, but only 129 are acknowledged in a series of photographic panels, which are not displayed along with the work. 
In many ways the current project on view at the museum by Ulrike Müller, an Austrian-born artist based in Sunset Park, Brooklyn -- she is also a co-editor of LTTR, a self-described ''independent gender queer feminist art journal'' -- serves as an update, rejoinder and response to Ms. Chicago's landmark work. Spearheaded by one woman, it is nevertheless collaborative. And like ''The Dinner Party,'' with its use of mediums like ceramics and textiles, it celebrates what have often been considered ''minor'' arts in the West, even as it also strives for a level of transparency and egalitarianism around authorship and a formal simplicity that is somewhat lacking in Ms. Chicago's theatrical and bombastic installation.
To make the work Ms. Müller provided written descriptions of T-shirts collected by the Lesbian Herstory Archives in Park Slope and distributed them to feminists, queer artists and ''other interested New Yorkers'' (according to a news release). The participants then created two-dimensional objects based on these descriptions. The results are hung on the walls just off the elevator on four different floors.
The responses range from poignant to political, hilarious to heartbreaking. A wonderful drawing made by Ginger Brooks Takahashi and Dana Bishop-Root from the description ''A graphic of the island of Lesbos with icons depicting different sites and tourists activities'' includes a lovely truncated quote from Sappho, the bard of Lesbos: ''Let me tell you this, someone in some future time will think of us.''
A more contentious relationship between object and description can be seen in Fox Hysen's rendition of ''Ronald Reagan with Day-Glo shocking pink eyes'' on a ''chartreuse background.'' For the work Ms. Hysen simply wrote the words ''Elizabeth Warren'' in dark-pink cursive, replacing the Republican president with the Democratic Senate candidate from Massachusetts and critic of his economic policies.
Many of the works demonstrate a similar logic, reducing or transforming the description into a completely abstract representation. The effect is to assert the agency of the artist and suggest that it is the mandate of feminists to break the rules of patriarchy -- or any authoritarian system (even a description provided by another artist). Works by Keltie Ferris, Linda Stillman, J D Samson, Lee Maida, Mitra Wakil and Jonah Groeneboer have translated their descriptions into spare geometric abstractions. This is true too of Ms. Müller's own submission, ''Abstract design with clitoris in the center,'' which consists of black, white and red concentric circles with a bright red circle at the center.
Some of the works include editorial statements, like Mariah Garnett's pencil-drawn rendition of ''A caricature of a woman with large breasts and wild hair inside a circle with words,'' which states that she found the image too depressing to complete. Moyra Davey's ''vase with dead flowers'' has a note addressed to Ms. Müller on its lower left-hand corner, explaining that she ''gave up'' on drawing the image with make up and took a photograph instead.
Among the 100 collaborators are many well-known artists: Louise Fishman, Amy Sillman, Marlene McCarty, Zoe Leonard, Nicole Eisenman, Sadie Benning, Faith Wilding, R. H. Quaytman, Emily Roysdon, A. L. Steiner, Gregg Bordowitz, Robert Bordo -- as well as participants better known through music channels, like Kathleen Hanna and J D Samson. It feels sacrilegious to single them out, because this goes against the tenor of the project, which is to display the works next to one another without privilege or advantage. At the same time the participation of ''bigger'' artists in this collective project shows the advances feminist art has made within the current system since Ms. Chicago's moment.
Along with the work created for ''Raw/Cooked'' -- as the museum's series showcasing contemporary Brooklyn artists is called -- Ms. Müller has selected objects from the museum's collection that illustrate words and concepts significant within feminist and lesbian traditions: flower, hand, rainbow, triangle, ax. It is interesting to see Elsa Tennhardt's 1928 silver-plated pepper shakers within the context of the triangle, or a pair of tiny American Indian (possibly Osage) baskets made of bark. Their presence here suggests a world of objects overlooked in the greater scope of a museum collection.
But the best part of the project is the living, breathing collaboration on the walls -- and that it began with T-shirts, which, despite their ubiquity and visual power, rarely make it into any museum at all.
''Raw/Cooked: Ulrike Müller'' continues through Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park; (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org.
PHOTO: An abstract by Adriana Minoliti is among the pieces in ''Raw/Cooked: Ulrike Müller.'' (PHOTOGRAPH COURTESY OF THE ARTIST, BROOKLYN MUSEUM)

HEADLINE: A President's Brief Respite

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG; Allison Kopicki and Mark Landler contributed reporting.

 BODY:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Presidential candidates can usually count on luxuriating in a few days of warm feelings from their convention as they ride the high generated by impassioned supporters and cross their fingers for rising poll numbers.
But for President Obama, the party could come to an abrupt halt even before he breaks camp here Friday morning when the government releases its employment report for August, a blunt reminder of the forces working against him.
The Democrats inside the hall here on Thursday night as Mr. Obama accepted his party's nomination for a second term defined the race as a fundamental clash of visions between Republicans who want an every-man-for-himself society and Democrats who want to ensure that the middle class gets a fair shake -- what Mr. Obama called ''the clearest choice of any time in a generation.''
But that message of promise for the future is up against the immediacy of persistently high unemployment, which, no matter what Friday's report shows, is unlikely to drop so much before Election Day that it will recede as an issue. 
So the biggest question for Mr. Obama as he heads into the home stretch against Mitt Romney and the Republicans is whether he can make the race about sufficiently big and compelling issues, and draw a sharp enough contrast between what his policies and Mr. Romney's would mean for the middle class in the years ahead, to keep the outcome from being swayed by constant reminders of the shaky state of the economy.
The answer, and the result in November, will turn in large part on which is more potent: Mr. Obama's argument that he offers a way toward ''a better place'' for struggling middle class voters whom Democrats say Mr. Romney does not understand, or the more troublesome reality of the moment for voters as they ponder Mr. Romney's question about whether they are better off than four years ago.
From the start, Mr. Obama's campaign aides acknowledged that they were attempting something of a Houdini act in seeking to push the focus of the election ''Forward,'' as their slogan goes, beyond the ''now'' that is harder to pretty up.
Now leaving the cloister of his national convention, and the free network airtime it gave him to put forward his strongest case unopposed, Mr. Obama will be in an environment in which Mr. Romney can use his well-financed general election bank account to outspend him on advertising and hammer home the message that Mr. Obama had his chance and failed.
Obama campaign officials are also mindful that any major economic disruption in the next two months could impede their efforts to focus on the future. They are tracking oil futures so they have a handle on possible gasoline price increases and watching developments in Europe to be on top of any possible financial crisis as much as they are analyzing Gallup tracking polls.
Even before Mr. Obama gave his acceptance speech here, Mr. Romney's aides were pointing to the statistics that went unmentioned in the progression of feel-good speeches that at times made the Time Warner Cable Arena feel like a hermetically sealed Democratic Happyland.
''The middle class has been crushed these past four years, and all the president is offering is more negative commercials and stale ideas,'' said Stuart Stevens, Mr. Romney's strategist. ''As Governor Romney said, 'It's still the economy and we're not stupid.' ''
Democrats, who play down the prospects of any major polling lift for Mr. Obama, acknowledge that they do not have an easy case to make. ''It's hard,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York. ''But don't forget this: If people can be given an explanation of the past, they want to believe in the future.''
Mr. Schumer argued that former President Bill Clinton had managed to do that here on Wednesday night with his point-by-point look at the historically grim economy Mr. Obama inherited and the 4.5 million private jobs created during his term -- not enough to cover all the damage from the recession, which Mr. Clinton said he could not have fixed in one term himself.
Mr. Obama's aides say they are convinced that voters are more likely to base their choice for president more on what they think will be best for them in the next four years than on what transpired in the last four.
They are taking comfort in the idea that they have succeeded in turning the race into ''a choice between two different paths,'' as Mr. Obama put it on Thursday night -- beating back Mr. Romney's attempts to define the election as a referendum on Mr. Obama's tenure. Any doubt that he wanted that message to get through was dispelled when it used the word ''choice'' some 20 times in his 38-minute speech.
Democrats say Mr. Romney, who is running close to Mr. Obama in national polls, helped along the process of making the election a choice by picking as his running mate Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, whose conservative budget proposals make the policy differences between the parties that much clearer.
They are battling history as much as the current reality. Polls are full of the sort of numbers that have ended presidencies in the past, with frequent poor marks on his handling of the economy and a sense that the country is moving in the wrong direction.
But Mr. Obama's aides are counting on the notion that each election is unique, not fated by history. And they have other poll numbers that give them heart, including those showing that majorities agree that the wealthy do not pay their fair share of taxes, that job creation is helped along by spending on public projects, and that blame for the economic situation rests more with his predecessor than with him.
''We put the last four years in perspective last night about what the situation was when we took office,'' Stephanie Cutter, Mr. Obama's deputy campaign manager, said Thursday, ''and how we're on the right path.''
That made the delegates and lawmakers in the arena here feel better. ''A lot of people came in feeling sort of nervous after the Republican convention,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont. ''I feel a lot more optimism than I did before I came,'' he said.
Whether that optimism will prove justified will likely depend upon not only Friday's jobs report but on the one after that, the one after that and on Mr. Obama's ability to keep the focus beyond them.

HEADLINE: Character, Not Audacity

BYLINE: By DAVID BROOKS

 BODY:
Charlotte, N.C.
As I listened to President Obama on stage in Charlotte, N.C., Thursday night, I thought back to the days more than four years ago, when he spoke at a Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Iowa, or on the night he won the caucuses of that state. There was his romantic vision, the possibility of transformational change.
I don't know if we are worse off now than we were back then, but we were certainly worse off then than we knew. The financial crisis of the past years has exposed debilitating flaws in our way of life. It's exposed the crushing burden of debt and the unsustainability of our entitlement system. It's exposed flaws in our style of capitalism -- the overreliance on finance, the concentration of power. It exposed a widening education gap; the educated have recovered from the recession while the unskilled fall further behind. It exposed even deeper dysfunctions in our political system. 
Obama was rhetorically grand back then, but many of us have spent this year looking for even bigger strategies and policies.
The Republicans understand the severity of our economic problems, but they put too much faith in tax cuts. The Republicans understand that unless Medicare is reformed, it will swallow everything else, though judging from their convention, they are too timid to explain the problem or champion their own plan.
So, as I looked to President Obama's speech Thursday night, I was looking to see if he was capable of a new burst of change.
There were parts of his speech that raised the old expectations. I liked the emphasis he put not on himself but on the word ''you'' -- the idea that change comes organically from the bottom up. I liked his extraordinary self-awareness, his willingness to admit that often life on the campaign trail requires candidates to do silly things. I liked the sense of citizenship that pervaded his address, the sense of mutual obligation.
But what I was mostly looking for were big proposals, big as health care was four years ago. I had spent the three previous days watching more than 80 convention speeches without hearing a single major policy proposal in any of them. I asked governors, mayors and legislators to name a significant law that they'd like to see President Obama pass in a second term. Not one could. At its base, this is a party with a protective agenda, not a change agenda -- dedicated to defending government in all its forms.
The Obama speech offered some important if familiar hints of big policy ideas. There was a vague hint of a major tax reform. There was a vague promise to accept an agreement based on the principle of the Simpson-Bowles committee on deficit reduction. But it's hard to be enthusiastic about President Obama truly championing initiatives that get no more than a sentence or a clause.
Over all, the speech had a fierce opposition toward the Republicans and a desire for incremental continuity about what the Democrats themselves would offer. Worse, the speech was dominated by unexplained goals that were often worthy, but also familiar, modest and incommensurate with the problems at hand. The government should help more students attend community colleges. It should recruit more math and science teachers. These are good existing programs, but these are not policies to pinion a presidency around.
It would be nice if exports doubled. It would be nice if deficits came down gradually over the next 10 years. But the goals President Obama set in these spheres will probably be met if everybody in Washington carried on the status quo. They do not entail big change.
President Obama offered other small and worthy ideas, familiar to him since his days in the Senate, that would make America better -- more long-lasting batteries, more trade agreements. But these are improvements fit for countries that are already firmly on the right track.
The country that exists is not on the right track. It has a completely dysfunctional political system. What was there in this speech that will make us think the next few years will be any different? America will only be governable again if there is a leader who breaks the mold and reframes the debate. Romney is unlikely to do that, and Obama's speech didn't offer much either.
In short, change is still the issue, and the focus of his solid but not extraordinary speech was incremental improvement. The next president has to do three big things, which are in tension with one another: increase growth, reduce debt and increase social equity. President Obama has the intelligence, the dexterity and the sense of balance to navigate these crosscutting challenges. But he apparently lacks the creativity to break out of the partisan categories, the trench warfare gridlock.
Thursday night's speech showed the character and his potential. It didn't show audacity and the fulfillment of that potential.

HEADLINE: Singaporean Tells China U.S. Is Not in Decline

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

 BODY:
BEIJING -- In an unusual public airing of strategic problems surrounding China's rise, the prime minister of Singapore, Lee Hsien Loong, warned China on Thursday that it should view the United States not as a declining power, but as a nation with the ability to innovate and bounce back.
Speaking at the Central Party School, the prestigious training ground for officials of the Communist Party, Mr. Lee also suggested that China try to solve its maritime disputes in the South China Sea regionally, through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, known as Asean, rather than country by country. 
Mr. Lee is the son of Lee Kuan Yew, the longtime leader of Singapore who forged strong relations with China and the United States and successfully balanced his small city-state between the two, and his views carry considerable weight among the Chinese elite. By choosing to make his pointed remarks in a prime setting like the Central Party School, the prime minister was ensuring that they carried extra heft. The president of the school is Vice President Xi Jinping, expected to be the next leader of China.
Mr. Lee addressed the question of America's standing in the world, a subject that fascinates Chinese academics and writers in the state-run news media, many of whom have written caustically in recent months about Washington's budget difficulties, political gridlock and what they see as a crisis of confidence.
''It is currently facing some very difficult problems, but it is not a nation in decline,'' Mr. Lee said of the United States. ''The U.S. is an enormously resilient and creative society, which attracts and absorbs talent from all over the world, including many from China and the rest of Asia.''
In a subtle jab at China, Mr. Lee noted, ''All eight Nobel Prize winners in science who are of Chinese descent either were or subsequently became American citizens.''
''We should never underestimate the U.S. capacity to reinvigorate and reinvent itself,'' he said.
Singapore is considered an important post for the United States military presence in Asia. American aircraft carriers and other warships use Singapore's port, which sits astride the South China Sea. Last year, Singapore agreed to an American request to allow four new littoral combat ships, a new category of fast warship, to use its facilities.
At the same time, Singapore maintains a strong relationship with Beijing, which began when Deng Xiaoping visited the country in 1978 and was impressed that Lee Kuan Yew's stern governance was accompanied by economic prosperity.
Mr. Lee's appearance at the Communist Party school came after China effectively shattered Southeast Asian unity on how to deal with disputes in the South China Sea, a tactic that shocked Washington and Singapore alike.
At a meeting in Cambodia in July that was attended by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, China managed to quash an agreement on the South China Sea among members of Asean. Some Southeast Asian officials said they believed that China was emboldened by a belief that the United States was a waning power that lacked the clout to keep Asean unified.
In his speech, Mr. Lee said Asean ''has to take and state a position which is neutral, forward-looking and encourages the peaceful resolution of issues.''
''For Asean not to address it would severely damage its credibility,'' he continued. Moreover, Asean and China should soon start talks on a code of conduct designed to help resolve conflicts, he said.
This was a position put forward by Mrs. Clinton during her visit to Beijing this week, which so far the Chinese have resisted.
Lee Kuan Yew wrote in his memoirs that he told the Chinese leader, Mr. Deng, that the countries of Asia were more afraid of the ''China dragon'' than the ''Russian bear.'' His son appeared to be beaming, indirectly, a variant of that message to his Chinese audience on Thursday.
The prime minister closed his speech by saying he believed that ''the Chinese government and people are determined to overcome its various challenges.'' But without being explicit, Mr. Lee seemed to be echoing his father, and suggesting that in Asia, China was more feared than the United States.

HEADLINE: Cuomo, in Brief Visit to Convention City, Gives a Spirited Speech From a Small Stage

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BARBARO

 BODY:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. - Giant clusters of red, white and blue balloons hung overhead and an imposing black rope line stretched across the room. Campaign-style bunting festooned the podium and Bon Jovi's "Working for the Working Man" blared through loudspeakers. A seasoned political spouse leapt to her feet at applause lines, and the candidate shouted to be heard over an adoring crowd.
As Democrats assembled for their convention this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo steadfastly refused to appear on his party's biggest stage. 
Instead, he set up his own inside a white banquet tent on the asphalt parking lot of a Doubletree Hotel on the outskirts of the city.
The scene at the Cuomo Convention on Thursday may have lacked TV-ready glamour (those balloons aside), but the result was no less splashy: the governor of New York delivered a stemwinder of a speech - filled with tart-tongued denunciations of Republican economic policies and praise for New York as a progressive ideal for the country - that intensified speculation about his White House ambitions for 2016.
With its conflicting message and goal, the site seemed to perfectly encapsulate Mr. Cuomo himself at the moment, at once wanting to be a Big Deal but worried about becoming a Big Deal.
Since taking office last January, Mr. Cuomo has all but penned himself into the state, avoiding any out-of-town travel and high-profile speaking engagements that might expose him to the unforgiving scrutiny of the national political press.
Here in Charlotte, that reluctance seemed magnified. The governor waited until Thursday morning to fly in from New York, skipping the first two days of his party's gathering and the parties that surround it. To avoid unwanted headlines, he canceled a fund-raiser with top Democratic donors.
And yet.
On Thursday, inside the tent, he sounded unmistakably like a man with ambitions well beyond Albany.In a speech by turns stirring and scathing, he drew on his experience in Albany - and legislative achievements on taxes, education and same-sex marriage - as a blueprint for how Democrats can govern nationally.
It was clear that, despite the out-of-the-way location, his remarks were more tailored to the national audience in the convention hall, as he slipped between addressing his audience as "New Yorkers" and "America."
He called on the country to embrace his vision of progressivism, describing the choice between President Obama and Mitt Romney as a "gut-check election" and the "truest test of who we are."
"Do you believe in interconnection and interrelation and, do you believe that I am connected to you, to you and to you?" he asked, pointing to people in the crowd, his voice rising to a full shout as audience members stood and clapped madly.
"And there is a chord that connects us all. And that chord weaves a fabric. And when one of us is raised, we are all raised. And when one of us is lowered, we are all lowered. Do you believe that the sweetest success is shared success, when we all do well?"
Mr. Cuomo rarely engages in partisan broadsides, emphasizing his across-the-aisle diplomacy with members of the New York Legislature.
But on Thursday he starkly departed from that script, variously deriding the speeches and policies articulated at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., last week as "absurd" and "obnoxious."
"I found it amusing. It was great theater - it was theater," he said, smiling. "That's why the actors felt so at home."
He reserved his deepest disdain for the claim, made by Mr. Romney and his running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, that cutting taxes for the nation's wealthiest will, as Mr. Cuomo put it, "unleash the American entrepreneurial spirit."
In an extended riff, he mocked this "American spirit they talk about all the time."
"That great mystic spirit will come out," he continued. "The American spirit has a special wand and he will wave the wand. And everything will be O.K."
"No," Mr. Cuomo added. "When you cut taxes on the rich, there is no spirit that appears. The rich people get more money."
Like Mr. Cuomo himself these days, the event toggled between local and national, polished and rough, big and small. The Syracuse mayor made self-deprecating jokes as Mr.
Cuomo's glamorous girlfriend, the Food Network personality Sandra Lee, turned heads among the wait staff.
As the governor sat onstage, waiting to speak, a state senator and local union official received the state Democratic Party's highest honor: the "Progressive Tax Reform Achievement Award." (Mr. Cuomo posed for photos with both.)
But in the moments after he finished speaking, the normally voluble and friendly governor, who is known for mingling with reporters, suddenly seemed more like a national candidate, quickly dashing out through a side door and hopping into a waiting S.U.V., which whisked him away.
This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HEADLINE: From Convention Floor, Delegates Give Obama Benefit of Their Doubts

BYLINE: By CARL HULSE; Will Storey contributed reporting.

 BODY:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- In a perfect world, Sara Riley, a delegate to the Democratic National Convention from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, would have preferred that President Obama had done more to fulfill what the party saw as the transformative nature of the 2008 campaign and election.
''Would I have liked to seen Gitmo closed? Yes,'' said Ms. Riley, a personal injury lawyer, referring to the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. ''However, the Senate and House, Republicans and Democrats alike, voted not to allow funding. How is he going to close Gitmo if he doesn't have the money? 
''He has done a lot,'' Ms. Riley said as the convention swirled around her at the Time Warner Cable Arena. ''He hasn't done everything.''
As they prepared to leave their party's convention after three speech-filled nights here, Ms. Riley and the hundreds of grass-roots activists, union members, local government officials, educators and other Democrats who served as delegates acknowledged that the president had fallen short in some areas. The tone in Washington remains sharply partisan, powerful special interests wield tremendous influence, the economy is sluggish, climate change legislation has stalled and the health care law was largely a purely Democratic product.
But in about two dozen interviews, they said the president had earned a second term to finish what he started. The delegates blame not Mr. Obama, but his determined opponents -- as well as the scope of the problems he inherited -- for any work left undone.
''We have to face the reality of 2008 and what we were facing as a country,'' said Janet Payne, a retired school administrator from Fredericksburg, Va., who saw her savings dwindle in the economic collapse. ''I don't think anybody else could have done what he did.''
''We know when we started this in '08 there were major, major problems,'' said Renee Watson, a delegate and economic development officer from San Antonio. ''America was hurting.''
She and other delegates echoed a message that was also reinforced from the podium: If Mr. Obama has not turned the nation completely around, it is because he faced a confluence of threatening events that defied precedent and quick solution.
''I want to nominate a man who ran for president to change the course of an already weak economy and then just six weeks before his election saw it suffer the biggest collapse since the Great Depression, a man who stopped the slide into depression and put us on the long road to recovery,'' former President Bill Clinton said Wednesday night in sentiments expressed repeatedly in Charlotte.
''He had a long way to go,'' said Alice Boyd, a delegate and retired teacher from Des Moines. ''We had all been in a very deep hole, and he has been providing us shovels to get out. He had a tough four years, but he had a long way to go.''
While some elements of the party may have been angry at Mr. Obama during points in his term, given his refusal to embrace a government-run plan as part of the new health care law or what they saw as foot-dragging on Iraq and Afghanistan, the delegates in Charlotte were not looking back.
''My God, the man got more than any human being could have gotten when he became president,'' said Rosalind Wyman, 81, a retiree from Los Angeles who has attended every Democratic convention since 1952. ''He's moved us along, we're not in a depression, the stock market is up, we've had jobs for 29 months. What do you want?''
The delegates on the floor, like many of the convention speakers, aimed much of their fire at Congressional Republicans, accusing them of purposefully standing in the president's way to build their own political power and of thwarting efforts that could have accelerated the economic recovery.
''He spent a lot of time trying to build consensus and buy-in from both sides; I almost wonder if that backfired,'' said Sabrina Sanders of Long Beach, Calif. ''He was so undermined from the other side, I feel like we lost a sense of civility from the Republican Party.''
''This has been a huge mountain to climb, and Barack Obama has made incredible progress in the face of obstacles that the Republicans joyfully put up,'' said Ed O'Shea, a delegate from New York.
John P. Gulino, a lawyer from Staten Island, compared the president's task to restoring a failing business. ''As a lawyer and as a businessman, I understand the concept of taking over a defunct business, if you want to call it that, and bringing it back,'' he said. ''It's not that easy; it can't be done in four years.''
Others argued that Mr. Obama's full set of accomplishments was not being recognized and that the campaign needed to do more to remind voters of what had been done.
''Look at the record,'' said Tony Alexander, a union activist and delegate from San Jose, Calif. ''Two Supreme Court judges; the National Labor Relations Board, incredible; passing affordable health care, incredible. Look back, look over your shoulder and see where we were 8, 12 years ago and where we are now. We are moving forward. Forward, not back.''
