Of this group, Martinez and Murray are two players with a great chance of moving up the list. Martinez needs a big game against the Bruins to follow up his start against Southern Mississippi, when he was superb. All eyes will be on tonight's game between Georgia and Missouri - by extension, all eyes will be on Murray.
4:02 P.M. | 3:30 p.m. games to watch
Games we'll be tracking among the 3:30 p.m. starts:
Syracuse vs. U.S.C. (Hunter Atkins on site)
Florida at Texas A&M (likewise with Tom Spousta)
Purdue at Notre Dame
South Florida at Nevada
3:58 P.M. | A&M gets on the board
Sumlin apparently thinks he's still got Case Keenum at quarterback. A&M comes out firing behind Manziel, go 66 yards in 15 plays, and kick a 27-yard field goal for 3-0 lead on its first possession in the SEC. Might have been 7-0, but Manziel was 3 yards over the line of scrimmage when he threw a 7-yard touchdown pass.
Gators looked a bit stunned. Did well to hold Aggies to a field goal.
3:47 P.M. | Another update from Tom Spousta:
SEC Commissioner Mike Slive just announced it as "SEC Day," including his trip to Missouri in his festive pregame comments. Slive will toss a commerative here, then leave in the middle of second quarter for Columbia, Mo., and do the coin toss for Mizzou vs. Georgia.
Slive said he soaked in some of A&M's traditions, including Yell Practice on Friday night, when about 40,000 Aggies show up at Kyle Field and, well, practice yelling.
"It's a historic day," Slive said. "The preliminaries are over, and now we're going to play football and watch how they can compete."
3:46 P.M. | An update from Tom Spousta at Kyle FIeld
Hey from Kyle Field, and what's being hailed as a historic day - by the SEC and Texas A&M, anyway. Quite the buzz here, and folks are finally ready for actual blocking and tackling.
That, and to see how redshirt freshman Johnny Manziel, who's never taken a college snap, runs new coach Kevin Sumlin's Air Raid offense imported from Houston. We'll see how much it's toned down from what he and Case Keenum ran at Houston.
Gorgeous day. A few clouds, temperatures in the 80s, fans waving their white towels and the place is about to start swaying!
3:39 P.M. | SEC life begins at Texas A&M
What's the best atmosphere I've seen in college football over the last half-decade? It came in College Station, in 2010, when Texas A&M hosted Nebraska. It gave the Aggies an unstoppable home-field advantage - it was an SEC-like atmosphere, in fact.
When the Aggies are rolling, there are few stadiums as special as Kyle Field. And for you first-time visitors, take heed: "Please do not be alarmed as the press box will move during the Aggie War Hymn."
3:34 P.M. | Final: Virginia 17, Penn State 16
A final in Charlottesville: Penn State falls, 17-16. Sam Ficken missed a 42-yard field goal as time expired. Virginia staked a dramatic final drive, finally scoring with a six-yard touchdown pass by Michael Rocco to Jake McGee with 1:28 remaining. Penn State falls to 0-2 for the first time since 2001, and this one was a heart-breaker. The three missed field goals (and extra point) really came back to haunt them.
3:21 P.M. | Hunter Atkins from U.S.C.-Syracuse
Want to know what to watch for in today's U.S.C.-Syracuse game at MetLife Stadium?
Look up. Because that is where the ball will almost always be today.
Who could have predicted that Curtis McNeal and Silas Redd, both 1,000-yard rushers in 2011, would have combined to carry the ball 14 times in U.S.C.'s 49-10 victory over Hawaii last week? Perhaps Lane Kiffin designed an early boost for quarterback Matt Barkley's Heisman Trophy campaign. Barkly passed for 372 yards and four touchdowns.
But Syracuse quarterback Ryan Nassib made his own case for the better gunslinger, leading the nation in completions (45), passing yards (482) and total offense (512 yards) in a 42-41 loss to Northwestern last Saturday.
Syracuse lost to Northwestern after a stirring 28-point rally gave the Orange a 41-35 lead with less than three minutes to play, but the Wildcats rallied to score the decisive touchdown in the final minute to extend a six-game losing streak dating back to last October.
Dubbed the inaugural "New York's College Classic," Syracuse (0-1) and No. 2 U.S.C. (1-0) will meet for the second year in a row. Behind five touchdown passes from Matt Barkley, the Trojans beat the Orange, 38-17, a year ago in Los Angeles. This game will be one of three games in five days at MetLife Stadium. On Wednesday, Tony Romo led the Dallas Cowboys over Eli Manning and the Giants. Barkley and U.S.C. invade today. And former Trojan Mark Sanchez will start for the New York Jets against the Buffalo Bills on Sunday - with one of college football's legends, Tim Tebow, waiting in the wings.
Barkley is anticipating what he called "a blast of a weekend," earlier this week. His image streamed across a video board in Times Square this week and today is his 22nd birthday. The Orange's porous defense seems gift-wrapped for a big celebration. Northwestern quarterbacks completed 22 of 32 passes for 213 yards in its win over the Orange and the Trojans are 26-point favorites today.
Still, Nassib gives the Orange a chance of a close shoot-out.
"I feel like if we can keep it close, play them tough all game long and not let the game get away from us, I think we've got a good shot," Nassib said earlier this week.
An upset win for Syracuse could buck a decade of mediocrity. The Orange have had two winning seasons since 2001.
Syracuse head coach Doug Marrone, who grew up in the Bronx, acknowledged that Saturday's game will be a showcase for prospective recruits, even if it makes for a challenging trip for the hometown faithful upstate.
Plenty of Syracuse and U.S.C. fans flooded Penn Station and practically hijacked the transit system, turning it into a string of high-speed rally buses to New Jersey.
"It's like we turned the NJ Transit system into a frat party," said Sarah, who graduated from Syracuse in May and spent most of the ride embarrassed by her boyfriend's outlandish displays of fandom.
Joe, a mechanical engineering major, held an informal poll on the train when he raised his hand and shouted: "Who here is unemployed?"
"I haven't been looking to hard," Joe said of finding a job. He said that Syracuse gamedays will hold him back even further.
"This makes me never want to get a job," he said as he clutched a case of 30 light beers.
Joe looked over his shoulder at Sarah and added, "She made me leave the whiskey at home."
3:04 P.M. | Mississippi State, Miami (Fla.) unprecedented
How rare is Mississippi State's forthcoming win over Auburn? (The Bulldogs have the ball, up by 28-10, with eight minutes left in the fourth quarter.)
The Bulldogs have not won an SEC opener since 1999. Eight of the 12 conference-opening losses over this span have come against Auburn.
Nor has Mississippi State beat a SEC West team other than Mississippi since Dan Mullen took over in 2009. This is a big win for Mullen and this program.
How about Miami (Fla.), currently losing, 45-9, to Kansas State? The Hurricanes have lost only two games by 30 or more points since 2000: the 2005 Peach Bowl to L.S.U. (40-3) and in 2007 at Oklahoma (51-13).
This specific team is historically bad. And what does Miami's showing against the Wildcats say about Boston College, which lost, 41-32, to the Hurricanes last Saturday?
3:00 P.M. | Penn State surges ahead
Penn State has scored nine unanswered points and leads, 16-10, with 10:55 remaining in the fourth. It grabbed the lead when the tight end Allen Robinson made a terrific diving catch in the end zone, and the kicker Sam Ficken finally put a field goal through, this time from 32 yards. Setting up for a good finish here.
2:47 P.M. | A second update on Devon Walker
A second update on Tulane's Devon Walker, who was injured late in the first half of the Green Wave's game at Tulsa:
Rece Davis of ESPN reports that Walker is in stable condition at a nearby hospital, confirming Curtis Johnson's earlier statement. Keep Walker in your thoughts.
2:42 P.M. | Sims in; a storm's coming
Heading to the fourth quarter now, still 10-7, Virginia. The Cavs have put the former Alabama transfer Philip Sims in the game at quarterback, looking for something, anything, to happen offensively. It's starting to get cloudy here, too, and I hear a storm is coming. Mom, if you're reading this, I'm safe in a press box.
2:26 P.M. | Anthony Fera's transfer looms large
Hey, it's understandable. We don't think about kickers - we focus on quarterbacks, running backs and receivers. So while the headlines focused on Silas Redd leaving for U.S.C., Rob Bolden for L.S.U. and Justin Brown for Oklahoma, few considered how Anthony Fera's transfer to Texas would impact Penn State in Bill O'Brien's first season.
So far? Instead of Redd (or his former backup), the Nittany Lions started a walk-on at running back. After Matt McGloin was injured, the offense was forced to turn to the true freshman Steven Bench, not Bolden. Without Brown in the mix, O'Brien used a linebacker, Gerald Hodges, on punt returns against Ohio (O'Brien has since had a change of heart).
And what of Fera? Without the team's former kicker and punter, O'Brien has been forced to turn to the sophomore kicker Sam Ficken - to disastrous results. Ficken has missed three field goals, most recently a 20-yard chip shot; as a result, Virginia has maintained its 10-7 lead.
No one thinks about the kicker, until his backup misses three field goals and your team loses by a touchdown or less.
2:16 P.M. | Virginia moves ahead against Penn State
Virginia takes its first lead at 9:22 in the third quarter on a one-yard pass from Michael Rocco to the tight end Jeremiah Mathis. That capped a 77-yard opening drive, which nearly equaled their entire offensive output from the first half (95 yards). Penn State still without Matt McGloin and are facing an uphill battle, indeed.
2:13 P.M. | Curtis Johnson on Devon Walker
An update on Devon Walker:
Tulane head coach Curtis Johnson tells Fox Sports' Desmond Purnell that Walker "was breathing again and he is stable."
2:09 P.M. | Tulane defensive back injured
A developing story coming out of this afternoon's game between Tulane and Tulsa:
Tulane defensive back Devon Walker, a former walk-on who was recently put on scholarship, suffered an apparent neck injury late in the first half. Walker suffered a head-to-head blow with a teammate as both tackled a Tulsa wide receiver.
According to Bill Haisten of the Tulsa World, medical personnel appeared to be administering C.P.R. on the field.
Fox Sports, which is broadcasting the game, reported that Walker had stopped breathing, requiring resuscitation. He is considered to be in "stable" condition, per Fox Sports.
Walker was taken off the field in an ambulance, joined by Tulane athletic director Rick Dickson, after being strapped onto a board and placed on a stretcher.
I'll update as more information comes in from Tulsa.
1:56 P.M. | No Watkins, no problem for Clemson
Oh, what is Clemson doing to do without Sammy Watkins? How will the Tigers survive?
Life without Watkins is going quite well, thank you. For one, the Tigers still have the offensive coordinator Chad Morris - and as long as Morris is around, the Tigers' offense will run with the best of 'em. (Clemson has given Morris the sort of contract that should ensure he sticks around until a team offers him a head coaching job, which should be soon.)
And the Tigers also have Nuk Hopkins. Last year's second banana, Hopkins has filled Watkins' shoes with style. In last week's win over Auburn, Hopkins set a new school record with 13 receptions. In the first half of today's game against Ball State, Hopkins has tied a school record with three touchdown grabs.
Quickly, Hopkins has gone from wildly underrated as a secondary option to the A.C.C.'s most prolific receiver. What does this mean for Clemson? It's just another weapon that opponents - like Florida State, for example - must consider when planning a defense that can slow down this offense. It's a major, major development for an already potent attack.
1:45 P.M. | Temple lays a first-half egg against Maryland
It's all Maryland, thanks to a 23-point second quarter. Heading into halftime, the Terrapins hold a 26-3 lead. Bully for you, Maryland. And for you, Temple? Get your act in gear.
Through 30 minutes, the Owls' statistical line includes the following gems: two first downs (one via a Maryland penalty), one completed pass, three points, five penalties, four fumbles (lost two), 1.3 yards per carry.
It's hard to find the right word to describe such a performance. Gruesome? Horrific? Hilarious? (If you're a Maryland fan, a Villanova fan, etc.)
Big East jokes are low-hanging fruit, so let's be serious: Temple losing by 23 points to Maryland - a really weak team, in my opinion - is just bad for the league. It's not good. I thought that the Owls would be the Big East's worst team in 2012, but to get your doors blown off by the Terrapins reflects poorly on your team and your league.
1:35 P.M. | Halftime in Charlottesville
It's halftime at Scott Stadium, and I'd say that the story here is really how poor the Cavaliers are playing. The offense turned the ball over twice and has been sluggish, to say the least. A 46-yard field goal is the only thing they have to show for it. Meanwhile, Penn State is currently winning without its starting quarterback or running back. And as far as atmosphere goes, I've seen Tim Rohan wear hats with more eccentricity than the crowd has shown here so far.
1:18 P.M. | U.C.F.'s busy offseason
U.C.F.'s offseason, in brief: Big East, N.C.A.A. violations, N.C.A.A. appeal. Let's go down the line.
U.C.F. has been a member of Conference USA since 2005; before joining the league, the Knights spent three years in the Mid-American Conference (2002-4) and six years (1996-2001) as an F.B.S. Independent. (From 1979, when the program debuted, through 1995, U.C.F. spent time in Division III, Division II and in the F.C.S.)
Come 2013, U.C.F. will join three others Conference USA programs in making a move to the Big East - joining Memphis, S.M.U. and Houston.
Now, the violations. Propelled by a story by Pete Thamel, then of The New York Times, the N.C.A.A. in 2011 began investigating U.C.F.'s relationship with Ken Caldwell, a Chicago man who had allegedly given more than $16,000 in impermissible benefits to 11 U.C.F. men's basketball and football recruits. 
U.C.F. self-imposed penalties, putting its athletic department on three years of probation and placing recruiting limitations on both athletic programs - decreasing the number of official visits the men's basketball and football programs could use during a given year. 
In late July, the N.C.A.A. added another penalty: U.C.F.'s men's basketball and football programs will be ineligible for postseason play during the 2012-13 academic year. For the football team, a postseason ban includes the conference title game. The only silver lining for U.C.F. is that the penalties assessed by the N.C.A.A. did not extend into the 2013-14 year, when the university joins the Big East.
Finally, the appeal. The penalties would not have extended in 2013-14, rather, if U.C.F. hadn't opted to appeal its postseason ban. In short, the Knights might win the appeal, meaning the program will not undergo any ban whatsoever. Win or lose, the appeal will likely continue through this coming season - meaning that U.C.F., if it loses the appeal, would be ineligible for postseason play in its first year as part of the Big east.
1:18 P.M. | Injury news for Penn State
Bad news for the Nittany Lions: the quarterback Matt McGloin was taken to the locker room with 8:16 left in the second quarter. It looks like he was favoring his right shoulder. He got crushed on a pass attempt that went incomplete, the second time in the last couple of minutes that he took a hard shot to that right side. We'll see if he can come back. Steven Bench, a freshman, is the backup. Penn State still leads, 7-0.
12:51 P.M. | Maryland and Temple meet again
Baby steps, Maryland. Baby steps. In last year's meeting, the Terrapins trailed Temple by 21-0 after the first quarter. This year, the Terrapins and Owls are tied at 3-3 after 15 minutes. Progress! (Progress?)
Both teams opened 2012 with a win over an F.C.S. opponent, though each victory had a different feel. Maryland's 7-6 win over William & Mary was as ugly as it sounds; the Tribe could have won - should have, in fact - had a wide receiver not dropped a sure touchdown pass in the second half.
Temple, on the other hand, dismantled a fairly good Villanova team, 41-10. While some have the Owls pegged as the last-place team in the Big East (I'm not naming names), they should still be able to beat a team like Maryland. Decimated by attrition and injuries, Randy Edsall's squad has no identity, no leaders and no hope for a winning season.
What does Maryland have? A superb true freshman in Stefon Diggs, a five-star product who has already moved into a huge role at wide receiver. Through the first minute of the second quarter, Diggs has gained 12 yards on the ground to go with 2 receptions for 21 yards.
And look at that: Maryland just scored to make it a 10-3 game. Perry Hills, a freshman who stepped in at quarterback after C.J. Brown suffered a season-ending injury late in fall camp, found Matt Furstenburg for a six-yard touchdown. 
12:32 P.M. | Zach Schonbrun: Penn State strikes first
Penn State gets on the board with an 8-yard touchdown pass from Matt McGloin to the tight end Kyle Carter. That capped a 17-play, 75-yard opening drive, which also included two timeouts, one video replay, two 4th-down conversations and felt like it took years off my life. But anyway, good start for the Nittany Lions to strike first on the road. Showing no jitters.
12:26 P.M. | George O'Leary is not impressed by the Horseshoe
George O'Leary, speaking Thursday on his weekly radio show, on Ohio State's supposed home-field advantage: 
"I tell you what, it's like Michigan. It's not a loud stadium. I mean, they sit on their hands in that stadium. I've been there before, and you take Wisconsin, you take Iowa, you take U.C.F. is much louder than that stadium. It really is as far as the noise is concerned, because it is so far away from the field. But a lot of stadiums are a lot louder than that place. I didn't even bring in music this week, or any type of noise because I think we should be able to execute without it."
Ohio State averaged 105,231 fans per game last fall, the second-highest total in the country, trailing Michigan. And when was the last time O'Leary coached in the Horseshoe? That would be 1980, when he was a first-year defensive line coach at Syracuse. It's been a while.
The Buckeyes lead, 7-0, and just regained possession after forcing U.C.F. into a punt.
12:01 P.M. | Zach Schonbrun from Scott Field
Minutes away from kickoff at Scott Stadium in Charlottesville. A sellout crowd is expected tonight, and there are a lot of Penn State fans here, too. So far the crowd seems pretty docile. Some signs in the student section but nothing too tawdry. On a personnel note, Penn State's running back Bill Belton did not make the trip and Derek Day will start.
11:57 A.M. | Noon games we'll be following
Noon games we'll be following (and if you have any suggestions, please leave them below):
U.C.F. at Ohio State
Penn State at Virginia
Maryland at Temple
Miami (Fla.) at Kansas State
Auburn at Mississippi State
Storylines abound. George O'Leary thinks Ohio State fans "sit on their hands." Penn State looks to avoid an 0-2 start. Maryland is a train wreck. Miami came within an inch of knocking off Kansas State last September; one could make the case that the win propelled the Wildcats to a double-digit win season. While it won't match the 3-2 game in 2008, the Auburn-Mississippi State won't have close to the same amount of fireworks as last season's 41-34 Auburn win.
11:40 A.M. | Pregame reading; quarterback notes
A little pregame reading from Tim Rohan, Zach Schonbrun and Tom Spousta.
First, Tim with an enlightening profile of Vanderbilt's James Franklin:
"Undeterred, Franklin visited every fraternity and sorority three times, telling them to take pride in the team, their university. It became cool to go to games, and Rodgers is now hounded by his fellow students. Still, Rodgers said, 'Coach Franklin's the rock star on campus.'
Many students watched the YouTube videos Franklin posted of him surprising the team with a dodge ball tournament or with a bowling outing. The videos humanized the coach and his team. Recruits saw the videos and the success, and now they listened when Franklin visited their homes. He presented what he called a logical argument: why wouldn't they want to play right away in the SEC, receive a quality education and make history at Vanderbilt?"
Zach with a great piece on Kyle Flood, the former Rutgers offensive line coach who was named as Greg Schiano's successor over the winter:
Well before Rutgers named Flood its football coach in January, he was a math teacher at St. Francis Preparatory School in Queens. His nightly concern was stimulating 41 high school students through five algebra and trigonometry courses each weekday morning. He was a part-time offensive line coach at C. W. Post in the afternoons.
Tom, who will be in College Station for Texas A&M's debut against Florida, discusses the animosity between two new rivals:
"Little would suggest any animosity between Texas A&M and Florida. But fuel the pregame hype with a hurricane, a gift basket and a strategically placed billboard, and a heated rivalry might be born Saturday at Kyle Field."
Now, football news. Connor Shaw, who suffered an upper-body injury in South Carolina's season-opening win over Vanderbilt, will not start for the Gamecocks against East Carolina.
Instead, the Gamecocks will go with the sophomore Dylan Thompson - but don't be surprised if Shaw sees some time early, especially if U.S.C. struggles. Thompson is a work in progress.

PUB-DATE: September 8, 2012

SECTION: US; politics

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: After Jobs Report, Obama Tries to Change the Subject

BYLINE: HELENE COOPER and ASHLEY PARKER


HIGHLIGHT: President Obama began hammering away at the Republican ticket's plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength. 

 BODY:
SEMINOLE, Fla. - President Obama on Saturday began hammering away at the Republican ticket's plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida, with its large number of retired and elderly voters, to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength.
Kicking off a two-day bus tour through this perennial swing state, the president told a rally here that Mitt Romney's running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, had proposed overhauling Medicare and replacing it with a voucher system that could mean higher costs for beneficiaries.
"Florida, you should know I will never turn Medicare into a voucher system," Mr. Obama said to rousing cheers from a crowd of 11,000 at St. Petersburg College, Seminole. "No American should have to spend their golden years at the mercy of insurance companies."
The president's advisers have indicated that they are eager to re-engage their opponents on their Medicare plan, while the Romney camp would prefer to talk about the economy. A government report on Friday showed that employers had eased up on hiring in August, adding just 96,000 jobs, compared with 141,000 in July. The unemployment rate dropped to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent, but that was largely because of people leaving the work force entirely.
Mr. Romney has sought to blunt Mr. Obama's Medicare offensive with attacks of his own, something Obama advisers appeared to await eagerly.
"If they want to have a discussion about who do you trust on Medicare for the next 60 days as their central argument, you know we ought to send them an in-kind contribution," David Plouffe, Mr. Obama's senior adviser, told reporters aboard Air Force One on Friday. "We're happy to have that discussion. We think people trust the president more on Medicare."
The president grabbed that mantle on Saturday and ran with it. "We will reform and strengthen Medicare," he told the rally, "but we'll do it by reducing the costs of health care, not by dumping the costs on seniors."
For good measure, he threw in several more lines in his stump speech aimed at older people, who he said "are saving an average of $6,000 on prescription drugs because of Obamacare. And by the way, I do care." That was a reference to the derogatory phrase that Republicans have given his health care overhaul. These days, the president has embraced the label with open arms.
"I like the name 'Obamacare,' " he said. Mr. Romney "says he's going to repeal it. That's because Romney doesn't care."
With 58 days to go until Election Day, the battle for seven or so fiercely contested swing states has intensified. No state is more crucial than Florida, with its 29 electoral votes and its diverse mix of conservative Southerners, Hispanics, African-Americans and elderly and Jewish voters.
Mr. Obama does not appear to have much of a shot with conservative Southerners, but he is fighting mightily for the rest. That is why his weekend bus tour was straddling the center of the state, in the territory that hosted the Republican National Convention two weeks ago. Mr. Obama won Florida in 2008.
After Seminole, the president traveled up Interstate 4 toward Orlando, with a stop in Kissimmee. On Sunday, he was to head down to Melbourne and then West Palm Beach, ground zero for the Bush-Gore election recount of 2000.
Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, was focusing his efforts Saturday on Virginia, another state that Mr. Obama captured in 2008 and that he has made a priority in his re-election bid.
At his first stop, in Virginia Beach, Mr. Romney led the crowd in the Pledge of Allegiance, using it as a jumping-off point to criticize Mr. Obama and the Democrats for initially passing a convention platform that did not mention God.
"The promises that were made in that pledge are promises I plan on keeping if I am president, and I've kept them so far in my life," Mr. Romney told the cheering audience. "That pledge says 'under God.' I will not take 'God' out of the name of our platform. I will not take God off our coins, and I will not take God out of my heart."
The stop in Virginia Beach and an appearance at the start of the Sprint Cup Series Nascar race in Richmond, is intended to help him shore up his lead among white working-class voters.
Although the president trails Mr. Romney in this crucial demographic, some polls still show Mr. Romney underperforming among those voters. Mr. Romney's choice of Mr. Ryan as his running mate was also expected to help him win over working-class whites and the Republican conservative base, many of whom were wary of Mr. Romney during the primary contests.
For Mr. Romney, the son of a Detroit auto executive turned Michigan governor courting working-class voters may be a challenge. He is Harvard educated and has an estimated net worth of more than $200 million.
During a visit to the Daytona 500 this year, Mr. Romney ran into some trouble when he said that while he did not follow the sport as closely as some ardent fans did, he had "some great friends who are Nascar team owners." His opponents used the comment to portray him as wealthy and out of touch with the concerns of average voters.
Mr. Obama has made repeated campaign stops in Virginia, particularly courting black voters around the Richmond area to try to drive up their turnout. He has also focused on liberal-leaning areas of Northern Virginia.
Besides the on-the-ground campaigning this weekend, the Sunday morning talk shows were on the candidates' agendas. Mr. Romney was to make his first appearance of the campaign season on "Meet the Press" on NBC, and Mr. Obama and Mr. Ryan were scheduled to appear on "Face the Nation" on CBS.
.

PUB-DATE: September 8, 2012

LENGTH: 482 words

HEADLINE: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 9

BYLINE: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN


HIGHLIGHT: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, are to appear on NBC's "Meet the Press." Representative Paul D. Ryan will speak for the Republican ticket on CBS's "Face the Nation" and ABC's "This Week." 

 BODY:
With the conventions in the rearview mirror, the general election is off and running. The Romney campaign is wasting no time, branching out from the nominee's almost exclusive appearances on "Fox News Sunday" to date by scheduling Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, for an interview with NBC's "Meet the Press."

Glenn Hubbard, economic adviser to the Romney campaign and former chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers under President George W. Bush, and Austan Goolsbee, former chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers under Mr. Obama.

The Labor secretary, Hilda L. Solis, will discuss the latest jobs report on TV One's "Washington Watch."
And Bloomberg's "Political Capital" has J. Ann Selzer, president of Selzer & Company and pollster for Bloomberg, and Mark Blumenthal, founding editor of Pollster.com and senior polling editor at The Huffington Post.

HEADLINE: Taking the 'Cheap' Out of the Small Car

BYLINE: By LINDSAY BROOKE

 BODY:
THE idea that good things come in small packages has rarely played well with American car buyers. And who can blame them?
After all, a longstanding notion that bigger was always better, combined with gasoline at bargain prices compared with the rest of the world, led Detroit's executives and engineers to direct their best efforts toward more profitable cars in the midsize and large classes. In the process, they sentenced their small cars to a starvation diet.
''This goes back to the domestic philosophy of 'small cars equal small profit,' '' said Jim Hall, managing director of 2953 Analytics, an auto consulting firm. ''The philosophy was that you're going to be low-profit, so you want to convince people to buy something bigger.''
Even Henry Ford's early investors tried to persuade him to abandon his idea for the compact, efficient Model T and instead concentrate on big 6-cylinder touring cars because that's where the money was. Though Ford prospered with the Model T, his business plan later changed, and in the postwar years hulking, powerful American cars prevailed. 
There's no getting around the basic mechanics that make longer, wider, heavier cars feel comfortable on the road and their 6- and 8-cylinder engines inherently silky and quiet running.
''Generally, the lighter and shorter the car, and the shorter its wheelbase, the greater the challenge in your overall refinement options,'' said Jim Federico, General Motors' global chief engineer for small cars.
He noted that while a smaller car's lighter weight can benefit fuel economy, it may also reduce the pleasure of traveling in it.
''First, mass is actually your friend for reducing N.V.H.,'' he said, using the engineer's shorthand for noise, vibration and harshness. ''So our approaches to designing in refinement on a 3,100-pound Cruze and a 2,200-pound Spark will have many similarities and some differences.''
Even the profile and proportions of the bodies are factors: a long car typically manages airflow at the rear more smoothly, while a design that has been truncated abruptly at the rear generates turbulence at speed.
''The shorter the vehicle, the more difficulty engineers have in making aerodynamics work in favor of fuel economy, as well as interior noise,'' Mr. Federico said. ''Cars like the Spark create an expectation, because of their small size, that they have superhigh highway fuel economy. But in reality they have the aerodynamics of a brick.''
The refinements that helped turn big cars into Detroit's profit centers were mostly absent when fuel efficiency became a selling point in the 1970s and '80s and a wave of new small cars arrived in showrooms.
Remember the Ford Pinto and Escort? Datsun F10? Dodge Shadow? The Chevrolet Chevette and Citation? They may have been cheap to buy, but there was little joy in driving them. These and other buzzy underachievers -- often called penalty boxes and worse by owners -- set a low bar for the small-car genre in the United States.
The picture is much brighter today. Small cars have the benefit of years of development, and American buyers demand greater levels of polish. Consider how far removed a modern compact like the European-bred Ford Fiesta has advanced from efforts of four decades ago like the troubled Pinto.
Some credit for this trend belongs to the vehicles that came from Japan and Europe, where gasoline has long been expensive and multivehicle families are far less common. There, the reference standard for small cars is on another plane entirely.
Delightfully light-to-the-touch controls and 4-cylinder engines with electric-motor smoothness became hallmarks of cars like the Honda Civic, which elevated refinement in a mainstream small car to an art form.
Buyers in the United States and Europe generally have different expectations about vehicle refinement, particularly in regard to the powertrain. Because manual transmissions are far more prevalent in Europe, for example, drivers are more used to the sound, vibrations and comfort levels associated with shifting gears manually.
Today's small cars actually span three main segments in the global vehicle market. The tiny A-segment cars include the Chevy Spark and Smart Fortwo. They're extremely short and very light. Slightly larger are B-segment cars like the Ford Fiesta and Chevy Sonic. The A- and B-cars are known as subcompacts.
In the C-segment -- typically called compacts -- are the largest of the small cars. Examples include the Toyota Corolla, a perennial sales leader, as well as the Ford Focus, Chevy Cruze, Hyundai Elantra, Honda Civic and Volkswagen's Golf and Jetta.
Chevrolet's entries in all three segments highlight the small-car dimensional differences that can limit their relative refinement. The Spark is just 145 inches long, has a 93.5-inch wheelbase (the distance between axles) and weighs about 2,240 pounds. The B-segment Sonic is 18 inches longer than the Spark with a wheelbase nearly six inches longer; the Sonic is also almost 500 pounds heavier. The C-segment Cruze is yet another 18 inches longer than the Sonic, with a wheelbase more than six inches longer; the Cruze weighs almost 400 more pounds more than the Sonic.
Mike Merlo is chief engineer of the 2012 Dodge Dart, which is based on the well-regarded Alfa Romeo Giulietta platform developed by Chrysler's parent, Fiat.
Mr. Merlo's counterparts in Italy define ''vehicle refinement'' differently from the American engineers.
''To them, refinement means a 'European feel' of the car,'' he said. ''They spend a lot of time on seat comfort and its relation to the driving position, and maybe not as much time as we do on road isolation characteristics, because their roads are generally in much better condition than ours.''
European car owners also favor three-season tires that have exemplary ride and handling characteristics in spring, summer and fall. When winter comes, they install tires with specific winter grip and performance; Americans typically mount all-season tires for year-round use.
''So we had to calibrate the Dart's suspension and ride characteristics for the tire differences,'' Mr. Merlo said. ''The all-season tires led to trade-offs in the car's overall refinement.''
A suspension calibration can involve changing the rubber bushings at the connecting points between the suspension and the body. The bushings are rated according to their specific hardness; different bushings give firmer handling, a more compliant ride or a combination of both. Calibration can also involve the selection of alternate wheels and tires, and upgrading to sophisticated, and more expensive, suspension dampers.
Mr. Merlo noted two important lessons, shared by the members of his Chrysler team and their Fiat counterparts, that brought a higher level of refinement to the new Dart. One was a type of door construction commonly used in Europe that features advanced noise-sealing techniques.
The other was Chrysler's unusually high standards for the stiffness of the car's body -- the torsional bending measurement. Chrysler's requirement surprised the Fiat engineers, but the extra rigidity made it possible to build the larger Dart from the smaller foundation of the Alfa.
''These really helped us end up with a cabin that's very quiet,'' Mr. Merlo said. ''Because the body is stiff, it allows us a lot of flexibility to have both a softer-riding car when we want it to be soft and a firmer-riding car when we want it to have outstanding chassis dynamics.''
With United States small-car sales up 14 percent in the last decade, automakers are increasingly devoting major design and engineering resources to their development. Extensive computer analysis of body construction and materials, noise and vibration sources and driving dynamics is done in the early stages of vehicle design before any metal parts are made.
The goal is to identify the sources within the vehicle that cause unpleasant acoustics, sloppy control or poor driving dynamics -- and reduce or eliminate them, rather than devising expensive fixes aimed at masking them.
Engineers can select from a deep box of technologies aimed at vehicle refinement, including sound-damping materials behind the dash panel, under the floor and in the headliner; thick door seals and laminated acoustic glass.
But the state of the art in executing a great small car is in knowing how to make the vehicle refined in the right places -- making a steel bulkhead a fraction of a millimeter thicker, or using an adhesive to join two parts.
''The key is to thoroughly understand the vehicle's dynamics and N.V.H. sources up front,'' Mr. Federico said.
''To an increasing number of American buyers, small cars are no longer base cars,'' said Mr. Hall, whose early experience as a magazine journalist exposed him to many of the worst small cars of past years. ''They want the same things they have in their larger cars, just in a smaller size. They don't need the space, and they're a generation who are more open to small cars than their parents were.''
PHOTOS: LONG ROAD: Two small Fords, the '78 Pinto and a new Fiesta that comes to North America in 2013, are inches apart in size but miles apart in sophistication. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY FORD MOTOR) (AU1); HIS BABY: G.M.'s chief engineer for small cars, Jim Federico, with a '13 Spark. (PHOTOGRAPH BY GENERAL MOTORS); PHOTOS (AU2)
CHART: My, How We've Grown: The Changing Measure of the Small-Car Class: Cars classified as compact models and smaller have long been available in American showrooms, but low gas prices have kept them from the top of the sales charts. Last month, as has been the case for years, large pickups and midsize sedans were the best sellers. That may change, however, with the introduction of new models that include more big-car features, and with the advent of tougher fuel-economy standards. One small car that has consistently succeeded in the United States is the Honda Civic, serving through the years as a benchmark of refinement and dependability. Over four decades, the Civic has also grown considerably, gaining roughly two feet in wheelbase, three feet in overall length and 1,000 pounds in weight. No longer the smallest car Honda sells in America -- the Fit hatchback is more than a foot shorter -- it serves as a good case study in automotive evolution. HEADLINE: Very, Very High Season

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
AS you approach from the west, the Spaceport America main terminal looks like a gigantic moth, its rounded wings outspread against the arid, reddish-brown dirt of southern New Mexico. 
But it is the view from the east -- which reveals a curved, pitched glass facade, soaring steel hanger doors and a white-on-white ''2001''-style interior -- that truly encapsulates the future hopes of this complex, which officials call the first specifically designed to serve commercial space companies.
''The idea was to really bring economic development to New Mexico,'' said Christine Anderson, the executive director of the New Mexico Spaceport Authority. ''We think the commercial space industry is poised to take off. Literally.''
Built by the state at a cost of $209 million, Spaceport America was constructed with a tenant in mind -- Virgin Galactic -- which has signed a 20-year lease and is expected to start suborbital flights in the next year or so.
To say the site is remote doesn't do it justice. A power substation had to be installed, wells dug, water and sewer systems put in place. And while the spaceport will have a restaurant, at the moment the nearest place to grab a meal is more than 20 miles away.
But the Spaceport Authority hopes to make the place more inviting by the end of 2013 -- part of a mandate that the spaceport be self-supporting. Plans are afoot for an elaborate visitor center complete with interactive exhibits devoted to all manner of space-oriented activities.
Hopes are high; officials say they expect to draw as many as 200,000 visitors a year to see the spaceport.

SECTION: Section AU; Column 0; Automobiles; BEHIND THE WHEEL | 2013 CHEVROLET SPARK; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: Korean-Flavored Chevy Is Thrifty and City-Smart

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE ULRICH

 BODY:
AT the 2001 Detroit auto show, before he was pulled back into the family business like the movie mobster Michael Corleone, General Motors' godfather-for-hire, Robert A. Lutz, gravely assessed the design studies on display: ''A whole family of angry kitchen appliances, demented toasters, furious bread machines and vengeful trash compactors.''
Mr. Lutz, 80, is now retired from G.M., again. But I thought of him when I drove the new Chevrolet Spark: Mr. Lutz, your toast is served. With a nice coating of green marmalade.
Yes, the Spark looks as though it's about to spit a load of brioche from its roof. But as strange as this mini city car may appear, the oddest thing about the Spark is the Chevy bow tie that gleams from its grille and hatch. 
Mr. Lutz, long associated with steroidal specials like the Dodge Viper, once pronounced global warming a ''total crock.'' Yet the Berkeley-educated former Marine fighter pilot -- always a blend of contradictions -- was soon shepherding the Chevy Volt plug-in hybrid to production, saying the electrification of the automobile was inevitable.
This Spark is not battery-powered, not yet, though the model will lead G.M.'s electric car efforts with a low-volume, limited-market edition set to arrive next year. But the Spark's name, styling and park-anywhere size did lead one Manhattan onlooker to assume that a cache of batteries was on board.
Whether a gasoline version or electric, the Spark also suggests a road to Damascus experience for G.M. The company's obsession with paramilitary Hummers and other expressions of S.U.V. overkill nearly brought it to ruin when fuel prices ran up and buyers ran away.
Currently earning billions as the ''new'' G.M., the company is not out of the woods. But while this 1.2-liter 84-horsepower urban runabout is about the slowest thing on wheels -- and as much a niche car in America as any Hummer -- its very existence says something good about G.M. On all fronts, the company is at least trying to anticipate market trends, rather than propagate an action-movie fantasy worthy of Michael Bay.
That is not to say there isn't room for cinematic Camaros or modern S.U.V.'s. What it does mean is that the parochial Midwestern bubble that once surrounded G.M. -- and in which Chrysler and Ford happily floated as well -- seems to have popped for good.
The Spark also illuminates G.M.'s greater global focus, having been designed, engineered and built in Korea. The littlest Chevy, which replaces the larger Aveo, has been on sale internationally since 2009.
This demented toaster is barely larger than a breadbox, 14 inches shorter than Chevy's Sonic hatchback and roughly 2 inches shorter than a Mini Cooper. Although a Mini or a Fiat 500 is sexier, sportier and much more expensive than the Spark, neither has a back seat nearly as habitable.
The Spark is ultra-affordable, starting at $12,995, rising to $15,795 for the line-topping 2LT, and it never feels cheap or chintzy. That's especially true of the interior, which mimics style leaders like the Mini with swoopy shapes, body-color trim and an instrument pod that sprouts from the steering column.
My test car was laden with standard features that included stability control, 10 air bags, Bluetooth, cruise control, keyless entry and a leather-clad steering wheel with audio and phone buttons.
The styling follows a trend of cars like the Nissan Leaf E.V., which, deciding they can't be pretty, choose to be out-there instead. That defiantly frumpy approach can be charming, as Nissan has managed with its Juke crossover.
But I confess to feeling more silly than edgy at the wheel of this narrow, squashed-face carnival buggy, even as it showed me a responsible 42 m.p.g. on the highway and about 37 m.p.g. over all. The manual-shift Spark easily topped federal estimates of 32/38 m.p.g. in city and highway use.
The green paint didn't improve my self-esteem, either. Chevy calls it Jalapeño, but I'd never touch tongue to any chili with this irradiated shade.
But then the Spark isn't aimed at people like me, who thought '80s hatchbacks were small. Instead, Chevy seems convinced that millennials, the much-sought demographic segment ranging in age from about 16 to 31, are the Spark's natural audience. I picture more Gulf Coast retirees than Brooklyn hipsters in the Spark, but what do I know? I still think of Pabst Blue Ribbon as factory-town swill.
To that youthful end, the Spark's cabin is rich with connected technology that may well make its way to top luxury models rather than the usual trickle-down from posh to poor. Its Chevrolet MyLink system integrates all its functions -- phone, music, video and navigation -- through an iPhone or Android phone. There's not even a slot for CDs.
It's all managed, with reasonable smoothness, through a passive 7-inch display screen that doesn't require navigation or other systems to be embedded in the dashboard. Those systems can add thousands of dollars to the window sticker, and their maps and other features can quickly grow obsolete. In contrast, a phone-based system can be updated as easily as downloading a new app. SiriusXM satellite service, as well as apps for Pandora and Stitcher Smart radio, are installed at the factory.
There are pitfalls to current phone-based systems: they can eat up cellphone minutes, and smartphone antennas are not as good as a car's antenna. Spark's apps, including route guidance, won't work in a tiny town or barren wilderness with no cell service. The familiar ''Can you hear me now?'' will become ''I'm lost, can you find me now?''
The Spark could also use one or two more dedicated buttons on the dashboard or screen, including a simple map button to return to the main view and an easy-access volume control. But one thing is certain: the Spark's controls were more advanced and easier to operate than those of many cars that cost more.
If only the Spark drove as well as it dialed calls or summoned Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds from the bowels of, um, an iPhone.
The barely 2,200-pound microcar gets the job done on city or suburban streets for which it's intended. There's decent bump control and just enough urge to keep up with traffic, despite a 0-60 m.p.h. time well into the double digits.
My test car's 5-speed manual shifter, roughly the length of a croquet mallet, would have been at home in a school bus. A 4-speed automatic is available for $925, though some critics have found it douses the Spark's already tepid acceleration.
As speeds increase, the Spark's short wheelbase, underdamped suspension and meager power make for rougher going. Road imperfections crashed and boomed in the high-decibel cabin. Heaven help you if you get caught in the wrong gear on a highway on-ramp.
The car itself feels solid and well built. But with its flaccid suspension and lifeless, overboosted steering, the Spark charted a wobbly highway course; there's none of the fun and nimbleness you'd prefer in such a tiny car. Flogging the little green goblin, I managed to keep pace, barely, with BMWs on the Interstate. But the Spark is more at home in the slow lane.
Consider the Spark a city-centric econobox -- with a clever bonus box inside for iPhone or Android users.
INSIDE TRACK: A miniature multitasker.
PHOTOS: SLICKER: Designed for young city dwellers, the tiny Spark does well in tight spaces. Left, the body color wraps inside. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY GENERAL MOTORS)

HEADLINE: Joanna Wilson, Brett Green

 BODY:
Joanna Hayes Wilson and Brett Samuel Green were married Saturday evening at Memorial Church on the campus of Stanford University. The Rev. Susan Scott, an Evangelical Lutheran minister and an associate minister at the church, performed the ceremony. 
The bride, 28, and the groom, 30, met at Stanford, from which she received a master's in international policy studies and he a master's in financial mathematics as well as a doctorate in managerial economics.
Mrs. Green is a business consultant in the advisory unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers in San Francisco. She graduated summa cum laude from Washington University in St. Louis.
She is the daughter of Sandra J. Wilson and Robert D. Wilson of Coralville, Iowa. The bride's father retired as a State District Court judge in Des Moines. Her mother is a middle-school English teacher at North Central Junior High School in North Liberty, Iowa.
Mr. Green is an assistant finance professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. He graduated summa cum laude from Duke.
He is a son of Carol B. Green and Michael D. Green of Winston-Salem, N.C. The groom's father is a professor at the Wake Forest University School of Law in Winston-Salem.
The groom was the bride's teaching assistant in a managerial economics class at Stanford. They discovered that, decades earlier, his father had taught a class at the University of Iowa School of Law in which her father was a student.

SECTION: Section BU; Column 0; Money and Business/Financial Desk; LETTERS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 172 words

HEADLINE: The Problem With a No-New-Tax Pledge

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In '' 'Framing' Prevents Needed Stimulus'' (Economic View, Sept. 2) Robert J. Shiller argued that the persistent layoffs of public workers were a result of a framing problem -- the idea that superficial, irrelevant details can lead uninformed people to make the wrong choices, in this case about taxes. 
I disagree. Many Americans are willing to accept higher taxes in order to reduce deficits and prevent further government layoffs. The problem is that a promise not to raise taxes has virtually become a condition of being a Republican elected official. All but a handful of Republicans of Congress have made that pledge, despite the benefits that increased taxes could bring.
So even if the public is ready to make rational choices about their tax rates and government revenue, it wouldn't matter right now, because many of their elected officials have pledged that they will forever be irrational.
Albert J. Sumell
Youngstown, Ohio, Sept. 2
The writer is an associate professor of economics at Youngstown State University.

HEADLINE: Bulk of Charitable Giving Not Earmarked for the Poor

BYLINE: By GINIA BELLAFANTE

 BODY:
One weekend several years ago, as I was arriving at my neighborhood farmers' market, a college student approached me with a clipboard and an impassioned, if easily forgettable pitch for Greenpeace. If I signed the papers he had in his hand, a $20 charge would appear on my credit card statement each month and a small but vital fraction of the world's marine life could be saved. Confronted by an actual person and standing in the vicinity of cheese whose per-pound price was equal to the monthly cost of potentially saving a monk seal, I was too embarrassed to say, ''Thanks, but I'll pass,'' only then to move on to the artisanal cheddars of Pennsylvania. 
Need confronts us all the time, especially in New York, where density and dependence on mass transit place those on various sides of the economic divide into more routine contact than might occur in Houston or Denver or Seattle. Need, of course, has been escalating in recent years, and liberals fear that it would soar far more aggressively under a Republican leadership likely to make significant cuts to federal programs that benefit the poor. Could charitable inclination, further aroused by new tax breaks, really assume the burdens relinquished by government? Though it may be the case, as some would contend, that decentralized giving is the most efficient means of reaching the poor, the argument rests on the assumption that human beings give efficiently.
It is not entirely clear that they do. Americans give generously but they give polymorphously. Charitable contribution is motivated by compassion, affinity, history, fealty, social contest and, not infrequently, shame. The bulk of charitable donations in this country are made by individuals, and the passions of individuals do not typically align with the broader exigencies of a particular social moment. Nationally, 32 percent of the $298 billion given away last year went to religious institutions, 13 percent to cultural organizations and 12 percent to social services, according to a report issued annually by the American Association of Fundraising Counsel. But if giving were conducted with the greatest consideration paid to the most urgent needs of the society, then Yale, a private institution with a $19.2 billion endowment, would arguably never receive another 50 cents.
New Yorkers give lavishly. According to the Chronicle of Philanthropy, the metropolitan area ranks highest among cities in terms of dollar sum (though not in percentage of income) given to charity. The Upper East Side's 10021 ZIP code was responsible for $459 million in charitable donations in 2008, making it the country's most magnanimous in terms of money allocated.
And yet if we look at the Chronicle's ranking of individual donations of $1 million or more made in New York State so far this year, we see very little money going to causes aimed at enriching the lives of the less fortunate. Of the top five donations, totaling $190 million, one was made to Columbia University's business school, another to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Third on the list is Joshua P. Rechnitz's $40 million contribution to the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation, made specifically for the purpose of building an indoor cycling track. That figure represents about 25 times the amount raised by New Yorkers for Children, an organization focusing on young people in foster care and run by a former commissioner for the Administration of Children's Services, Nicholas Scoppetta, at its annual gala.
Looking at the top 49 gifts on the Chronicle's list, not one went to support social services explicitly.
Even when improving the lives of the suffering is at the forefront of charitable interest, giving in a way that maximizes the usefulness of what you give is not something ordinary civilians are reflexively equipped to do. It may be that $240 given annually to Greenpeace does wonderful, impactive work or it may be that the money would be of more vital use to an organization like the Food Bank for New York City -- to pick one of a hundred examples -- which has been forced to deliver 11 million fewer meals this year because of cuts in federal spending. The more charitable obligation we assume, the more we are put in the uncomfortable position of playing God.
And then there are the questions of metrics, numbers, statistics. ''If you spend 50 percent on fund-raising, you're considered a bad charity,'' Lorie A. Slutsky, chief executive of the New York Community Trust, a nearly-100-year-old organization that administers charitable giving for the wealthy, told me. But that measure of analysis is itself fluid, she explained, because new charities may not see yield on expensive direct-mail solicitation for years. Barring the reading of 990 tax forms, it is often difficult to determine what constitutes a successful charitable enterprise.
I asked Ms. Slutsky, who has taken donors to impoverished parts of the city in the hope of widening their charitable scope beyond the institutions favored on the Upper East Side, what she thought of the idea that charity could repair potentially bigger holes in the social safety net. ''I always say to people, name one of the richest people you can think of,'' she told me. ''Let's say Mike Bloomberg. Even if he gave away every penny he had -- $22 billion -- that would be a drop in the bucket. That's basically New York City's public school budget for one year.''
E-mail: bigcity@nytimes.com
