'DOUBT' Reeling from the recession, opera companies across America are playing it safe. But the Minnesota Opera -- which has, in Minneapolis and St. Paul, communities used to adventurous culture -- continues to program new work and thoughtful, theatrical productions of the classics. Next year brings this major commission composed by Douglas J. Cuomo, with a libretto by John Patrick Shanley, based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning play. The cast features the huge-voiced soprano Christine Brewer, in one of her too-rare operatic turns, as well as Denyce Graves, Matthew Worth and Adriana Zabala. Christopher Franklin conducts, and Kevin Newbury directs. Opens Jan. 26. Minnesota Opera, Ordway, St. Paul, (612) 333-6669, mnopera.org. (Z.W.)
'RIGOLETTO' This one might cause a ruckus. For his Metropolitan Opera debut, the director Michael Mayer (Broadway's ''Thoroughly Modern Millie'' and ''Spring Awakening'') places Verdi's great opera in Rat Pack-era Las Vegas, with a set by Christine Jones and the Duke cast as a sleazy Sinatra-type entertainer. Met audiences have tended to be doubtful about such updatings, but the previous production, from 1989, never inspired much affection, and if anyone can sell a difficult concept it is the excellent opening-night cast: the soprano Diana Damrau, the tenor Piotr Beczala and the baritone Zeljko Lucic. (Lisette Oropesa, Vittorio Grigolo and George Gagnidze take over later in the run.) Opens Jan. 28. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
MARC-ANDRÉ HAMELIN Everything this pianist plays, he plays well. And it's a good thing, since he plays almost everything. He began his career exploring the virtuosic fringes of the repertory and has gradually moved toward the center. His program here ranges from Bach to Mr. Hamelin's own Variations on a Theme by Paganini (in its New York premiere) and also includes works by Debussy, Rachmaninoff and Busoni. Jan. 30. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
WEST-EASTERN DIVAN ORCHESTRA Daniel Barenboim performing Beethoven at Carnegie is nothing new. But this time he brings his orchestra of young Israelis, Palestinians and Arabs to play all the symphonies. There is little in the sound of their recently released recordings of the works that would make you sense either youth or diversity. Seeing them in action should be a different matter, Jan. 30-31, Feb 2-3, Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
OPERA LAFAYETTE Sometimes this intrepid company's wanderings through the thickets of the French operatic repertory can yield great pleasures, and sometimes they remind you that there are reasons obscurities are obscure. Ah, but life's a crap shoot like that. Will ''Lalla Roukh,'' an Orientalist fantasia by Félicien David that wowed the Opéra Comique in 1862, hold up today as any more than a curiosity? We shall see. In any case, Ryan Brown's conducting is always spirited, and the production, by Bernard Deletré, incorporates the acclaimed Indian-dance troupe Kalanidhi Dance. Jan. 31. Rose Theater. (Z.W.)
FEBRUARY
OSVALDO GOLIJOV Mr. Golijov is Carnegie Hall's composer in residence this season, and a concert in its Making Music series, which offers commentary from composers as well as their music, could offer fascinating insights if the right questions are asked and answered. It is a chance to explore the methodology of a composer whose acquisitive methods have recently been called into question, to the point that some have accused him of plagiarism. The program, performed by the St. Lawrence String Quartet, the Zankel Band and others, includes the New York premiere of Mr. Golijov's ''Qohelet'' (more widely known under the spelling ''Koholet''), a Carnegie co-commission and one of the works that was challenged. Mr. Golijov altered it as a result. So what is the whole story? Feb. 4. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S It was a significant coup for this ensemble, excellent though it is, to secure the fast-rising Pablo Heras-Casado as its new principal conductor. He leads the orchestra for the first time at Carnegie Hall since his appointment in a program of the central repertory: Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture, Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 (with Christian Zacharias as soloist), Hans Zender's orchestrations of five Debussy preludes and the lighter, leaner 1841 version of Schumann's Fourth Symphony. All these are distant from the Baroque and new music in which Mr. Heras-Casado has long specialized. The orchestra has bet that his charisma and energy will outweigh his relative inexperience; it may be good for both him and the band that he will get to work with these fine players to refine his interpretations of the standards. Feb. 7. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
ROYAL CONCERTGEBOUW ORCHESTRA Mariss Jansons -- the principal conductor of both this ensemble and the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, and thus a regular commuter between Amsterdam and Munich -- turns 70 in January and seems to have emerged from several health crises of recent decades in fine fettle. Oh, he may still suffer from jet lag, but he certainly doesn't seem fazed. He takes the Bavarians to Tokyo to perform all the Beethoven symphonies in late November. Here he presents good variety in programs well gauged to show off this great orchestra's and Mr. Jansons's own versatility: in one, Bartok's Second Violin Concerto, with Leonidas Kavakos as soloist, and Mahler's First Symphony; in the other, Strauss's ''Death and Transfiguration'' (Mr. Jansons may feel that he has lived it) and Bruckner's Seventh Symphony. Feb. 13-14. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'PARSIFAL' Appearing a bit earlier than its traditional place around the Easter season, Wagner's final and perhaps deepest music drama arrives in New York in a new production by François Girard after a practice run at the Lyon Opera, where its scenic requirements -- a stage-filling sea of blood, for one thing -- strained the company's technical capabilities to the breaking point. Presumably those challenges will be a walk in the park for a Met recently tested by the mechanical headaches of Robert Lepage's Wagner ''Ring'' cycle. And blood aside, the house is fielding a remarkably strong cast: Jonas Kaufmann, seemingly born for the title role, as well as Katarina Dalayman, Peter Mattei, René Pape and Evgeny Nikitin, making his first New York appearance since his withdrawal from the Bayreuth Festival after the bizarre discovery that one of his tattoos resembled, at one point, a swastika. Daniele Gatti's deliberate, expansive take on the opera has polarized audiences in the past, but a little more time spent with singers of this quality wouldn't be too bad a fate. Opens Feb. 15. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'POWDER HER FACE' It's a sign of the composer Thomas Adès's rise to the top of his field that both his operas are being performed in New York this season. The Met's production of his sweeping version of ''The Tempest,'' opening in October, will doubtless grab more attention, but the chamber work ''Powder Her Face,'' about a 1960s sex scandal involving the Duchess of Argyll, has raunchily intimate charm. It's an opera that in content and scale wouldn't make much sense at the Met, so it's an ideal opening act for a New York City Opera, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for two of its four productions, that is trying to define itself artistically after a listless last season. Jay Scheib directs; Jonathan Stockhammer, a specialist in contemporary opera, conducts. Opens Feb. 15. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
'DON CARLO' When Lorin Maazel returned to the Met podium for a run of Wagner's ''Walküre'' in 2008 it was the first time he had conducted at the company since the early 1960s. It's a far smaller gap this time, as he leads Verdi's dark masterpiece and an experienced cast that includes Barbara Frittoli, Anna Smirnova, Ramón Vargas, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, Eric Halfvarson and Ferruccio Furlanetto, who scored a personal coup as Philip II when Nicholas Hytner's production was new in 2010. Opens Feb. 22. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'RADAMISTO' Harry Bicket has that rarest and best of gifts for an early-music specialist: the ability to make regular opera orchestras play with the snap of a period-instrument band. But there is still something special that happens when he leads his own English Concert, which will be joined for one of Handel's lesser-known masterworks by a fine cast that includes the veteran countertenor David Daniels, Brenda Rae, Patricia Bardon, Joélle Harvey and Luca Pisaroni. It is the first in a series of concert performances of Baroque operas at the hall by Mr. Bicket and the ensemble in coming seasons, so there's much to look forward to. Feb. 24. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
'THE TURN OF THE SCREW' The New York City Opera finally has the right idea. This beleaguered company has learned that it's a losing battle to go head to head with the Met in terms of repertory and production style, and smarter to compete with the city's smaller, more nimble companies. To that end, it is opening its season with two intimate-scale operas that would have been naturals from, say, Gotham Chamber Opera: Thomas Adès's ''Powder Her Face'' and this intensely creepy work by Britten, both performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The conductor is the versatile Jayce Ogren; the director is Sam Buntrock, whose Broadway production of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' used lighting and projections with fluid ease. The cast had not been announced at press time. Opens Feb. 24. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
MARCH
VIENNA PHILHARMONIC Happiness is conducting two of the world's greatest orchestras at Carnegie Hall in one season. Franz Welser-Möst, having dropped in with his own Cleveland Orchestra in November, now leads an orchestra that -- though proudly independent -- is his in another sense, he being Austrian. The three programs include symphonies by Dvorak (No. 7), Schubert (No. 6) and Bruckner (No. 4); songs by Richard Strauss, sung by the tenor Herbert Lippert; Berg's Violin Concerto, played by Frank Peter Zimmermann; and a work by the contemporary German Jörg Widmann. March 1-3. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
JENNIFER KOH You may see Ms. Koh early in the season, since she is enacting the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing title character of Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's ''Einstein on the Beach'' in some performances (Sept. 14-16) of the Brooklyn Academy production. Here, in the second installment of her three-part multiyear series Bach and Beyond, she occupies the stage alone and presumably without fright wig, playing solo violin works by Bartok and Phil Kline, in addition to Bach. (A recording of the first part is to be released in October by Cedille Records.) March 2. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI' The Met reserves runs of Riccardo Zandonai's infectiously dramatic verismo rarity for divas it really believes in. It was last mounted in the 1980s for Renata Scotto, and this new revival is a major endorsement of the soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek, a favorite in London whose New York career is just getting started. (She also joins the Met Orchestra for Wagner's ''Wesendonck Lieder'' at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 14.) Her co-star, the tenor Marcello Giordani, is ardent but inconsistent, two adjectives that also apply to the conductor, Marco Armiliato. But when Ms. Westbroek is in her groove, she is as thrilling as large stretches of Zandonai's score. Opens March 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
THE BACH VARIATIONS The early-music specialist Masaaki Suzuki and his Bach Collegium Japan and Yale Schola Cantorum join the New York Philharmonic in opening its monthlong festival. The program is built on a lovely idea, juxtaposing works by Bach with near counterparts by his great revivalist, Mendelssohn. (From each comes a Magnificat in D.) March 6-9. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'LA PASIÓN SEGÚN SAN MARCOS' As a sort of belated appendage to its festival Voices From Latin America, Carnegie Hall devotes its choral institute this season to Osvaldo Golijov's magnum opus. In the culminating performance, Robert Spano conducts the Orquesta la Pasión, members of the Schola Cantorum de Venezuela and choruses from area high schools. March 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
LONDON PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, having presented the London Symphony and the Philharmonia Orchestra in the fall, completes its minifestival of major London orchestras. Vladimir Jurowski, the orchestra's principal conductor, presents two programs: first Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. 1, with Vadim Repin as soloist, and Beethoven's Symphony No. 5; then Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4, with Hélène Grimaud as soloist, and Mahler's Symphony No. 5. March 10-11. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
MASS IN B MINOR Happily, major American orchestras have been rediscovering Bach and the Baroque, having largely conceded that repertory to early-music specialists for several decades. The New York Philharmonic had a leg up with Kurt Masur as its music director through the 1990s. Coming from a long tenure in Leipzig, Germany, where Bach spent his last 27 years, Mr. Masur brought Bach's major choral works to the orchestra with some regularity and in 1998 even imported the choir of St. Thomas Church in Leipzig, which Bach had directed, for a ''St. Matthew Passion.'' It is good to see Alan Gilbert pick up the mantle here as part of a major Philharmonic series, the Bach Variations, with the New York Choral Artists and stellar vocal soloists: Dorothea Röschmann, Anne Sofie von Otter, Steve Davislim and Eric Owens. March 13-16. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE' This season Renée Fleming has a coveted Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, for which she has programmed two recitals, including a battle of the divas alongside the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, and a concert with the New York Philharmonic. But the centerpiece is a semistaged concert performance of this gauzily lyrical André Previn opera, with Blanche DuBois created as a vehicle for Ms. Fleming, first performed in 1998. The work hasn't been heard much since, though it is being revived on March 26 at Lyric Opera of Chicago, where Ms. Fleming is the creative consultant. The Carnegie performance, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's under Patrick Summers, is a test run of sorts for that Chicago stand, featuring the same excellent supporting cast: Susanna Phillips, Teddy Tahu Rhodes and Anthony Dean Griffey. March 14. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY After this gloriously adventurous ensemble's American Mavericks festival last year at Carnegie Hall, which featured work from some of the out-there corners of the repertory, it will be a fascinating shift to hear it in the standards, in which the orchestra and its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, also shine. The first night's program pairs Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4 (with the brilliant Yuja Wang as soloist) and Brahms's First Symphony with the New York premiere of a work by Samuel Carl Adams, and the second concert features the Ninth Symphony of Mahler, a Thomas favorite. March 20-21. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
CARTER BREY New York Philharmonic audiences have been blessed, hearing Mr. Brey regularly since he became the orchestra's principal cellist in 1996. But the pleasure has been mixed, because he had to cut back sharply on his solo career to do it. In a substantial bit of payback, the Philharmonic puts Mr. Brey forward to perform Bach's six unaccompanied cello suites as part of its Bach Variations festival. Expect him to shine. March 27. Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th Street and Central Park West, (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org. (J.R.O.)
LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC At its premiere in Los Angeles in May, John Adams's oratorio ''The Gospel According to the Other Mary'' badly lagged dramatically, but many moments of its protean, searching score showed a mature composer at the height of his powers. The Philharmonic and its music director, Gustavo Dudamel, bring the work to New York with the same excellent soloists -- Tamara Mumford, Kelley O'Connor and Russell Thomas -- and a new element: a staging by the theater artist Peter Sellars, who collaborated with Mr. Adams on the libretto. The next evening's concert features Claude Vivier's ''Zipangu,'' for strings, ''La Mer'' by Debussy and Stravinsky's ''Firebird,'' the kind of vividly dramatic work at which Mr. Dudamel excels. March 27-28. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
'ST. MATTHEW PASSION' Ivan Fischer's conducting appearances in New York invariably yield fine performances, but in recent years they have also become genuine events. In 2010 Mr. Fischer presented all the Beethoven symphonies, half on period instruments, half on modern; in 2011 he offered Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' in his own staging; and in April he led Mozart's Requiem with choristers intermingled among the orchestra to give the players a better feel for the text. Bach's great Passion is to be sure an event in itself, and no unusual twists have been announced -- yet. Mr. Fischer conducts Musica Sacra and the Orchestra of St. Luke's, with soloists including Dominique Labelle, John Tessier and Hanno Müller-Brachmann. March 28. Carnegie Hall. (In other notable performances of the ''St. Matthew Passion,'' John Scott conducts the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and Concert Royal at St. Thomas Church on March 22, and Julian Wachner conducts the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at Trinity Church on March 24.) (J.R.O.)
APRIL
BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA In all the rampant speculation about who might succeed James Levine as the orchestra's music director, the name Daniele Gatti seems to have receded. Mr. Gatti is a gifted and experienced maestro in midcareer and seems not to be overcommitted by the standards of conductors today, despite major posts at the Orchestre National de France and the Zurich Opera. In this series, after a mixed program conducted by Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, a veteran who has given the orchestra yeoman service during its transition, the second and third programs are conducted by Mr. Gatti. Though there is no reason to expect anything but excellent performances, it will be hard not to wonder what Mr. Levine might have done with Mahler's Third Symphony, one of his great specialties, this time around in the second program, or what he might have made of the third, all Wagner. Certainly, on each of these terrains, Mr. Gatti will be held to the highest standard, by orchestra and public alike. April 3-5. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'GIULIO CESARE' It's tough being the final new Met production of the year. With everyone exhausted and attention flagging, you tend, like Rodney Dangerfield, to get no respect. It doesn't help that David McVicar's version of this Handel masterpiece, which puts a colorful colonial-era, Neo-Classical spin on the ancient Egyptian setting, has already been captured on DVD. But the Met's cast -- David Daniels in the title role, Natalie Dessay as Cleopatra and the excellent Alice Coote as Sesto -- is of interest, and the conductor, Harry Bicket, is a pro at this repertory. The Met orchestra plays its heart out for him. Opens April 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'GESUALDO REFLECTIONS' The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is best known for the classics; its concerts are the place to go when you want a Beethoven quartet played with dependable polish. But the society also has a relatively unheralded, consistently creative and excellent new-music series in Lincoln Center's intimate Kaplan Penthouse. The highlight, though it doesn't take place at the penthouse, is a celebration of the 400th anniversary of the birth of the brilliant and murderous composer Carlo Gesualdo featuring the Antioch Chamber Ensemble, the pianist Soyeon Kate Lee and the Brentano String Quartet. In keeping with Gesualdo's experimental music, centuries ahead of its time, the program juxtaposes his work with 21st-century responses -- by Bruce Adolphe, Brett Dean, David Gompper and Wolfgang Rihm -- for various chamber forces. April 4. Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org. (Z.W.)
'DER RING DES NIBELUNGEN' There will be a degree of deja vu as the Met brings back Robert Lepage's version of Wagner's epic masterpiece for the first time as a piece of the repertory, after the rollout of the full cycle last season. For the three cycles Deborah Voigt and Katarina Dalayman still alternate as Brünnhilde; Jay Hunter Morris's bright-voiced Siegfried still gets his turn, as does Hans-Peter König's memorably rich Hagen; and the enormous planks of Mr. Lepage's machine still rotate impassively. The question will be whether and how the spectacle suffers without the intensity provided by some of last season's stars: Bryn Terfel, Jonas Kaufmann, Eva-Maria Westbroek and Waltraud Meier. Fabio Luisi conducts. Cycles open on April 6 and 25 and May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'MOSÈ IN EGITTO' Rossini's serious operas still don't receive the productions they deserve; they are long and not easy to cast. But they have irresistible grandeur. The Opera Orchestra of New York did Rossini's French adaptation of ''Mosè in Egitto'' in concert last year, and it sailed along with the muscular grace of an ocean liner. Now the New York City Opera offers a super-rare staging of the Italian original at City Center, the company's original home. The production is directed by Michael Counts, the visually eclectic creator of City Opera's ''Monodramas'' evening; we'll see how he handles the climactic parting of the Red Sea. (Projections, credited to Ada Whitney/Beehive, will presumably play a role.) Jayce Ogren, City Opera's man for all seasons, conducts. Opens April 14. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
DRESDEN STAATSKAPELLE It will be fascinating to catch up with this orchestra and itsprincipal conductor, Christian Thielemann, in view of the jockeying for power going on at European festivals. After Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic announced that they would leave the Salzburg Easter Festival next spring in favor of an event in Baden-Baden, Germany, Mr. Thielemann and the Staatskapelle were quick to move in. The Berlin Philharmonic sounded in splendid shape at Carnegie in February, and this season, just weeks after that Salzburg appearance, it is the Staatskapelle's turn in programs of Brahms (''Academic Festival Overture''; Violin Concerto, with Lisa Batiashvili as soloist; Symphony No. 4) and Bruckner (Symphony No. 8). April 17, 19. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'TRISTAN UND ISOLDE' The acclaimed Swedish dramatic soprano Nina Stemme, who set Carnegie Hall ablaze as Strauss's Salome with Franz Welser-Möst and the Cleveland Orchestra in May, has said that her way in life is ''to hurry slowly.'' She has held back in establishing a career in the United States, and she will take up Wagner's Isolde at the Met only in the 2016-17 season. American Wagnerites will undoubtedly flock to Houston to hear her do it sooner. Ben Heppner is scheduled to sing Tristan, but you may recall that he gave the Met fits in the role in 2008, claiming illness and showing up for only the last of six planned performances. Christof Loy directs, and Patrick Summers conducts. If it all comes together, it should be worth the trip. Opens April 18. Houston Grand Opera, Wortham Center, (713) 228-6737, houstongrandopera.org. (J.R.O.)
'LA PÉRICHOLE' Christopher Alden's dreamlike production of Mozart's ''Così Fan Tutte'' was the bright spot in the New York City Opera's uninspired last season, the latest in a series of memorable shows the director has made for the company in recent years. He now turns his attention to a seemingly unlikely work: this farcical operetta by Offenbach about a Peruvian street singer who triangulates between her true love and a Spanish official. (Another frothy opera, Johann Strauss's ''Fledermaus,'' is also on Mr. Alden's agenda this year, with a production opening in October at the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto.) Mr. Alden has a gift for bringing out the darkness and sophistication in the unlikeliest of places and pieces. Opens April 21. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
'WAR REQUIEM' Of the many commemorations of Benjamin Britten's centennial here in 2013, this performance of a consummate masterpiece, a pacifist statement mingling the text of the Requiem Mass with poetry of Wilfred Owen, will undoubtedly be one of the more imposing, with Kent Tritle conducting the 200-voice Oratorio Society of New York, itself celebrating its 140th anniversary. The vocal soloists are the excellent Emalie Savoy, soprano; John Matthew Myers, tenor; and Jesse Blumberg, baritone. April 22. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
SWEDISH CHAMBER ORCHESTRA New York admirers of the Swedish soprano Nina Stemme who cannot catch that ''Tristan und Isolde'' in Houston must content themselves with this catchall concert, in which she will perform songs of Berlioz, Brahms, Wagner, Grieg, Sibelius, Strauss and Weill. In addition, Thomas Dausgaard conducts the fine ensemble in works or parts of works by Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Elgar, Sibelius and Ravel. April 25. Alice Tully Hall. (J.R.O.)
STRAVINSKY SACRED WORKS Julian Wachner continues his emphasis on more or less contemporary fare this season with the Trinity Choir and Novus NY devoting a weekend to the complete sacred works by a restless master. Stravinsky essentially announced modernism in music with his ''Rite of Spring'' in 1913, then looked back over his shoulder with a Neo-Classicism largely of his own invention and finally found his way to the spare, serialist aesthetic that dominates in many of the works here. Rightly, the majestic ''Symphony of Psalms'' crowns the affair. April 26-27 at Trinity Church. April 28 at St. Paul's Chapel. (J.R.O.)
YALE IN NEW YORK This four-concert series concludes with a commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the death of Paul Hindemith, ''Prankster and Master'': a Yale professor for the 13 years before his death and an astonishingly prolific composer and champion of useful music (Gebrauchsmusik) most of whose works have largely fallen into disuse. The current faculty members Boris Berman, pianist, and Ettore Causa, violist, and members of the Yale Philharmonia perform works of Hindemith including the sure-to-be-immortal ''Overture to 'The Flying Dutchman' as Played at Sight by a Second-Rate Concert Orchestra at the Village Well at 7 O'Clock in the Morning,'' for string quartet. April 28. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
MAY
'DIALOGUES DES CARMÉLITES' Some critics, including Anthony Tommasini in The New York Times, have called for the Met to appoint a director of productions, who would work with the general manager, Peter Gelb, and the music director, whoever that may be, to plot the company's theatrical direction. (S0 far Mr. Gelb has resisted the idea.) The last time something like that happened was when John Dexter filled the position in the late 1970s and early '80s. Audiences are periodically reminded of that brief golden age for theater at the Met when Dexter's productions are revived; though more than 30 years old, their elegance and intelligence shine through, as in his spectacular yet subtle take on Britten's ''Billy Budd,'' performed last season. One of Dexter's finest shows was his ''Dialogues des Carmélites,'' as unadorned and inspired as Poulenc's score. This revival has a fine cast, including Isabel Leonard, Patricia Racette, Erin Morley, Elizabeth Bishop and Paul Appleby, conducted by Louis Langrée. Opens May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
EARLY MUSIC NEW YORK The fascinating program ''London's Musical Bridge: The Enlightened English'' pairs works by 18th-century native English composers with counterparts by Germans who had settled in London: thus, suites by John Avison and Handel, overtures by William Boyce and Johann Christian Bach, and sinfonias by Thomas Arne and Frederick William Herschel. Herschel, in his day job as astronomer, discovered the planet Uranus: enlightened indeed. May 4. First Church of Christ, Scientist, Central Park West at 68th Street, (212) 280-0330. earlymusicny.org. (J.R.O.)
SPRING FOR MUSIC This annual festival of North American orchestras, conceived by top music professionals to encourage and reward adventurous programming, has in its first two seasons effectively filled what it has shown to be a valuable niche: giving Carnegie Hall-exposure to ensembles showing initiative, several of which might otherwise never have found their way there. Carlos Kalmar and the Oregon Symphony -- who made the biggest splash in 2011 with a program they have since recorded for the Pentatone label, ''Music for a Time of War'' -- present a wide-ranging collection of works by Schubert, Ravel, Schoenberg, Kurt Weill and the Thai composer Narong Prangcharoen (May 9). Also returning to the festival, which mandates a year off between appearances, are David Alan Miller and the Albany Symphony Orchestra, who presented a program centered on spirituals in 2011 and now play another American program, with works by Gershwin, Morton Gould and John Harbison (May 7). In addition, Marin Alsop conducts the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra; JoAnn Falletta, the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra; Leonard Slatkin, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra; and Christoph Eschenbach, the National Symphony Orchestra. May 6-11. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
DETROIT SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA To single out the oddest of the Spring for Music programs: Leonard Slatkin conducts Ives's Symphonies Nos. 1 through 4, a notion utterly logical on its surface yet, given the ear-twisting complexities in much of the music, utterly bizarre. Not even counting however many intermissions and stage changes, the program runs well over two hours. But will Mr. Slatkin be able to resist adding an encore: say, Ives's attempt at a monster sequel, the ''Universe Symphony,'' which the Nashville Symphony performed in the completion by Larry Austin at Spring for Music this year? May 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
TOKYO STRING QUARTET Though the personnel has shifted in recent years, it was still quite a brand, established over 43 years of excellent performance (and kudos to Kazuhide Isomura, the violist, who saw it all). Now the quartet has decided to quit while still near the top. It has picked excellent collaborative works to go out with, both in this concert (Schubert's resolutely sunny String Quintet, with the cellist Lynn Harrell) and in its penultimate recording (Brahms's late, mellow Clarinet Quintet, with the clarinetist Jon Manasse), to be released by Harmonia Mundi in November. But the quartet takes final leave on its own, both here on stage, with works by Haydn and Bartok (the Sixth Quartet, his last), and on disc, with works of Dvorak and Smetana, scheduled for release in 2013. May 11. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO' Looking around and noting the decided paucity of quality opera in its city, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, never an ensemble to rest on its laurels, is improbably turning itself into a de facto opera company. It is focusing on new and recent works but also unveiling a series of staged performances of Mozart and Lorenzo Da Ponte's three classic operas, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel and featuring sets and costumes by noted architects and fashion designers. Last year ''Don Giovanni'' was promising, but the logistics, with the orchestra far above and behind the singers, were a work in progress. For this year's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' the setup will be adjusted for a production designed by Jean Nouvel and Azzedine Alaïa and starring Christopher Maltmann and Dorothea Röschmann. May 17, 19, 23, 25. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com. (Z.W.)
'GILBERT'S PLAYLIST' If four programs in May and June are being put forward as Alan Gilbert's playlist, you have to wonder what that implies about the rest of his season with the New York Philharmonic. Rote? Required? But questions about the marketing strategy don't detract from the quality and creativity of the work he is offering under that unfortunate title. First come jazz-inflected works by Stravinsky, Shostakovich, Copland and Wynton Marsalis, played alongside the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, then Dallapiccola's stark one-act opera ''Il Prigioniero'' (featuring Gerald Finley and Patricia Racette), sharing a bill with Lisa Batiashvili in Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1. Mr. Gilbert offers his new arrangement of Wagner, ''A Ring Journey,'' with Christopher Rouse's ''Seeing,'' featuring the pianist Emanuel Ax. Finally, to close the season, Doug Fitch, who has collaborated with Mr. Gilbert and the orchestra in recent seasons, directs and designs an evening of Stravinsky ballets (''The Fairy's Kiss'' and ''Petrouchka'') with Karole Armitage creating choreography for the New York City Ballet dancer Sara Mearns. May 31-June 29. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
JUNE
STOKOWSKI CELEBRATION Now the gloves are off. Mr. Nézet-Séguin, for all practical purposes, embodies Stokowski, as the Philadelphia Orchestra returns to its treasured but acoustically flawed old home, the Academy of Music. In three days of intensive programming, he conducts Brahms's First Symphony and Dvorak's Ninth, Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Scheherazade'' and works by Ippolitov-Ivanov and Wagner, an audience-choice program and repertory from the animated Disney film ''Fantasia.'' But in the film, Stokowski got to shake hands with Mickey Mouse. How do you replicate that, Mr. Nézet-Séguin? June 21-23. Academy of Music, Philadelphia, (215) 893-1999, philorch.org. (J.R.O.)

HEADLINE: The Launching Pad

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE ROSENBLUM

 BODY:
FOR countless newly minted college graduates, it's a rite of passage. After the mortarboards have been tossed into the air, they head for New York City, ready to embark on the next chapter of their lives. In 2010, some 40,000 graduates age 22 to 28 moved to the city in search of jobs, according to the latest figures from the Census Bureau's American Community Survey.
But whatever the next step, they first need a place to live. As rents continue to soar -- in August, the average monthly rent for a Manhattan apartment was $3,536 -- and the job market sputters, the task can be daunting, especially for those on the lower rungs of the economic ladder. Even people who have heard horror stories about how hard it can be to find a first apartment in New York aren't prepared for the challenges. 
For an up-close look at what the search is like, several dozen new graduates were interviewed and four were followed as they set out to find a home. They represented renters looking in three price ranges from $1,000 to $2,000 a month.
Isaac Hancock, a Connecticut College graduate who is teaching at Success Academy Bed-Stuy in Brooklyn through Teach for America, wanted an apartment where he and four roommates would each pay about $1,000 in rent. With the help of Teacher Space NY, an agency that caters to teachers on tight house-hunting schedules and equally tight budgets, the group found a five-bedroom on the Upper East Side that is near the subway and is flooded with natural light.
Riley Hall and Averi Ahsmann, who graduated with combined bachelor and master's degrees from St. Bonaventure University, about an hour's drive from Buffalo, N.Y., wanted to pay a rent of $1,250 each. Ms. Hall, who is studying for her certified public accountants' exam, and Ms. Ahsmann, who works as a marketing assistant, found a two-bedroom apartment with a large living area near Gramercy Park, with the help of Morgan Turkewitz of Citi Habitats.
Charles McConnell, a recent graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, Conn., who plans to travel and play professional tennis while looking for a job in politics, wanted an apartment where he and two fraternity brothers could each pay about $2,000 in rent.
With the help of the Next Step Realty, a national real estate company that specializes in finding apartments for new college graduates, they found a three-bedroom in Murray Hill, complete with exposed brick, working fireplaces and a skylight. A coin laundry, a pizza place, a grocery store, A.T.M.'s and other services are within a block.
To give a sense of what it's like for new graduates to find a first apartment in New York, these four people were asked to keep track of the ups and downs of their search from the moment they began looking for a place to the day they signed the lease. (By coincidence, all four wound up in Manhattan, despite the fact that Brooklyn, and increasingly, parts of Queens, attract great numbers of young renters.) In all cases, the search proved more challenging than anticipated, but all four were happy with the place where they ended up.
These new graduates didn't get exactly what they were looking for when they started out, especially when it came to price. But now that they are settled into their new places and are preparing to embark on their new lives in the city, they can look back and impart a little wisdom to those who will come after them.

HEADLINE: Doubts as Portland Weighs Fluoride and Its Civic Values

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
PORTLAND, Ore. -- Who bears responsibility for an impoverished child with a mouth full of rotting teeth? Parents? Soda companies? The ingrained inequities of capitalism? Pick your villain, or champion. They are all on display here as the largest city in the nation with no commitment to fluoridating its water supply -- and one of the most politically liberal cultures anywhere -- has waded into a new debate about whether to change its ways and its water.
The debate flared on Thursday at a public hearing before the five-member City Council, whose vote on the issue is scheduled for this week. Some of the arguments have focused on health concerns, with opponents raising questions and citing studies about fluoride's effects on brain development and I.Q.
Others said that times had changed since in the 1950s, when fluoridation first took off in the United States. People now get plenty of fluoride, critics say, in products from toothpaste to food that has been processed, grown or cleaned elsewhere. About three-fourths of the country's population lives in areas where fluoride is added to the water. 
''If there's a problem with kids' dental health, why don't we put the money toward better nutrition?'' said Angel Lambart, who testified on Thursday with her young daughter on her lap.
But befitting a city where socially conscious, environmentally fervent goals have become a kind of local brand, the more ferocious questions for both sides centered on personal choice and societal burden. Once consigned to the ranks of the gritty and damp, along with Seattle and other Pacific Northwest shipping towns, Portland has been reinvented by waves of highly educated newcomers working at places like Intel, a huge regional employer.
But beyond the bike-friendly, walk-friendly downtown of rose gardens and coffee bars, a kind of parallel Portland of perpetual poverty, concentrated in minority groups and often invisible to visitors, has festered.
Dental decay rates, numerous state and federal studies say, are linked to income, education and access to health insurance, but also to lifestyle, diet and parental choices in insisting on a toothbrush. Such conclusions give fuel to both sides, with supporters of fluoride seeing a social problem to be solved by government, while opponents focus on unhealthy habits and diets that they say will not be affected by chemicals.
Mayor Sam Adams, who backs the fluoridation plan and has one of five votes on the Council, comes firmly down on the side that says Portland must address dental care for everyone if its progressive goals and self-image are valid.
''It's about health equity, it's about social justice,'' he said in an interview. ''Fluoride is means to an end,'' he added. ''I hope that folks, whether they agree with me or not, understand that my intentions are to help those Portlanders that have no voice in this process.''
Some opponents of fluoridation have lobbed that kind of reasoning right back into the laps of the commissioners. ''I don't appreciate you trying to alleviate your white guilt by putting toxins in our water,'' Frances Quaempts-Miller, who described herself as mixed black and Muscogee Indian, said in testifying at the public hearing before the all-white Council of four men and one woman.
Who is empowered to make the choice for Portland has become part of the debate as well. Fluoridation efforts have failed at the ballot box here, most recently in 1980. And two other members of the City Council, in addition to Mr. Adams, who is not seeking re-election in November, said even before public testimony was taken that they planned to vote for the plan -- making a majority -- when it goes before them. Some opponents call that an undemocratic end-run around the popular will.
But one of the commissioners, Nick Fish, in a defense of his pro-fluoride position at Thursday's hearing, said that what some call closed-door deal-making, he calls leadership. ''I think we were elected to make the tough calls,'' said Mr. Fish, the public works commissioner. He said that gridlock in Congress was an example to be avoided. ''In this community we have a chance to do something different,'' he said.
Some critics say Portland's sense of civic duty is misplaced when it comes to bad teeth, which they say is a much greater problem in what many residents call the ''other Oregon,'' beyond the Portland metro area. Portland has bounced back from recession, while much of the rest of the state, where residents also mostly drink unfluoridated water, continues to struggle.
But even before the recession, there was a dental divide. A study in 2007 by the Oregon Department of Human Services said that 1 out of 17 first, second and third graders outside the Portland metro area needed urgent dental care because of pain or infection, but in the metro area itself, only 1 in 100 students did. Adding fluoride to Portland's water would affect about 900,000 residents in a state of 3.9 million people.
''Portland has better teeth,'' said Kim Kaminski, director of Clean Water Portland, a group that is fighting fluoridation. She called fluoridation for Portland a Band-Aid on a larger problem.
Fluoride remains a debating point around the nation, with some communities questioning the cost or re-examining the science. In Florida, the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners voted last October to halt fluoridation, but the water district serving San Jose, Calif., voted in December to start.
Portland residents interviewed on a downtown public square on a morning last week were divided on whether voters or their elected representatives should have the final say.
''There are issues that are more complex than the general population sometimes can really assess appropriately,'' said Carol Lindstrom, the marketing director for an energy efficiency company. Ms. Lindstrom said she grew up in a rural community in Washington State that did not have fluoride, ''and I think I suffered for it,'' she added.
Celia Wagner, a Web site developer, said the local fluoride debate, full of hyperbole and passion, had brought out the ''rugged individuality and quirkiness'' of Portland's character, for better and worse. ''It's Portland doing its Portland thing, which I love; I've been here 35 years,'' she said. ''It's charming, but occasionally not charming.''
Still, she said that it should be the voters who decide, and that she would vote for fluoride if she could. She grew up with it in the suburbs of Seattle. ''People tell me I have nice teeth,'' she said. ''I don't see the problem.''

HEADLINE: Where Cows Are Happy and Food Is Healthy

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

 BODY:
YAMHILL, Ore.
FOOD can be depressing. If it's tasty, it's carcinogenic. If it's cheap, animals were tortured.
But this, miraculously, is a happy column about food! It's about a farmer who names all his 230 milk cows, along with his 200 heifers and calves, and loves them like children.
Let me introduce Bob Bansen, a high school buddy of mine who is a third-generation dairyman raising Jersey cows on lovely green pastures here in Oregon beside the Yamhill River. Bob, 53, a lanky, self-deprecating man with an easy laugh, is an example of a farmer who has figured out how to make a good living running a farm that is efficient but also has soul.
As long as I've known him, Bob has had names for every one of his ''girls,'' as he calls his cows. Walk through the pasture with him, and he'll introduce you to them. 
''I spend every day with these girls,'' Bob explained. ''I know most of my cows both by the head and by the udder. You learn to recognize them from both directions.''
''This is Hosta,'' he began, and then started pointing out the others nearby. ''Jill. Sophia. This is Kimona. Edie would be the spotted one lying there. Pesto is the black one standing up. In front of her is Clare. Next to her is Pasta, who is Pesto's daughter.''
I asked about Jill, and Bob rattled off her specs. She is now producing about eight gallons a day, with particularly high protein and butterfat content. Jill's mother was Jolly, a favorite of Bob's. When Jolly grew old and unproductive, he traded her to a small family farm in exchange for a ham so she could live out her retirement with dignity.
When I pushed for Bob's secret to tell the cows apart, he explained: ''They have family resemblances. They look like their mothers.''
Oh, that helps.
As a farmkid myself, growing up with Bob here in the rolling green hills of Yamhill, where the Willamette Valley meets the coastal range, I've been saddened to see American farms turn into food factories. Just this year, I've written about hens jammed in cages, with dead birds left to rot beside the survivors, and about industrial farms that try to gain a financial edge by pumping chickens full of arsenic, antibiotics, Tylenol and even Prozac.
Yet all is not lost. Family farms can still thrive, while caring for animals and producing safe and healthy food.
For Bob, a crucial step came when he switched to organic production eight years ago. A Stanford study has cast doubt on whether organic food is more nutritious, but it affirms that organic food does contain fewer pesticides and antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Bob's big worry in switching to organic production was whether cows would stay healthy without routine use of antibiotics because pharmaceutical salesmen were always pushing them as essential. Indeed, about 80 percent of antibiotics in the United States go to farm animals -- leading to the risk of more antibiotic-resistant microbes, which already cause infections that kill some 100,000 Americans annually.
Bob nervously began to experiment by withholding antibiotics. To his astonishment, the cows didn't get infections; on the contrary, their health improved. He realized that by inserting antibiotics, he may have been introducing pathogens into the udder. As long as cows are kept clean and are given pasture rather than cooped up in filthy barns, there's no need to shower them with antibiotics and other pharmaceuticals, he says.
Many cows in America now live out their lives in huge dairy barns, eating grain and hay and pumping out milk. But evidence is growing that cows don't do well when locked up, so now many dairies are reverting to the traditional approach of sending cows out to pasture on grass.
''Pasture does wonders for cow health,'' Bob said. ''There's so much evidence that they are much happier out there. You can extend their lives so much by keeping them off concrete, so the trend is going that way.''
Is it a soggy sentimentality for farmers to want their cows to be happy? Shouldn't a businessman just worry about the bottom line?
Bob frowned. ''For productivity, it's important to have happy cows,'' he said. ''If a cow is at her maximum health and her maximum contentedness, she's profitable. I don't even really manage my farm so much from a fiscal standpoint as from a cow standpoint, because I know that, if I take care of those cows, the bottom line will take care of itself.''
This isn't to say that Bob's farm is a charity hostel. When cows age and their milk production drops, farmers slaughter them. Bob has always found that part of dairying tough, so, increasingly, he uses the older cows to suckle steers. That way the geriatric cows bring in revenue to cover their expenses and their day of reckoning can be postponed -- indefinitely, in the case of his favorite cows.
I teased Bob about running a bovine retirement home, and he smiled unapologetically.
''I feel good about it,'' he said simply. ''They support me as much as I support them, so it's easy to get attached to them. I want to work hard for them because they've taken good care of me.''
Like many farmers, Bob frets about regulations and reporting requirements, but he also sympathizes with recent animal rights laws meant to improve the treatment of livestock and poultry.
''You hate to have it go to legislation, but we need to protect the animals,'' he said. ''They're living things, and you have to treat them right.''
Granted, such a humane attitude may be easier to apply to dairying than to poultry. It's tough for cage-free poultry farms to compete economically with huge industrial operations that raise millions of birds jammed into cages, and healthy food that is good for humans and animals in some cases will cost more.
Moreover, we're never going to revert to the kind of agriculture that existed a century ago. Bob's 600 acres used to be farmed by five different families, and that consolidation won't be undone. But neither is it inevitable that consolidation will continue indefinitely so that America's farms end up as vast, industrial, soulless food factories.
I loved growing up on a sheep and cherry farm, even if that did mean getting up at 3 a.m. in the winter to check for newborn lambs, and I hope medium-size family farms remain a pillar of rural America. As Bob's dairy shows, food need not come at the cost of animal or human health and welfare. We need not wince when we contemplate where our food comes from.
The next time you drink an Organic Valley glass of milk, it may have come from one of Bob's cows. If so, you can bet it was a happy cow. And it has a name.
PHOTO: Bob Bansen raises Jersey cows on his Yamhill, Ore., organic farm. To him, they're more than milk cows. They're his ''girls.'' (PHOTOGRAPH BY SUSAN SEUBERT FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (SR13)

HEADLINE: The Issues? Yawn.

BYLINE: By DAVID JAVERBAUM. 
David Javerbaum is the author of ''The Last Testament: A Memoir by God.''

 BODY:
In this or any election year the candidates can be counted on to make regular references in their campaign speeches to ''the issues.'' It's important to realize that in doing so they are not actually alluding to the real-world challenges facing Americans. They are alluding to ''the issues'' -- just that, that actual two-word phrase.
The issues, of course, are what we all know elections are supposed to be about. In theory we want our public servants to be like those in Thucydides, appealing to our intellect with long, detailed, well-defended elaborations of their positions on those economic and geopolitical questions upon whose answers the future of our nation depends. But in practice, you were yawning by the end of that sentence. 
Most of us just aren't built to endure that much debate. (And they weren't in ancient Greece either. Thucydides was the Aaron Sorkin of his day -- a great writer who used current events as the basis for inspiring and thought-provoking speeches no real person would or could ever actually say.)
No: we are human beings. We like personalities and ad hominem attacks and sex scandals and gossip. This is how Homo electorus rolls. But the Homo sapiens part of us feels guilty about this. We know we should be talking about the issues. We just don't wanna. Luckily, the candidates are just as uninterested in getting wonky as the electorate is, and the two sides have evolved an ingenious, mutually beneficial arrangement to make structuralists proud: Turn signifier into the signified. Like:
''I care about the issues facing this country.''
''The issues facing this country are far too urgent for me to spend the next 10 minutes outlining them.''
''I want this debate to be about the issues. The economy. Our future. How to make America great. [Pause.] I'll tell you what else is great -- the fried dough here at the Iowa State Fair!''
If you don't make me talk about policy, I won't make you think about it. That is the unspoken agreement behind ''the issues.'' It is the electoral equivalent of the agreed-upon ''safety word'' that automatically ends an S&M session before it gets too intense.
But the phrase's work is still not done, for the officeseeker must now use it to win over the crowd, allaying its guilt over its own attention-deficit disorder by blaming a scapegoat -- his opponent.
''My opponent wants to avoid the issues.''
''My opponent is dancing a contemptuous cha-cha around the issues.''
''My opponent doesn't think you're smart enough to discuss the issues. To talk in-depth about things like... prosperity. Jobs. Money. [Pause.] Although I will admit there is plenty of 'dough' here at the Iowa State Fair! [Aide whispers in ear.] I mean the Missouri State Fair!''
In this way, ''the issues'' triggers an instantaneous meta-shift in the terms of the debate. The candidate now seeks to be judged, not on what he believes, but on how seriously he can get you to believe he wishes he could talk about what he believes. (In fact, a sentence like ''My opponent wants to avoid the issues'' implies a character flaw in one's opponent that, in a bit of Möbius logic, is itself a distraction from the issues.)
''The issues'' is versatile enough to allow columnists, bloggers and pundits -- the collective unholy troika of all human misery -- to join the fun. By dint of nine simple letters, they can effortlessly pose as Apollonian intellectuals perched high above politics' dismal squalor.
''Why won't Barack Obama and Mitt Romney talk about the issues?''
''Why are we so fixated on a congressman who believes in magical spermicidal anti-rape vagina fairies instead of the issues?!?''
''Why are we so fixated on the Athenian general Alcibiades' regular attendance at Dionysian orgies in Attica and Sparta instead of on the issues?!?''
''The issues'' is a rhetorical head fake; a feint toward a line of discussion as unlikely to ensue as a Martian invasion; the theoretical magnetic north to which the conjectural needle of some hypothetically idea-driven campaign desperately wishes to point.

LENGTH: 1077 words

HEADLINE: A City's Heartbreak Outlives Its Source

BYLINE: By MARK WINEGARDNER. 
Mark Winegardner is the author of four novels, including ''Crooked River Burning.''

 BODY:
On a bright, yet metaphorically dark day in 1995 -- temperature in the high 30s, balmy for Cleveland in December -- my 6-year-old son and I trudged down toward the lake to witness the real Cleveland Browns' dying day.
We threaded our way though a throng of angry tailgaters chanting ''Go to hell, Art Modell.'' Actually, Modell, the Browns' owner, was taking one of the best-supported teams in N.F.L. history not to hell but to Baltimore.
This and other profane slogans could also be found emblazoned on unlicensed T-shirts. My son, Sam, begged me for one.
I strongly considered it. 
Even though the N.F.L. would award Cleveland an expansion team that was allowed to keep the Browns' name, colors and records, Sam would never have the relationship with the team that a half-century's worth of Clevelanders had enjoyed -- and righteously suffered for.
From the time the team was founded in 1946 until Modell bought it in 1961 -- a prosperous era in which Cleveland was nobody's laughingstock -- the Browns were the best team in American sports. They had a record of 143-37-6. They were the only champion the All-American Football Conference ever had, and, in 1950, their first year in the N.F.L., they won that league's title, too. They returned to the championship game for each of the next five years, winning twice.
Cleveland loved these guys, but not just because they won.
The coach, Paul Brown, was from Massillon, right down the road. He had built Massillon High School into a prep powerhouse and won a national championship at Ohio State. He created the modern passing game. He helped integrate professional football, bringing in the future Hall of Famers Marion Motley and Bill Willis, both Ohio kids. The team's other big stars had names that sounded like the guy next to you on the assembly line -- and nicknames that were sublimely cool. Dante (Glue-Fingers) Lavelli. Automatic Otto Graham. Frank (Gunner) Gatski. Lou (the Toe) Groza.
When, in 1956, the Browns finally had a losing season, they used the sixth pick in the draft to select perhaps the greatest player ever: Jim Brown.
I missed all this.
I was born in 1961, eight months after Modell bought the team. Obviously, I have no memory of the next year, when Modell got into a power struggle with Paul Brown and fired him, or of 1964, when the Browns won the only championship by any major Cleveland sports team in my lifetime. I was oblivious when, after the '65 season, Jim Brown, in London filming ''The Dirty Dozen,'' asked to report late to training camp. Modell refused. Insulted, Brown -- barely 30, having led the league in rushing the previous year by almost 700 yards -- retired from football.
My first Browns were the Bill Nelson/Leroy Kelly teams, which, in 1968 and 1969, came up one game short of the Super Bowl. By then, Cleveland had become the scene of riots, of blocks of burning buildings. Our river had burned, too, somehow. This became a running joke, first on the television show ''Laugh-In,'' then pretty much everywhere else.
For most of the '70s, the Browns hugged .500. Not until 1980, about halfway through the Modell years, did the team start to feel accursed.
The so-called Kardiac Kids, led by quarterback Brian Sipe, after a year's worth of late-game heroics, were in the playoffs, at home, in subzero weather with a gale-force wind, down, 14-12, to Oakland with less than a minute to play and on the Raiders' 13. Sipe threw the ball into the wind. It was intercepted.
The name of the play was Red Right 88. Some now call it the Pass.
Later in the '80s, as Cleveland's attempts to repair its image and economy came to seem futile, in came a new hero, quarterback Bernie Kosar -- from Youngstown, right down the road. In both '86 and '87, the Browns came within a game of the Super Bowl. Both times, they lost, in the final moments and to Denver, undone once by the Drive and the next year by the Fumble, the details of which are too painful to explain.
In the '90s, as the city had a short-lived economic comeback, the Browns struggled. In 1991, Modell hired Bill Belichick, and said with confidence that if Belichick didn't work out, he would leave town.
In fact, Modell's departure was already on the horizon. When the city built a new stadium for the Indians, and the Browns had the chance to share it, Modell told the city he was O.K. waiting for a renovation to Cleveland Stadium. When he reconsidered, Cleveland put an initiative on the ballot for that renovation. On the eve of Election Day, Modell announced that he was moving to Baltimore. The next day, the initiative passed, with 72 percent of the vote.
A month later, my son and I entered the stadium for the last game. All around us were fans passing through the gates with wrenches, hacksaws and crowbars.
Inside, all the advertising had been blacked out. Modell watched on TV from his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. -- something that, because the game was not a sellout, unlike hundreds of games in a row before that season, and was thus not shown locally, the people of Cleveland could not do.
The Browns beat Cincinnati, 26-10. There was no booing. Nobody blamed the players. Afterward, people sawed and pried out the seats families had had for generations. The Browns ran over to the hard-core fans in the north end zone, the Dawg Pound, shaking hands and saying thank you.
After the season, Modell fired Belichick.
An expansion team called the Browns made its debut in 1999, but the connection with the team's past will probably, like Cleveland itself, never be the same.
In the fake Browns' second season, Baltimore won the Super Bowl. When Modell hoisted that trophy, he might as well have kneecapped us with it.
The year after, it was Belichick, then with New England, who was a Super Bowl champion.
The fake Browns are 68-141 and expected, again, to be awful. Yet on Sunday, three days after Modell's death, Sam and I will each be watching the first game of the season, me in Tallahassee, Fla., Sam an adult living in Chicago, wondering if we will live to see a champion in the city our hearts call home.

HEADLINE: Russia and Japan in Agreement on Natural Gas Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
VLADIVOSTOK, Russia -- Gazprom, Russia's state-controlled gas monopoly, signed an accord on Saturday with the government of Japan to move forward with plans for the construction of a $13 billion natural gas terminal here that would propel the Kremlin's ambitions to multiply its business and trade ties in the Far East.
While the ultimate deal still hinges on reaching an agreement on the price Japan will pay for the natural gas, the accord is a crucial step toward increasing Russian energy exports at a time when Japan is eager to find alternatives to its largely shuttered, and politically embattled, nuclear power industry. 
The agreement was signed by Aleksei Miller, the chairman of Gazprom, and Ichiro Takahara, a senior Japanese trade official, on the sidelines of the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting, which is being held in Russia for the first time.
Gazprom already sells natural gas to Japan, but another major deal would further reduce Russia's reliance on Europe as its primary market.
In a statement, Mr. Miller said that the Asia-Pacific market was ''the most capacious in the world'' and that within the next few years, sales by Gazprom to Asia would exceed its sales in Europe, where the company fills roughly a quarter of the Continent's demand.
At the economic summit meeting, officials said that the 21 members of the economic group, representing Pacific nations from Asia and the Americas, had reached an agreement to prevent any ban on the export of grains or other food products that could lead to rising prices and social unrest.
A ban on grain exports by Russia in 2010 was widely viewed as contributing to a global spike in prices, and it raised doubts about Russia as a reliable supplier of agricultural products. Severe droughts in the United States and parts of Russia this year have renewed fears of increases in food prices.
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has said there will be no export ban this year, and experts say that solid harvests in other parts of the world, including India, should help avert a crisis. Mr. Putin, as the conference host, had set food security as a top item on the agenda.
Officials said they had also reached an accord to reduce tariffs on products related to 54 technologies deemed environmentally friendly -- fulfilling a goal set at the economic conference last year.
Among the so-called green-technology items to benefit from the tariff reductions is equipment used for generating renewable energy, like solar and wind power, as well as products related to recycling and wastewater treatment. Under the agreement, customs duties could be no more than 5 percent by 2015.
One development being celebrated here in Vladivostok is Russia's entry last month into the World Trade Organization, making it the last major world economy to join the group, which establishes global norms and provides mechanisms to settle disputes.
But even as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton praised her Russian hosts for this development, noting that American exports ''could double or even triple'' as a result, she also criticized lingering protectionist policies, especially favored treatment of state-owned businesses.
Her comments were a clear rebuke of Russia and China, both of which maintain large state-controlled companies and sovereign wealth investment funds.
PHOTO: Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda and President Vladimir V. Putin met at a summit meeting in Vladivostok on Saturday. (PHOTOGRAPH BY SERGEI KARPUKHIN/REUTERS)

HEADLINE: Rescued by Music, Happy to Mail Out His Own CDs

BYLINE: By ANDY LANGER. 
Andy Langer is the music columnist for Esquire and the midday D.J. on KGSR in Austin.

 BODY:
Just two years ago, ''Junky Star,'' the album by Ryan Bingham & the Dead Horses, was released by the celebrated Nashville label Lost Highway Records. It was the most commercially successful album of Mr. Bingham's career, reaching No. 2 on the Billboard country charts. But on Sept. 18, when he releases its follow-up, ''Tomorrowland,'' the record will not appear on Lost Highway or any other major label. It will be put out by his own label, Axster Bingham Records, which has no track record and no other artists on its roster.
Mr. Bingham does not have the high profile of Wilco, Jack White or Radiohead -- other artists who have taken the risks and put in the hard work that come with independence for the right to make their own decisions and keep most of the profits. But Mr. Bingham had reason to believe the time for striking out on his own was good. The success of ''Junky Star,'' his third major-label album, closely followed ''The Weary Kind,'' his contribution to the soundtrack of the movie ''Crazy Heart,'' which earned Mr. Bingham and his co-writer, T Bone Burnett, a Grammy, an Oscar and a Golden Globe. 
''It's a liberating thing to work for yourself,'' said Mr. Bingham, 31, a native of New Mexico who in 2004 traded a fledgling career bull riding in rodeos across Texas for a similarly itinerant life as a musician. ''We've always been more of a road band than a band that depended on record sales or radio play. Touring, the hard-work part, doesn't scare us. So we're not afraid to sit in the office and sign CDs or stuff envelopes. Running to the post office to mail CDs is a lot less dangerous than six months on the road.''
Late last month, Mr. Bingham discussed his independence and his time spent in Texas in a telephone conversation from his home in Southern California.
Q. Parts of this record lean in a more rock-oriented direction then we've heard from you.
A. For the first time in my career, I had some time off before recording, and it's really the first opportunity I had to sit down at home with some electric guitars and experiment. I was listening to a lot of Jimmy Page and Jimi Hendrix. And the Clash. And the truth of the matter is that rock 'n' roll is a lot more fun to play live. My last record was a little slow, and a lot of the songs were dark and sad. Playing those songs every night got tough sometimes. I wanted a record this time around that would be fun to play live.
Q. There's a lot of mythology around your time in Texas -- ranch work, rodeo riding and what sounds awfully close to homelessness. How lean were the Texas days?
A. They were pretty rough. I went out on my own at 17. I was fortunate to have a lot of friends in a bunch of different towns. Eventually, I started working for a rodeo company in Del Rio. I always had couches to stay on, but never anywhere I felt was home. The decision I eventually made, to live out of the car and be on my own, was really my decision. It made me feel uncomfortable to rely on other people and ask for favors, so a lot of times I felt more at ease sleeping in the truck or camping out somewhere than asking people for a place to sleep and some food to eat.
Q. Music rescued you.
A. I truly believe that. I started playing songs and from the get-go, it was really therapeutic. It's always helped to say stuff out loud. The songs weren't really written for anybody to hear. A lot of the places I played early on were rough roadhouses, honky-tonks and dive bars. People were there to get drunk and fight. I could sing the songs all night long, and nobody was listening to the lyrics as long as the guitars were loud and the tempos were up. But it gave me the opportunity to sustain myself. I could make 40 bucks a night and pay for gas and food.
Q. In an election year, ''Tomorrowland,'' an album about the small guy fighting back, sounds like a protest record.
A. I'm not a political person or a protest songwriter. But I think what's going on around me influences me like anybody else -- social issues, corruption, the economic situation. For a lot of people, these are lean times. Drive though Detroit or Baltimore or Hartford, Conn., and they look like war zones. As touring musicians, we see a lot of harsh realities; the places we experience and the characters we see at certain times of the night, most people don't see. As a songwriter, I'm not trying to describe the impressions we collect on the road specifically, but more the emotion, the feeling that exposure to that stuff leaves you with.
Q. I suppose it could leave you cursing someone or something you think is to blame. This album has enough four-letter words on it I'd have expected one of those old black-and-white parental advisory warning stickers.
A. It's part of who I am and how I talk. Every now and then, everyone has to get a four-letter word off his chest. I just have a few more than the next guy.
PHOTO: Ryan Bingham's new album, ''Tomorrowland,'' is on his own label, Axster Bingham Records. (PHOTOGRAPH BY ANNA AXSTER)

HEADLINE: In School Finance Tangle, Wealth Doesn't Necessarily Mean More

BYLINE: By ROSS RAMSEY. 
rramsey@texastribune.org

 BODY:
Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.
School districts can get rich just as fast as the people in the oil business, and the poor-to-rich whiplash can have some weird aftereffects.
Public schools in Texas get about half of their money, on average, from property taxes. And when the property turns out to be sitting on top of the Eagle Ford Shale play, the sudden changes in wealth can produce fiscal temblors in the schools. 
Some, like the Dilley Independent School District, see an influx of money and get to keep it. Others, like the Cotulla I.S.D., see the money come in but don't get to keep it for very long.
Dilley, southwest of San Antonio on Interstate 35, has seen property values balloon to about $275 million from $130 million two years ago, according to Nobert Rodriguez, the superintendent. It is by most measures a poor school district -- one that gets money from the state to supplement what can be raised from local property taxes.
The general idea (school finance is about as simple as the tax code) is that no district should have too high a tax rate and that the state will supplement those that can't raise enough locally to pay for schools. The rich districts that can, with the same tax rate, raise more than a certain amount for public schools have to use some of their money to support the poor districts. That's called ''recapture,'' in the gnarled language of school finance.
The boom in property values means more money for Dilley, where 78 percent of the students qualify for free and reduced school meals, a benefit that is based on family income. And as fast as its fortunes have risen, Dilley is still in a position to raise money locally and to get money from the state. Property values will have to increase by another $140 million or so before the state comes asking for money. It's not impossible, Mr. Rodriguez said. ''Last year,'' he said, ''we went up $100 million.''
Cotulla, off the next major exit ramp from I-35 as you go south, is in a more difficult situation. Values there have jumped to $2.3 billion from $877 million, according to the school superintendent, Jack Seals. The district will bring in more money this year and won't have to write the state a big check -- there's a one-year lag before the new local values are plugged into the state's formula. Next year, however, Mr. Seals estimates, Cotulla will be writing the state a $15 million check.
It doesn't mean that the district is rich or the people in it are wealthy -- just that the land it taxes has gone up quickly and dramatically in value. In Cotulla, 85 percent of the students were from economically disadvantaged families in 2010.
But more money in revenue can mean more money for the schools, as is the case in Dilley. In Cotulla, it's an issue for the accountants, who will need to set aside enough of this year's windfall to help cover next year's check to the state. Theoretically, they'll have about the same amount of money to spend per student each year.
But booms make the schools nervous. Right now, construction is at a crazy pace, and there are big trucks on all the roads. Out-of-town workers outnumber rooms and beds and have to sleep in trailers, new hotels, portable buildings or the backs of their trucks.
It's a classic boom. People are getting rich and working hard, and the dirt is flying.
Since 2010, more than a dozen school districts -- mostly small ones like North Zulch, Carrizo Springs and Karnes City -- have seen property values rise rapidly, with more than half the growth coming from mineral properties, according to an analysis by Moak, Casey & Associates, a consultancy in Austin.
If the boom stops, property values will drop. If oil and gas prices fall -- even if the production and construction continue -- property values will fall. In the Dilleys and Cotullas, that would mean less money. Dilley gets to keep its windfall now without sending it to the state, but would not see it replaced should values drop.
Cotulla would be able to get state money again. But remember that one-year lag that's working for them now? It would work against them in a year of declining values.
''I worry about declining values in the future,'' Mr. Seals said. ''If values drop, we're going to be well behind the eight ball.''
PHOTO: Mark de la Garza, left, and Chovie Martinez planning a fence at a school in Dilley, which has seen a big rise in property values. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JENNIFER WHITNEY FOR THE TEXAS TRIBUNE)
