He has brought to prominence with him the youthful Bolívar ensemble, whose two-night stand is part of Carnegie Hall's Voices of Latin America festival. The repertory, including works by composers like Silvestre Revueltas, Esteban Benzecry and Heitor Villa-Lobos, is almost never done here, and it is sure to be galvanizing: few conductors draw visceral excitement out of an orchestra -- especially these young charges -- the way Mr. Dudamel does. Dec. 10-11. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
'MESSIAH' There are so many excellent New York performances of this great Handel oratorio at Christmastime that it is impossible to predict which will be best over all, whatever that may mean. But John Scott's is sure to rank high among the contenders, and it is typically the most lovable, with the superbly trained St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys holding forth in festive red cassocks before the church's intricately sculptured altarpiece. (The ailing pipe organ is another story, with pleas for contributions sure to be stuffed into the program.) James Richman's Concert Royal, on period instruments, fills out a sound worthy of the magnificent space. Dec. 11, 13. St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 664-9360, saintthomaschurch.org. (In other notable performances of ''Messiah,'' Julian Wachner conducts the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at Trinity Church on Dec. 9 and at Alice Tully Hall on Dec. 12; Kent Tritle conducts the amateur Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 17 and the professional Musica Sacra, also at Carnegie, on Dec. 20 and 22; and Emmanuelle Haïm conducts the New York Choral Artists and the New York Philharmonic from Dec. 18 to Dec. 22.) (J.R.O.)
'LES TROYENS' James Levine, the Met's ailing music director, has long been a champion of Berlioz's sprawling, shining masterpiece, so his absence from the podium for this revival of Francesca Zambello's production is particularly painful. Fabio Luisi will replace him, leading a cast that includes the deeply sympathetic mezzo-soprano Susan Graham as the spurned queen Dido, the tenor Marcello Giordani in the high-reaching role of Aeneas and Deborah Voigt, fresh from trying out the epic Brünnhilde in Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, as the desperate prophetess Cassandra. But one of the vocal pleasures may be in a minor role: the excellent bass Kwangchul Youn as Narbal. Opens Dec. 13. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'CHRISTMAS ORATORIO' Here, in Bach's six-pack of Christmas cantatas, is a welcome change of pace from Philippe Herreweghe and his Collegium Vocale Gent Choir and Orchestra, whom we are used to hearing in Bach's somber Passions (no bad thing, to be sure). It should be entertaining as well as uplifting to catch them in a jubilant mood. Dec. 15. Alice Tully Hall. (In another notable performance of Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio,'' as part of Trinity Wall Street's 12th Night Festival, Julian Wachner and the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra, who last season presented each of the six component cantatas on the appropriate day of the liturgical calendar, will this year divide them differently, with midday performances of Nos. 1 and 2 on Jan. 3, and Nos. 3 and 4 on Jan. 4, all at St. Paul's Chapel; and Nos. 5 and 6 on Jan. 5, at Trinity Church.) (J.R.O.)
'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' The Met, of late, has offered tightened versions of certain productions as family-friendly entertainments for the holiday season, and Bartlett Sher's antic version of Rossini's classic is an ideal choice. The company has not stinted on this year's cast, which features the charming up-and-coming stars Isabel Leonard, Alek Shrader, Rodion Pogossov and Jordan Bisch. The conductor Yves Abel's work at the house has always had stylish spirit. Opens Dec. 18. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
CONTACT! Last year's installment of the New York Philharmonic's series of new and recent music felt staler than in the past, but this concert is a return to form, with premieres of works by Andy Akiho and Jude Vaclavik as well as the first New York performances of ''Try,'' by the noted young composer Andrew Norman, and Jacob Druckman's ''Counterpoise.'' Jayce Ogren, well practiced in contemporary music, conducts, and the vocal soloist is the brilliant soprano Elizabeth Futral. Dec. 21. Metropolitan Museum. Dec. 22. Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org. (Z.W.)
NEW YORK VIRTUOSO SINGERS Delightful pluck! On the day a Mayan text projects as the ''end date'' of the Mayan calendar (whatever that may mean for the world at large), Harold Rosenbaum, his excellent professional choir and the Orchestra of St. Luke's propose to pick up the pieces with a performance of Haydn's great oratorio ''The Creation.'' Haydn's resounding C major burst of light can undoubtedly be counted on to set the cosmos aright once again. Dec. 21. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'MARIA STUARDA' Another New Year's Eve, another starring role for the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato at the Met. Last year Ms. DiDonato led a sterling cast in the Baroque pastiche ''The Enchanted Island.'' Now she takes on the diva role of the embittered Mary Stuart in Donizetti's riveting melodrama, part of that composer's trilogy of operas based, however loosely, on the lives of Tudor queens. The Met's general manager, Peter Gelb, had originally intended for all three of the operas to be directed by David McVicar and to star the soprano Anna Netrebko; Mr. McVicar is still on for ''Maria Stuarda'' and the third, ''Roberto Devereux,'' next season, but Ms. Netrebko decided that ''Anna Bolena'' was it for her, clearing the way for Ms. DiDonato. She will be joined by a cast of rising stars: Elza van den Heever (as Mary's rival, Elizabeth), Francesco Meli, Joshua Hopkins and Matthew Rose. Maurizio Benini conducts. Opens Dec. 31. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
JANUARY
GREEN MOUNTAIN PROJECT The soprano Jolle Greenleaf and the violinist and conductor Scott Metcalfe have made Monteverdi a welcome fixture of the new year in New York. In 2010 and 2011, they presented the towering 1610 Vespers, and this year they produced a 1640 Vespers, something of a pastiche. Now it is back to 1610 and back to the church where it all began. A happy new year indeed. Jan. 2-3. Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street, Manhattan, (646) 470-5809, tenetnyc.com. (J.R.O.)
PROTOTYPE: OPERA/THEATER/NOW Though New York City Opera's Vox Festival will continue this year, albeit curtailed in size and scope, as a laboratory for new operas, this new festival aims to add to the city's range of performances of contemporary work. Organized by Here Arts Center in SoHo and Beth Morrison, an adventurous arts presenter, the two weeks will feature a commissioned premiere -- ''Sumeida's Song,'' by the rising young composer Mohammed Fairouz -- as well as David T. Little's ''Soldier Songs,'' directed by Yuval Sharon, and other readings, presentations, concerts and panels. Jan. 9-19. Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, (212) 352-3101, prototypefestival.org. (Z.W.)
BUDAPEST FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA There are few better marriages of conductor and orchestra than Ivan Fischer and his alert, exciting ensemble. Frequent guests of Lincoln Center, they come this year with a varied program: Shostakovich's ''Suite for Variety Orchestra,'' Bernstein's ''Serenade'' (based on Plato's ''Symposium'' and featuring the violinist Janine Jansen) and Rachmaninoff's Symphony No. 2. Jan. 20. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
'DOUBT' Reeling from the recession, opera companies across America are playing it safe. But the Minnesota Opera -- which has, in Minneapolis and St. Paul, communities used to adventurous culture -- continues to program new work and thoughtful, theatrical productions of the classics. Next year brings this major commission composed by Douglas J. Cuomo, with a libretto by John Patrick Shanley, based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning play. The cast features the huge-voiced soprano Christine Brewer, in one of her too-rare operatic turns, as well as Denyce Graves, Matthew Worth and Adriana Zabala. Christopher Franklin conducts, and Kevin Newbury directs. Opens Jan. 26. Minnesota Opera, Ordway, St. Paul, (612) 333-6669, mnopera.org. (Z.W.)
'RIGOLETTO' This one might cause a ruckus. For his Metropolitan Opera debut, the director Michael Mayer (Broadway's ''Thoroughly Modern Millie'' and ''Spring Awakening'') places Verdi's great opera in Rat Pack-era Las Vegas, with a set by Christine Jones and the Duke cast as a sleazy Sinatra-type entertainer. Met audiences have tended to be doubtful about such updatings, but the previous production, from 1989, never inspired much affection, and if anyone can sell a difficult concept it is the excellent opening-night cast: the soprano Diana Damrau, the tenor Piotr Beczala and the baritone Zeljko Lucic. (Lisette Oropesa, Vittorio Grigolo and George Gagnidze take over later in the run.) Opens Jan. 28. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
MARC-ANDRÉ HAMELIN Everything this pianist plays, he plays well. And it's a good thing, since he plays almost everything. He began his career exploring the virtuosic fringes of the repertory and has gradually moved toward the center. His program here ranges from Bach to Mr. Hamelin's own Variations on a Theme by Paganini (in its New York premiere) and also includes works by Debussy, Rachmaninoff and Busoni. Jan. 30. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
WEST-EASTERN DIVAN ORCHESTRA Daniel Barenboim performing Beethoven at Carnegie is nothing new. But this time he brings his orchestra of young Israelis, Palestinians and Arabs to play all the symphonies. There is little in the sound of their recently released recordings of the works that would make you sense either youth or diversity. Seeing them in action should be a different matter, Jan. 30-31, Feb 2-3, Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
OPERA LAFAYETTE Sometimes this intrepid company's wanderings through the thickets of the French operatic repertory can yield great pleasures, and sometimes they remind you that there are reasons obscurities are obscure. Ah, but life's a crap shoot like that. Will ''Lalla Roukh,'' an Orientalist fantasia by Félicien David that wowed the Opéra Comique in 1862, hold up today as any more than a curiosity? We shall see. In any case, Ryan Brown's conducting is always spirited, and the production, by Bernard Deletré, incorporates the acclaimed Indian-dance troupe Kalanidhi Dance. Jan. 31. Rose Theater. (Z.W.)
FEBRUARY
OSVALDO GOLIJOV Mr. Golijov is Carnegie Hall's composer in residence this season, and a concert in its Making Music series, which offers commentary from composers as well as their music, could offer fascinating insights if the right questions are asked and answered. It is a chance to explore the methodology of a composer whose acquisitive methods have recently been called into question, to the point that some have accused him of plagiarism. The program, performed by the St. Lawrence String Quartet, the Zankel Band and others, includes the New York premiere of Mr. Golijov's ''Qohelet'' (more widely known under the spelling ''Koholet''), a Carnegie co-commission and one of the works that was challenged. Mr. Golijov altered it as a result. So what is the whole story? Feb. 4. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S It was a significant coup for this ensemble, excellent though it is, to secure the fast-rising Pablo Heras-Casado as its new principal conductor. He leads the orchestra for the first time at Carnegie Hall since his appointment in a program of the central repertory: Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture, Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 (with Christian Zacharias as soloist), Hans Zender's orchestrations of five Debussy preludes and the lighter, leaner 1841 version of Schumann's Fourth Symphony. All these are distant from the Baroque and new music in which Mr. Heras-Casado has long specialized. The orchestra has bet that his charisma and energy will outweigh his relative inexperience; it may be good for both him and the band that he will get to work with these fine players to refine his interpretations of the standards. Feb. 7. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
ROYAL CONCERTGEBOUW ORCHESTRA Mariss Jansons -- the principal conductor of both this ensemble and the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, and thus a regular commuter between Amsterdam and Munich -- turns 70 in January and seems to have emerged from several health crises of recent decades in fine fettle. Oh, he may still suffer from jet lag, but he certainly doesn't seem fazed. He takes the Bavarians to Tokyo to perform all the Beethoven symphonies in late November. Here he presents good variety in programs well gauged to show off this great orchestra's and Mr. Jansons's own versatility: in one, Bartok's Second Violin Concerto, with Leonidas Kavakos as soloist, and Mahler's First Symphony; in the other, Strauss's ''Death and Transfiguration'' (Mr. Jansons may feel that he has lived it) and Bruckner's Seventh Symphony. Feb. 13-14. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'PARSIFAL' Appearing a bit earlier than its traditional place around the Easter season, Wagner's final and perhaps deepest music drama arrives in New York in a new production by François Girard after a practice run at the Lyon Opera, where its scenic requirements -- a stage-filling sea of blood, for one thing -- strained the company's technical capabilities to the breaking point. Presumably those challenges will be a walk in the park for a Met recently tested by the mechanical headaches of Robert Lepage's Wagner ''Ring'' cycle. And blood aside, the house is fielding a remarkably strong cast: Jonas Kaufmann, seemingly born for the title role, as well as Katarina Dalayman, Peter Mattei, René Pape and Evgeny Nikitin, making his first New York appearance since his withdrawal from the Bayreuth Festival after the bizarre discovery that one of his tattoos resembled, at one point, a swastika. Daniele Gatti's deliberate, expansive take on the opera has polarized audiences in the past, but a little more time spent with singers of this quality wouldn't be too bad a fate. Opens Feb. 15. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'POWDER HER FACE' It's a sign of the composer Thomas Adès's rise to the top of his field that both his operas are being performed in New York this season. The Met's production of his sweeping version of ''The Tempest,'' opening in October, will doubtless grab more attention, but the chamber work ''Powder Her Face,'' about a 1960s sex scandal involving the Duchess of Argyll, has raunchily intimate charm. It's an opera that in content and scale wouldn't make much sense at the Met, so it's an ideal opening act for a New York City Opera, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for two of its four productions, that is trying to define itself artistically after a listless last season. Jay Scheib directs; Jonathan Stockhammer, a specialist in contemporary opera, conducts. Opens Feb. 15. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
'DON CARLO' When Lorin Maazel returned to the Met podium for a run of Wagner's ''Walküre'' in 2008 it was the first time he had conducted at the company since the early 1960s. It's a far smaller gap this time, as he leads Verdi's dark masterpiece and an experienced cast that includes Barbara Frittoli, Anna Smirnova, Ramón Vargas, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, Eric Halfvarson and Ferruccio Furlanetto, who scored a personal coup as Philip II when Nicholas Hytner's production was new in 2010. Opens Feb. 22. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'RADAMISTO' Harry Bicket has that rarest and best of gifts for an early-music specialist: the ability to make regular opera orchestras play with the snap of a period-instrument band. But there is still something special that happens when he leads his own English Concert, which will be joined for one of Handel's lesser-known masterworks by a fine cast that includes the veteran countertenor David Daniels, Brenda Rae, Patricia Bardon, Joélle Harvey and Luca Pisaroni. It is the first in a series of concert performances of Baroque operas at the hall by Mr. Bicket and the ensemble in coming seasons, so there's much to look forward to. Feb. 24. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
'THE TURN OF THE SCREW' The New York City Opera finally has the right idea. This beleaguered company has learned that it's a losing battle to go head to head with the Met in terms of repertory and production style, and smarter to compete with the city's smaller, more nimble companies. To that end, it is opening its season with two intimate-scale operas that would have been naturals from, say, Gotham Chamber Opera: Thomas Adès's ''Powder Her Face'' and this intensely creepy work by Britten, both performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The conductor is the versatile Jayce Ogren; the director is Sam Buntrock, whose Broadway production of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' used lighting and projections with fluid ease. The cast had not been announced at press time. Opens Feb. 24. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
MARCH
VIENNA PHILHARMONIC Happiness is conducting two of the world's greatest orchestras at Carnegie Hall in one season. Franz Welser-Möst, having dropped in with his own Cleveland Orchestra in November, now leads an orchestra that -- though proudly independent -- is his in another sense, he being Austrian. The three programs include symphonies by Dvorak (No. 7), Schubert (No. 6) and Bruckner (No. 4); songs by Richard Strauss, sung by the tenor Herbert Lippert; Berg's Violin Concerto, played by Frank Peter Zimmermann; and a work by the contemporary German Jörg Widmann. March 1-3. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
JENNIFER KOH You may see Ms. Koh early in the season, since she is enacting the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing title character of Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's ''Einstein on the Beach'' in some performances (Sept. 14-16) of the Brooklyn Academy production. Here, in the second installment of her three-part multiyear series Bach and Beyond, she occupies the stage alone and presumably without fright wig, playing solo violin works by Bartok and Phil Kline, in addition to Bach. (A recording of the first part is to be released in October by Cedille Records.) March 2. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI' The Met reserves runs of Riccardo Zandonai's infectiously dramatic verismo rarity for divas it really believes in. It was last mounted in the 1980s for Renata Scotto, and this new revival is a major endorsement of the soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek, a favorite in London whose New York career is just getting started. (She also joins the Met Orchestra for Wagner's ''Wesendonck Lieder'' at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 14.) Her co-star, the tenor Marcello Giordani, is ardent but inconsistent, two adjectives that also apply to the conductor, Marco Armiliato. But when Ms. Westbroek is in her groove, she is as thrilling as large stretches of Zandonai's score. Opens March 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
THE BACH VARIATIONS The early-music specialist Masaaki Suzuki and his Bach Collegium Japan and Yale Schola Cantorum join the New York Philharmonic in opening its monthlong festival. The program is built on a lovely idea, juxtaposing works by Bach with near counterparts by his great revivalist, Mendelssohn. (From each comes a Magnificat in D.) March 6-9. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'LA PASIÓN SEGÚN SAN MARCOS' As a sort of belated appendage to its festival Voices From Latin America, Carnegie Hall devotes its choral institute this season to Osvaldo Golijov's magnum opus. In the culminating performance, Robert Spano conducts the Orquesta la Pasión, members of the Schola Cantorum de Venezuela and choruses from area high schools. March 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
LONDON PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, having presented the London Symphony and the Philharmonia Orchestra in the fall, completes its minifestival of major London orchestras. Vladimir Jurowski, the orchestra's principal conductor, presents two programs: first Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. 1, with Vadim Repin as soloist, and Beethoven's Symphony No. 5; then Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4, with Hélène Grimaud as soloist, and Mahler's Symphony No. 5. March 10-11. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
MASS IN B MINOR Happily, major American orchestras have been rediscovering Bach and the Baroque, having largely conceded that repertory to early-music specialists for several decades. The New York Philharmonic had a leg up with Kurt Masur as its music director through the 1990s. Coming from a long tenure in Leipzig, Germany, where Bach spent his last 27 years, Mr. Masur brought Bach's major choral works to the orchestra with some regularity and in 1998 even imported the choir of St. Thomas Church in Leipzig, which Bach had directed, for a ''St. Matthew Passion.'' It is good to see Alan Gilbert pick up the mantle here as part of a major Philharmonic series, the Bach Variations, with the New York Choral Artists and stellar vocal soloists: Dorothea Röschmann, Anne Sofie von Otter, Steve Davislim and Eric Owens. March 13-16. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE' This season Renée Fleming has a coveted Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, for which she has programmed two recitals, including a battle of the divas alongside the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, and a concert with the New York Philharmonic. But the centerpiece is a semistaged concert performance of this gauzily lyrical André Previn opera, with Blanche DuBois created as a vehicle for Ms. Fleming, first performed in 1998. The work hasn't been heard much since, though it is being revived on March 26 at Lyric Opera of Chicago, where Ms. Fleming is the creative consultant. The Carnegie performance, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's under Patrick Summers, is a test run of sorts for that Chicago stand, featuring the same excellent supporting cast: Susanna Phillips, Teddy Tahu Rhodes and Anthony Dean Griffey. March 14. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY After this gloriously adventurous ensemble's American Mavericks festival last year at Carnegie Hall, which featured work from some of the out-there corners of the repertory, it will be a fascinating shift to hear it in the standards, in which the orchestra and its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, also shine. The first night's program pairs Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4 (with the brilliant Yuja Wang as soloist) and Brahms's First Symphony with the New York premiere of a work by Samuel Carl Adams, and the second concert features the Ninth Symphony of Mahler, a Thomas favorite. March 20-21. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
CARTER BREY New York Philharmonic audiences have been blessed, hearing Mr. Brey regularly since he became the orchestra's principal cellist in 1996. But the pleasure has been mixed, because he had to cut back sharply on his solo career to do it. In a substantial bit of payback, the Philharmonic puts Mr. Brey forward to perform Bach's six unaccompanied cello suites as part of its Bach Variations festival. Expect him to shine. March 27. Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th Street and Central Park West, (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org. (J.R.O.)
LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC At its premiere in Los Angeles in May, John Adams's oratorio ''The Gospel According to the Other Mary'' badly lagged dramatically, but many moments of its protean, searching score showed a mature composer at the height of his powers. The Philharmonic and its music director, Gustavo Dudamel, bring the work to New York with the same excellent soloists -- Tamara Mumford, Kelley O'Connor and Russell Thomas -- and a new element: a staging by the theater artist Peter Sellars, who collaborated with Mr. Adams on the libretto. The next evening's concert features Claude Vivier's ''Zipangu,'' for strings, ''La Mer'' by Debussy and Stravinsky's ''Firebird,'' the kind of vividly dramatic work at which Mr. Dudamel excels. March 27-28. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
'ST. MATTHEW PASSION' Ivan Fischer's conducting appearances in New York invariably yield fine performances, but in recent years they have also become genuine events. In 2010 Mr. Fischer presented all the Beethoven symphonies, half on period instruments, half on modern; in 2011 he offered Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' in his own staging; and in April he led Mozart's Requiem with choristers intermingled among the orchestra to give the players a better feel for the text. Bach's great Passion is to be sure an event in itself, and no unusual twists have been announced -- yet. Mr. Fischer conducts Musica Sacra and the Orchestra of St. Luke's, with soloists including Dominique Labelle, John Tessier and Hanno Müller-Brachmann. March 28. Carnegie Hall. (In other notable performances of the ''St. Matthew Passion,'' John Scott conducts the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and Concert Royal at St. Thomas Church on March 21, and Julian Wachner conducts the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at Trinity Church on March 24.) (J.R.O.)
APRILIt is
BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA In all the rampant speculation about who might succeed James Levine as the orchestra's music director, the name Daniele Gatti seems to have receded. Mr. Gatti is a gifted and experienced maestro in midcareer and seems not to be overcommitted by the standards of conductors today, despite major posts at the Orchestre National de France and the Zurich Opera. In this series, after a mixed program conducted by Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, a veteran who has given the orchestra yeoman service during its transition, the second and third programs are conducted by Mr. Gatti. Though there is no reason to expect anything but excellent performances, it will be hard not to wonder what Mr. Levine might have done with Mahler's Third Symphony, one of his great specialties, this time around in the second program, or what he might have made of the third, all Wagner. Certainly, on each of these terrains, Mr. Gatti will be held to the highest standard, by orchestra and public alike. April 3-5. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'GIULIO CESARE' It's tough being the final new Met production of the year. With everyone exhausted and attention flagging, you tend, like Rodney Dangerfield, to get no respect. It doesn't help that David McVicar's version of this Handel masterpiece, which puts a colorful colonial-era, Neo-Classical spin on the ancient Egyptian setting, has already been captured on DVD. But the Met's cast -- David Daniels in the title role, Natalie Dessay as Cleopatra and the excellent Alice Coote as Sesto -- is of interest, and the conductor, Harry Bicket, is a pro at this repertory. The Met orchestra plays its heart out for him. Opens April 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'GESUALDO REFLECTIONS' The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is best known for the classics; its concerts are the place to go when you want a Beethoven quartet played with dependable polish. But the society also has a relatively unheralded, consistently creative and excellent new-music series in Lincoln Center's intimate Kaplan Penthouse. The highlight, though it doesn't take place at the penthouse, is a celebration of the 400th anniversary of the birth of the brilliant and murderous composer Carlo Gesualdo featuring the Antioch Chamber Ensemble, the pianist Soyeon Kate Lee and the Brentano String Quartet. In keeping with Gesualdo's experimental music, centuries ahead of its time, the program juxtaposes his work with 21st-century responses -- by Bruce Adolphe, Brett Dean, David Gompper and Wolfgang Rihm -- for various chamber forces. April 4. Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org. (Z.W.)
'DER RING DES NIBELUNGEN' There will be a degree of deja vu as the Met brings back Robert Lepage's version of Wagner's epic masterpiece for the first time as a piece of the repertory, after the rollout of the full cycle last season. For the three cycles Deborah Voigt and Katarina Dalayman still alternate as Brünnhilde; Jay Hunter Morris's bright-voiced Siegfried still gets his turn, as does Hans-Peter König's memorably rich Hagen; and the enormous planks of Mr. Lepage's machine still rotate impassively. The question will be whether and how the spectacle suffers without the intensity provided by some of last season's stars: Bryn Terfel, Jonas Kaufmann, Eva-Maria Westbroek and Waltraud Meier. Fabio Luisi conducts. Cycles open on April 6 and 25 and May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'MOSÈ IN EGITTO' Rossini's serious operas still don't receive the productions they deserve; they are long and not easy to cast. But they have irresistible grandeur. Now the New York City Opera offers a super-rare staging of the Italian original at City Center, the company's original home. The production is directed by Michael Counts, the visually eclectic creator of City Opera's ''Monodramas'' evening; we'll see how he handles the climactic parting of the Red Sea. (Projections, credited to Ada Whitney/Beehive, will presumably play a role.) Jayce Ogren, City Opera's man for all seasons, conducts. Opens April 14. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
DRESDEN STAATSKAPELLE It will be fascinating to catch up with this orchestra and itsprincipal conductor, Christian Thielemann, in view of the jockeying for power going on at European festivals. After Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic announced that they would leave the Salzburg Easter Festival next spring in favor of an event in Baden-Baden, Germany, Mr. Thielemann and the Staatskapelle were quick to move in. The Berlin Philharmonic sounded in splendid shape at Carnegie in February, and this season, just weeks after that Salzburg appearance, it is the Staatskapelle's turn in programs of Brahms (''Academic Festival Overture''; Violin Concerto, with Lisa Batiashvili as soloist; Symphony No. 4) and Bruckner (Symphony No. 8). April 17, 19. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'TRISTAN UND ISOLDE' The acclaimed Swedish dramatic soprano Nina Stemme, who set Carnegie Hall ablaze as Strauss's Salome with Franz Welser-Möst and the Cleveland Orchestra in May, has said that her way in life is ''to hurry slowly.'' She has held back in establishing a career in the United States, and she will take up Wagner's Isolde at the Met only in the 2016-17 season. American Wagnerites will undoubtedly flock to Houston to hear her do it sooner. Ben Heppner is scheduled to sing Tristan, but you may recall that he gave the Met fits in the role in 2008, claiming illness and showing up for only the last of six planned performances. Christof Loy directs, and Patrick Summers conducts. If it all comes together, it should be worth the trip. Opens April 18. Houston Grand Opera, Wortham Center, (713) 228-6737, houstongrandopera.org. (J.R.O.)
'LA PÉRICHOLE' Christopher Alden's dreamlike production of Mozart's ''Così Fan Tutte'' was the bright spot in the New York City Opera's uninspired last season, the latest in a series of memorable shows the director has made for the company in recent years. He now turns his attention to a seemingly unlikely work: this farcical operetta by Offenbach about a Peruvian street singer who triangulates between her true love and a Spanish official. (Another frothy opera, Johann Strauss's ''Fledermaus,'' is also on Mr. Alden's agenda this year, with a production opening in October at the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto.) Mr. Alden has a gift for bringing out the darkness and sophistication in the unlikeliest of places and pieces. Opens April 21. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
'WAR REQUIEM' Of the many commemorations of Benjamin Britten's centennial here in 2013, this performance of a consummate masterpiece, a pacifist statement mingling the text of the Requiem Mass with poetry of Wilfred Owen, will undoubtedly be one of the more imposing, with Kent Tritle conducting the 200-voice Oratorio Society of New York, itself celebrating its 140th anniversary. The vocal soloists are the excellent Emalie Savoy, soprano; John Matthew Myers, tenor; and Jesse Blumberg, baritone. April 22. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
SWEDISH CHAMBER ORCHESTRA New York admirers of the Swedish soprano Nina Stemme who cannot catch that ''Tristan und Isolde'' in Houston must content themselves with this catchall concert, in which she will perform songs of Berlioz, Brahms, Wagner, Grieg, Sibelius, Strauss and Weill. In addition, Thomas Dausgaard conducts the fine ensemble in works or parts of works by Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Elgar, Sibelius and Ravel. April 25. Alice Tully Hall. (J.R.O.)
STRAVINSKY SACRED WORKS Julian Wachner continues his emphasis on more or less contemporary fare this season with the Trinity Choir and Novus NY devoting a weekend to the complete sacred works by a restless master. Stravinsky essentially announced modernism in music with his ''Rite of Spring'' in 1913, then looked back over his shoulder with a Neo-Classicism largely of his own invention and finally found his way to the spare, serialist aesthetic that dominates in many of the works here. Rightly, the majestic ''Symphony of Psalms'' crowns the affair. April 26-27 at Trinity Church. April 28 at St. Paul's Chapel. (J.R.O.)
YALE IN NEW YORK This four-concert series concludes with a commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the death of Paul Hindemith, ''Prankster and Master'': a Yale professor for the 13 years before his death and an astonishingly prolific composer and champion of useful music (Gebrauchsmusik) most of whose works have largely fallen into disuse. The current faculty members Boris Berman, pianist, and Ettore Causa, violist, and members of the Yale Philharmonia perform works of Hindemith including the sure-to-be-immortal ''Overture to 'The Flying Dutchman' as Played at Sight by a Second-Rate Concert Orchestra at the Village Well at 7 O'Clock in the Morning,'' for string quartet. April 28. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
MAY
'DIALOGUES DES CARMÉLITES' Some critics, including Anthony Tommasini in The New York Times, have called for the Met to appoint a director of productions, who would work with the general manager, Peter Gelb, and the music director, whoever that may be, to plot the company's theatrical direction. (S0 far Mr. Gelb has resisted the idea.) The last time something like that happened was when John Dexter filled the position in the late 1970s and early '80s. Audiences are periodically reminded of that brief golden age for theater at the Met when Dexter's productions are revived; though more than 30 years old, their elegance and intelligence shine through, as in his spectacular yet subtle take on Britten's ''Billy Budd,'' performed last season. One of Dexter's finest shows was his ''Dialogues des Carmélites,'' as unadorned and inspired as Poulenc's score. This revival has a fine cast, including Isabel Leonard, Patricia Racette, Erin Morley, Elizabeth Bishop and Paul Appleby, conducted by Louis Langrée. Opens May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
EARLY MUSIC NEW YORK The fascinating program ''London's Musical Bridge: The Enlightened English'' pairs works by 18th-century native English composers with counterparts by Germans who had settled in London: thus, suites by John Avison and Handel, overtures by William Boyce and Johann Christian Bach, and sinfonias by Thomas Arne and Frederick William Herschel. Herschel, in his day job as astronomer, discovered the planet Uranus: enlightened indeed. May 4. First Church of Christ, Scientist, Central Park West at 68th Street, (212) 280-0330. earlymusicny.org. (J.R.O.)
SPRING FOR MUSIC This annual festival of North American orchestras, conceived by top music professionals to encourage and reward adventurous programming, has in its first two seasons effectively filled what it has shown to be a valuable niche: giving Carnegie Hall-exposure to ensembles showing initiative, several of which might otherwise never have found their way there. Carlos Kalmar and the Oregon Symphony -- who made the biggest splash in 2011 with a program they have since recorded for the Pentatone label, ''Music for a Time of War'' -- present a wide-ranging collection of works by Schubert, Ravel, Schoenberg, Kurt Weill and the Thai composer Narong Prangcharoen (May 9). Also returning to the festival, which mandates a year off between appearances, are David Alan Miller and the Albany Symphony Orchestra, who presented a program centered on spirituals in 2011 and now play another American program, with works by Gershwin, Morton Gould and John Harbison (May 7). In addition, Marin Alsop conducts the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra; JoAnn Falletta, the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra; Leonard Slatkin, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra; and Christoph Eschenbach, the National Symphony Orchestra. May 6-11. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
DETROIT SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA To single out the oddest of the Spring for Music programs: Leonard Slatkin conducts Ives's Symphonies Nos. 1 through 4, a notion utterly logical on its surface yet, given the ear-twisting complexities in much of the music, utterly bizarre. Not even counting however many intermissions and stage changes, the program runs well over two hours. But will Mr. Slatkin be able to resist adding an encore: say, Ives's attempt at a monster sequel, the ''Universe Symphony,'' which the Nashville Symphony performed in the completion by Larry Austin at Spring for Music this year? May 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
TOKYO STRING QUARTET Though the personnel has shifted in recent years, it was still quite a brand, established over 43 years of excellent performance (and kudos to Kazuhide Isomura, the violist, who saw it all). Now the quartet has decided to quit while still near the top. It has picked excellent collaborative works to go out with, both in this concert (Schubert's resolutely sunny String Quintet, with the cellist Lynn Harrell) and in its penultimate recording (Brahms's late, mellow Clarinet Quintet, with the clarinetist Jon Manasse), to be released by Harmonia Mundi in November. But the quartet takes final leave on its own, both here on stage, with works by Haydn and Bartok (the Sixth Quartet, his last), and on disc, with works of Dvorak and Smetana, scheduled for release in 2013. May 11. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO' Looking around and noting the decided paucity of quality opera in its city, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, never an ensemble to rest on its laurels, is improbably turning itself into a de facto opera company. It is focusing on new and recent works but also unveiling a series of staged performances of Mozart and Lorenzo Da Ponte's three classic operas, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel and featuring sets and costumes by noted architects and fashion designers. Last year ''Don Giovanni'' was promising, but the logistics, with the orchestra far above and behind the singers, were a work in progress. For this year's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' the setup will be adjusted for a production designed by Jean Nouvel and Azzedine Alaïa and starring Christopher Maltmann and Dorothea Röschmann. May 17, 19, 23, 25. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com. (Z.W.)
'GILBERT'S PLAYLIST' If four programs in May and June are being put forward as Alan Gilbert's playlist, you have to wonder what that implies about the rest of his season with the New York Philharmonic. Rote? Required? But questions about the marketing strategy don't detract from the quality and creativity of the work he is offering under that unfortunate title. First come jazz-inflected works by Stravinsky, Shostakovich, Copland and Wynton Marsalis, played alongside the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, then Dallapiccola's stark one-act opera ''Il Prigioniero'' (featuring Gerald Finley and Patricia Racette), sharing a bill with Lisa Batiashvili in Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1. Mr. Gilbert offers his new arrangement of Wagner, ''A Ring Journey,'' with Christopher Rouse's ''Seeing,'' featuring the pianist Emanuel Ax. Finally, to close the season, Doug Fitch, who has collaborated with Mr. Gilbert and the orchestra in recent seasons, directs and designs an evening of Stravinsky ballets (''The Fairy's Kiss'' and ''Petrouchka'') with Karole Armitage creating choreography for the New York City Ballet dancer Sara Mearns. May 31-June 29. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
JUNE
STOKOWSKI CELEBRATION Now the gloves are off. Mr. Nézet-Séguin, for all practical purposes, embodies Stokowski, as the Philadelphia Orchestra returns to its treasured but acoustically flawed old home, the Academy of Music. In three days of intensive programming, he conducts Brahms's First Symphony and Dvorak's Ninth, Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Scheherazade'' and works by Ippolitov-Ivanov and Wagner, an audience-choice program and repertory from the animated Disney film ''Fantasia.'' But in the film, Stokowski got to shake hands with Mickey Mouse. How do you replicate that, Mr. Nézet-Séguin? June 21-23. Academy of Music, Philadelphia, (215) 893-1999, philorch.org. (J.R.O.)

HEADLINE: The Weatherman Is Not a Moron

BYLINE: By NATE SILVER

 BODY:
From the inside, the National Centers for Environmental Prediction looked like a cross between a submarine command center and a Goldman Sachs trading floor. Twenty minutes outside Washington, it consisted mainly of sleek workstations manned by meteorologists working an armada of flat-screen monitors with maps of every conceivable type of weather data for every corner of the country. The center is part of the National Weather Service, which Ulysses S. Grant created under the War Department. Even now, it remains true to those roots. Many of its meteorologists have a background in the armed services, and virtually all speak with the precision of former officers. 
They also seem to possess a high-frequency-trader's skill for managing risk. Expert meteorologists are forced to arbitrage a torrent of information to make their predictions as accurate as possible. After receiving weather forecasts generated by supercomputers, they interpret and parse them by, among other things, comparing them with various conflicting models or what their colleagues are seeing in the field or what they already know about certain weather patterns -- or, often, all of the above. From station to station, I watched as meteorologists sifted through numbers and called other forecasters to compare notes, while trading instant messages about matters like whether the chance of rain in Tucson should be 10 or 20 percent. As the information continued to flow in, I watched them draw on their maps with light pens, painstakingly adjusting the contours of temperature gradients produced by the computers -- 15 miles westward over the Mississippi Delta or 30 miles northward into Lake Erie -- in order to bring them one step closer to accuracy.
These meteorologists are dealing with a small fraction of the 2.5 quintillion bytes of information that, I.B.M. estimates, we generate each day. That's the equivalent of the entire printed collection of the Library of Congress about three times per second. Google now accesses more than 20 billion Web pages a day; the processing speed of an iPad rivals that of last generation's most powerful supercomputers. All that information ought to help us plan our lives and profitably predict the world's course. In 2008, Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired magazine, wrote optimistically of the era of Big Data. So voluminous were our databases and so powerful were our computers, he claimed, that there was no longer much need for theory, or even the scientific method. At the time, it was hard to disagree.
But if prediction is the truest way to put our information to the test, we have not scored well. In November 2007, economists in the Survey of Professional Forecasters -- examining some 45,000 economic-data series -- foresaw less than a 1-in-500 chance of an economic meltdown as severe as the one that would begin one month later. Attempts to predict earthquakes have continued to envisage disasters that never happened and failed to prepare us for those, like the 2011 disaster in Japan, that did.
The one area in which our predictions are making extraordinary progress, however, is perhaps the most unlikely field. Jim Hoke, a director with 32 years experience at the National Weather Service, has heard all the jokes about weather forecasting, like Larry David's jab on ''Curb Your Enthusiasm'' that weathermen merely forecast rain to keep everyone else off the golf course. And to be sure, these slick-haired and/or short-skirted local weather forecasters are sometimes wrong. A study of TV meteorologists in Kansas City found that when they said there was a 100 percent chance of rain, it failed to rain at all one-third of the time.
But watching the local news is not the best way to assess the growing accuracy of forecasting (more on this later). It's better to take the long view. In 1972, the service's high-temperature forecast missed by an average of six degrees when made three days in advance. Now it's down to three degrees. More stunning, in 1940, the chance of an American being killed by lightning was about 1 in 400,000. Today it's 1 in 11 million. This is partly because of changes in living patterns (more of our work is done indoors), but it's also because better weather forecasts have helped us prepare.
Perhaps the most impressive gains have been in hurricane forecasting. Just 25 years ago, when the National Hurricane Center tried to predict where a hurricane would hit three days in advance of landfall, it missed by an average of 350 miles. If Hurricane Isaac, which made its unpredictable path through the Gulf of Mexico last month, had occurred in the late 1980s, the center might have projected landfall anywhere from Houston to Tallahassee, canceling untold thousands of business deals, flights and picnics in between -- and damaging its reputation when the hurricane zeroed in hundreds of miles away. Now the average miss is only about 100 miles.
Why are weather forecasters succeeding when other predictors fail? It's because long ago they came to accept the imperfections in their knowledge. That helped them understand that even the most sophisticated computers, combing through seemingly limitless data, are painfully ill equipped to predict something as dynamic as weather all by themselves. So as fields like economics began relying more on Big Data, meteorologists recognized that data on its own isn't enough.
The I.B.M. Bluefire supercomputer in the basement of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., is so large that it essentially creates its own weather. The 77 trillion calculations that Bluefire makes each second, in its mass of blinking lights and coaxial cable, generate so much radiant energy that it requires a liquid cooling system. The room where Bluefire resides is as drafty as a minor-league hockey rink, and it's loud enough that hearing protection is suggested.
The 11 cabinets that hold the supercomputer are long and narrow and look like space-age port-a-potties. When I mentioned this to Rich Loft, the director of technology development for NCAR, he was not amused. To him, this computer represents the front line in an age-old struggle to predict our environment. ''You go back to Chaco Canyon or Stonehenge,'' Loft said, ''and people realized they could predict the shortest day of the year and the longest day -- that the moon moved in predictable ways. But there are things an ancient man couldn't predict: ambush from some kind of animal, a flash flood or a thunderstorm.''
For centuries, meteorologists relied on statistical tables based on historical averages -- it rains about 45 percent of the time in London in March, for instance -- to predict the weather. But these statistics are useless on a day-to-day level. Jan. 12, 1888, was a relatively warm day on the Great Plains until the temperature dropped almost 30 degrees in a matter of hours and a blinding snowstorm hit. More than a hundred children died of hypothermia on their way home from school that day. Knowing the average temperature for a January day in Topeka wouldn't have helped much in a case like that.
The holy grail of meteorology, scientists realized, was dynamic weather prediction -- programs that simulate the physical systems that produce clouds and cold fronts, windy days in Chicago and the morning fog over San Francisco as they occur. Theoretically, the laws that govern the physics of the weather are fairly simple. In 1814, the French mathematician Pierre-Simon Laplace postulated that the movement of every particle in the universe should be predictable as long as meteorologists could know the position of all those particles and how fast they are moving. Unfortunately, the number of molecules in the earth's atmosphere is perhaps on the order of 100 tredecillion, which is a 1 followed by 44 zeros. To make perfect weather predictions, we would not only have to account for all of those molecules, but we would also need to solve equations for all 100 tredecillion of them at once.
The most intuitive way to simplify the problem was to break the atmosphere down into a finite series of boxes, or what meteorologists variously refer to as a matrix, a lattice or a grid. The earliest credible attempt at this, according to Loft, was made in 1916 by an English physicist named Lewis Fry Richardson, who wanted to determine the weather over northern Germany on May 20, 1910. This was not technically a prediction, because the date was some six years in the past, but Richardson treated it that way, and he had a lot of data: a series of observations of temperature, barometric pressures and wind speeds that had been gathered by the German government. And as a pacifist serving a volunteer ambulance unit in northern France, he also had a lot of time on his hands. So Richardson broke Germany down into a series of two-dimensional boxes, each measuring three degrees of latitude by three degrees of longitude. Then he went to work trying to solve the equations that governed the weather in each square and how they might affect weather in the adjacent ones.
Richardson's experiment failed miserably. It ''predicted'' a dramatic rise in barometric pressure that hadn't occurred and produced strange-looking weather patterns that didn't resemble any seen in Germany before or since. Had he made a computational error? Were his equations buggy? It was hard to say. Even the most devoted weather nerds weren't eager to solve differential equations for months on end to double-check his work for one day in one country six years in the past.
What Richardson needed, he thought, was more manpower. He envisioned a weather-forecasting center with some 64,000 meteorologists, all working simultaneously to have the computational speed to make accurate weather forecasts in real time. His dream came to fruition (sort of) in 1950, when the first computer weather forecast was tried by the mathematician John von Neumann and a team of scientists at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. They used a machine that could make about 5,000 calculations a second, which was quite possibly as fast as 64,000 men. Alas, 5,000 calculations a second was no match for the weather. As it turned out, their forecast wasn't much better than a random guess.
Our views about predictability are inherently flawed. Take something that is often seen as the epitome of randomness, like a coin toss. While it may at first appear that there's no way to tell whether a coin is going to come up heads or tails, a group of mathematicians at Stanford is able to predict the outcome virtually 100 percent of the time, provided that they use a special machine to flip it. The machine does not cheat -- it flips the coin the exact same way (the same height, with the same strength and torque) over and over again -- and the coin is fair. Under those conditions, there is no randomness at all.
The reason that we view coin flips as unpredictable is because when we toss them, we're never able to reproduce the exact same motion. A similar phenomenon applies to the weather. In the late 1950s, the renowned M.I.T. mathematician Edward Lorenz was toiling away in his original profession as a meteorologist. Then, in the tradition of Alexander Fleming and penicillin or the New York Knicks and Jeremy Lin, he made a major discovery purely by accident. At the time, Lorenz and his team were trying to advance the use of computer models in weather prediction. They were getting somewhere, or so they thought, until the computer started spitting out contradictory results. Lorenz and his colleagues began with what they believed were exactly the same data and ran what they thought was exactly the same code; still, the program somehow forecast clear skies over Colorado in one run and a thunderstorm in the next.
After spending weeks double-checking their hardware and trying to debug their code, Lorenz and his team discovered that their data weren't exactly the same. The numbers had been rounded off in the third decimal place. Instead of having the barometric pressure in one corner of their grid read 29.5168, for example, it might instead read 29.517. This couldn't make that much of a difference, could it? Actually, Lorenz realized, it could, and he devoted the rest of his career to studying strange behaviors like these by developing a branch of mathematics called chaos theory, the most basic tenet of which is described in the title of his breakthrough 1972 paper, ''Predictability: Does the Flap of a Butterfly's Wings in Brazil Set Off a Tornado in Texas?'' In other words, a small change in initial conditions can produce a large and unexpected divergence in outcomes.
Chaos theory does not imply that the behavior of the system is literally random. It just means that certain types of systems are very hard to predict. If you know the exact conditions of a coin as it leaves someone's hand, you can -- with the right laboratory equipment -- predict, almost perfectly, which side it will land on. And yet the slightest disturbance to that motion can change a coin toss from being almost wholly predictable to almost wholly unpredictable.
The problem with weather is that our knowledge of its initial conditions is highly imperfect, both in theory and practice. A meteorologist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration told me that it wasn't unheard-of for a careless forecaster to send in a 50-degree reading as 500 degrees. The more fundamental issue, though, is that we can observe our surroundings with only a certain degree of precision. No thermometer is perfect, and it isn't physically possible to stick one into every molecule in the atmosphere.
Weather also has two additional properties that make forecasting even more difficult. First, weather is nonlinear, meaning that it abides by exponential rather than by arithmetic relationships. Second, it's dynamic -- its behavior at one point in time influences its behavior in the future. Imagine that we're supposed to be taking the sum of 5 and 5, but we keyed in the second number as 6 by mistake. That will give us an answer of 11 instead of 10. We'll be wrong, but not by much; addition, as a linear operation, is pretty forgiving. Exponential operations, however, extract a lot more punishment when there are inaccuracies in our data. If instead of taking 5^5 -- which should be 3,125 -- we instead take 5^6, we wind up with an answer of 15,625. This problem quickly compounds when the process is dynamic, because outputs at one stage of the process become our inputs in the next.
Given how daunting the challenge was, it must have been tempting to give up on the idea of building a dynamic weather model altogether. A thunderstorm might have remained roughly as unpredictable as an earthquake. But by embracing the uncertainty of the problem, their predictions started to make progress. ''What may have distinguished [me] from those that proceeded,'' Lorenz later reflected in ''The Essence of Chaos,'' his 1993 book, ''was the idea that chaos was something to be sought rather than avoided.''
Perhaps because chaos theory has been a part of meteorological thinking for nearly four decades, professional weather forecasters have become comfortable treating uncertainty the way a stock trader or poker player might. When weather.gov says that there's a 20 percent chance of rain in Central Park, it's because the National Weather Service recognizes that our capacity to measure and predict the weather is accurate only up to a point. ''The forecasters look at lots of different models: Euro, Canadian, our model -- there's models all over the place, and they don't tell the same story,'' Ben Kyger, a director of operations for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, told me. ''Which means they're all basically wrong.'' The National Weather Service forecasters who adjusted temperature gradients with their light pens were merely interpreting what was coming out of those models and making adjustments themselves. ''I've learned to live with it, and I know how to correct for it,'' Kyger said. ''My whole career might be based on how to interpret what it's telling me.''
Despite their astounding ability to crunch numbers in nanoseconds, there are still things that computers can't do, contends Hoke at the National Weather Service. They are especially bad at seeing the big picture when it comes to weather. They are also too literal, unable to recognize the pattern once it's subjected to even the slightest degree of manipulation. Supercomputers, for instance, aren't good at forecasting atmospheric details in the center of storms. One particular model, Hoke said, tends to forecast precipitation too far south by around 100 miles under certain weather conditions in the Eastern United States. So whenever forecasters see that situation, they know to forecast the precipitation farther north.
But there are literally countless other areas in which weather models fail in more subtle ways and rely on human correction. Perhaps the computer tends to be too conservative on forecasting nighttime rainfalls in Seattle when there's a low-pressure system in Puget Sound. Perhaps it doesn't know that the fog in Acadia National Park in Maine will clear up by sunrise if the wind is blowing in one direction but can linger until midmorning if it's coming from another. These are the sorts of distinctions that forecasters glean over time as they learn to work around potential flaws in the computer's forecasting model, in the way that a skilled pool player can adjust to the dead spots on the table at his local bar.
Among the National Weather Service's detailed records is a thorough comparison of how well the computers are doing by themselves alongside the value that humans are contributing. According to the agency's statistics, humans improve the accuracy of precipitation forecasts by about 25 percent over the computer guidance alone. They improve the temperature forecasts by about 10 percent. Humans are good enough, in fact, that when the organization's Cray supercomputer burned down, in 1999, their high-temperature forecasts remained remarkably accurate. ''You almost can't have a meeting without someone mentioning the glory days of the Cray fire,'' Kyger said, pointing to a mangled, half-burnt piece of the computer that was proudly displayed in the office where I met him. ''If you weren't here for that, you really weren't part of the brotherhood.''
Still, most people take their forecasts for granted. Like a baseball umpire, a weather forecaster rarely gets credit for getting the call right. Last summer, meteorologists at the National Hurricane Center were tipped off to something serious when nearly all their computer models indicated that a fierce storm was going to be climbing the Northeast Corridor. The eerily similar results between models helped the center amplify its warning for Hurricane Irene well before it touched down on the Atlantic shore, prompting thousands to evacuate their homes. To many, particularly in New York, Irene was viewed as a media-manufactured nonevent, but that was largely because the Hurricane Center nailed its forecast. Six years earlier, the National Weather Service also made a nearly perfect forecast of Hurricane Katrina, anticipating its exact landfall almost 60 hours in advance. If public officials hadn't bungled the evacuation of New Orleans, the death toll might have been remarkably low.
In a time when forecasters of all types make overconfident proclamations about political, economic or natural events, uncertainty is a tough sell. It's much easier to hawk overconfidence, no matter if it's any good. A long-term study of political forecasts conducted by Philip Tetlock, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, found that when political experts described an event as being absolutely certain, it failed to transpire an astonishing 25 percent of the time.
The Weather Service has struggled over the years with how much to let the public in on what it doesn't exactly know. In April 1997, Grand Forks, N.D., was threatened by the flooding Red River, which bisects the city. Snowfall had been especially heavy in the Great Plains that winter, and the service, anticipating runoff as the snow melted, predicted that the Red would crest to 49 feet, close to the record. Because the levees in Grand Forks were built to handle a flood of 52 feet, a small miss in the forecast could prove catastrophic. The margin of error on the Weather Service's forecast -- based on how well its flood forecasts had done in the past -- implied about a 35 percent chance of the levees' being topped.
The waters, in fact, crested to 54 feet. It was well within the forecast's margin of error, but enough to overcome the levees and spill more than two miles into the city. Cleanup costs ran into the billions of dollars, and more than 75 percent of the city's homes were damaged or destroyed. Unlike a hurricane or an earthquake, the Grand Forks flood may have been preventable. The city's flood walls could have been reinforced using sandbags. It might also have been possible to divert the overflow into depopulated areas. But the Weather Service had explicitly avoided communicating the uncertainty in its forecast to the public, emphasizing only the 49-foot prediction. The forecasters later told researchers that they were afraid the public might lose confidence in the forecast if they had conveyed any uncertainty.
Since then, the National Weather Service has come to recognize the importance of communicating the uncertainty in its forecasts as completely as possible. ''Uncertainty is the fundamental component of weather prediction,'' said Max Mayfield, an Air Force veteran who ran the National Hurricane Center when Katrina hit. ''No forecast is complete without some description of that uncertainty.'' Under Mayfield's guidance, the National Hurricane Center began to pay much more attention to how it presents its forecasts. Instead of just showing a single track line for a hurricane's predicted path, their charts prominently feature a cone of uncertainty, which many in the business call ''the cone of chaos.''
Unfortunately, this cautious message can be undercut by private-sector forecasters. Catering to the demands of viewers can mean intentionally running the risk of making forecasts less accurate. For many years, the Weather Channel avoided forecasting an exact 50 percent chance of rain, which might seem wishy-washy to consumers. Instead, it rounded up to 60 or down to 40. In what may be the worst-kept secret in the business, numerous commercial weather forecasts are also biased toward forecasting more precipitation than will actually occur. (In the business, this is known as the wet bias.) For years, when the Weather Channel said there was a 20 percent chance of rain, it actually rained only about 5 percent of the time.
People don't mind when a forecaster predicts rain and it turns out to be a nice day. But if it rains when it isn't supposed to, they curse the weatherman for ruining their picnic. ''If the forecast was objective, if it has zero bias in precipitation,'' Bruce Rose, a former vice president for the Weather Channel, said, ''we'd probably be in trouble.''
The National Weather Service, on the other hand, takes plenty of blame when its cautious forecasts seem retrospectively unwarranted. I was reminded of this when I arrived in Tampa for the Republican National Convention. The city was briefly in Hurricane Isaac's cone of chaos before the storm took a westward tack. The airport and roads were remarkably quiet, no doubt because some reporters and delegates (and thousands of tourists) heeded caution and stayed home. When I so much as mentioned the weather forecast, my taxi driver turned and launched into a series of obscenities.
This article is adapted from ''The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail -- but Some Don't,'' to be published this month by Penguin Press. Kevin Erskine is a professional pseudonym used by the Dutch photographer Erik Hijweege.
