HEADLINE: Striking Notes Timely and Timeless

 BODY:
SEPTEMBER
LE POÈME HARMONIQUE New Yorkers have done well in recent years to make the acquaintance of L'Arpeggiata, a Paris-based ensemble that combines the highest level of early-music artistry and imagination with shifting degrees of theatricality. Now another fine French-based early-music group, which likes additionally to perform by candlelight if not in total darkness, receives its most prominent New York exposure to date, opening the season of the Miller Theater at Columbia University. The program, ''Venezia,'' is predictably heavy on works by Monteverdi, less predictably so on works by Francesco Manelli. Then again, Le Poème, like L'Arpeggiata, seems to put little premium on predictability. Just keep an open mind, and revel in the unexpected. Wednesday, Friday. (James R. Oestreich) 
TWELVE IN '12 Though by now it has been reduced to Nine in '12. Julian Wachner's music program at Trinity Wall Street, which did spectacular service in the first half of last season, especially for the Sept. 11 anniversary commemorations, only to be suspended for much of the second half for a re-evaluation of finances and purpose, is back and seeking new challenges. Under Mr. Wachner the program has become a hotbed of early music, especially with the Trinity Choir's Bach at One series at St. Paul's Chapel (which resumes on Oct. 1). Now, expanding the activities of Trinity's instrumental ensemble Novus NY, Mr. Wachner plans to make contemporary music an equal partner. Here, in a series of hourlong midday concerts, he opens the Trinity season with works by Pulitzer Prize-winning composers of the last dozen years. The first program, scheduled for last Thursday, offered works of Steven Stucky, Zhou Long and Paul Moravec. This week's concert features Jennifer Higdon, David Lang and John Corigliano. Still to come are Kevin Puts, Yehudi Wyner, John Adams, Henry Brant, Steve Reich and Ornette Coleman. Thursday (also Sept. 20, 27). Trinity Church. (J.R.O.)
'EINSTEIN ON THE BEACH' There have been many great operas, but only a few have redefined the very meaning of the art form. Of that select group, Monteverdi's ''Orfeo'' and Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' receive regular performances, but Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's 1976 masterpiece, ''Einstein on the Beach,'' which stretched the bounds of duration and plotlessness, is more talked about than seen. That makes this revival of the original production, part of an international tour honoring Mr. Glass's 75th birthday, one of the season's crucial events. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. Opens Friday. (Zachary Woolfe)
'I DUE FOSCARI' The Los Angeles Opera has retrenched artistically in recent seasons, having taken a huge chance on Achim Freyer's ambitious, often brilliant production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle. This year the only divergence from the standard repertory is this rarely performed tale of political and personal intrigue in 15th-century Venice, which is being mounted for the company's general director, the tenor Plácido Domingo, as he takes another step on his controversial path through Verdi's baritone roles. He is joined by the tenor Francesco Meli and the soprano Marina Poplavskaya; James Conlon, the company's music director, conducts. Opens Saturday. Los Angeles Opera, Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, (213) 972-8001, laopera.com. (Z.W.)
NATE WOOLEY When this avant-garde trumpeter played part of his mesmerizing ''Seven Storey Mountain'' at Issue Project Room in June, he used a trumpet without a mouthpiece, amplifying it to create breathy, lightly pitched, sometimes squawking, sometimes almost spoken sounds that whispered over a dense shimmer of other instruments. He returns, again under the auspices of Issue Project Room, with another of the instrument's innovators, Mazen Kerbaj, for an evening of solos and duets. Sept. 19. Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral, 113 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, (718) 330-0313, issueprojectroom.org. (Z.W.)
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC Alan Gilbert and the orchestra have restructured the opening of their season so that it no longer begins with a gala concert, however frothy. (That happens on Sept. 27, with Itzhak Perlman playing morsels by Massenet and Kreisler, and Mr. Gilbert adding Respighi's ''Fountains of Rome'' and ''Pines of Rome.'') Instead the season opens with a substantial subscription program: Gyorgy Kurtag's ''... quasi una fantasia ...''; Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3, with Leif Ove Andsnes as soloist; and Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.'' You may run into ''The Rite'' a lot this season, in anticipation of the 100th anniversary of its scandalous premiere in May. (Gustavo Dudamel and the Los Angeles Philharmonic also open their subscription season with it on Sept. 28.) But in this case it may be as much a matter of Mr. Gilbert's wanting to continue honing his interpretation of a thorny classic that he also performed in March, with the Juilliard Orchestra. Sept. 19-22. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
COMPOSER PORTRAITS This invaluable series -- the centerpiece of the Miller Theater's programming, established by George Steel and carried through admirably by his success sor as director of the theater, Melissa Smey, with, bless her, a greater concentration on women -- has generally featured living composers. But it starts this year with a nod to the centenary of John Cage: a program of Cage (and Pierre Boulez's ''Marteau Sans Maître'') with Steven Schick conducting the International Contemporary Ensemble. Other composers featured this season at the Miller are Jonathan Harvey, Olga Neuwirth, Sofia Gubaidulina, Enno Poppe, Rebecca Saunders, Oliver Knussen and Julio Estrada. The Composer Portraits series also goes on the road, to the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, with programs devoted to Fred Lerdahl (Oct. 18) and Ms. Gubaidulina (March 21; a somewhat different program). Sept. 20. Miller Theater. (J.R.O.)
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM The Met concert series, long a bastion of traditional classical music programming, sports a new face, as Limor Tomer, its new general manager, presents her first full season of programs. Here the Wordless Music orchestra joins the Danish art-rock group Efterklang in songs from that band's new album, ''Piramida.'' Page 33. Sept. 22. (J.R.O.)
BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Nothing is easy for this ensemble as it searches for a music director to succeed James Levine, who resigned in 2011. Last September the prime candidates seemed to be Riccardo Chailly and Andris Nelsons, and both were well represented in that season's programming. But Mr. Chailly had to cancel because of a heart arrhythmia; Mr. Nelsons, because of the birth of his child. Mr. Chailly must surely be out of the running now, the orchestra having struggled through no end of health crises with Mr. Levine. Mr. Nelsons, who caught up with the orchestra at Tanglewood this summer and is scheduled to appear in Boston this season (Jan. 31; Feb. 1-2, 5), still seems to be a front-runner, though he just extended his contract as music director of the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in England through the 2014-15 season. Other names currently circulating include those of Vladimir Jurowski, who makes his Boston Symphony debut in October (11-13), and -- a dark horse -- Esa-Pekka Salonen, who is not scheduled to conduct the Boston Symphony this season. The season opens here with Itzhak Perlman conducting a program of Beethoven in which he also performs the two violin romances. It seems safe to say that he harbors no ambitions to become the orchestra's music director. Sept. 22. Symphony Hall, (617) 266-1200 or (888) 266-1200, bso.org. (J.R.O.)
'L'ELISIR D'AMORE' How can you tell that a singer and a composer are riding high at the Metropolitan Opera? When they are given two opening nights in a row. The star soprano Anna Netrebko, who opened the last season in the title role of ''Anna Bolena,'' takes on another Donizetti opera -- though not ''Maria Stuarda,'' the follow-up to ''Bolena,'' as Peter Gelb, the Met's general manager originally hoped. (That vehicle falls to the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato on New Year's Eve.) Instead Ms. Netrebko plays Adina in a new production of the classic comedy ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' which combines ample laughs with threads of melancholy and touching emotion. The tenor Matthew Polenzani plays the love-struck Nemorino; the charismatic baritone Mariusz Kwiecien is Sergeant Belcore, his rival for Adina's affections; and the bass Ambrogio Maestri (and later in the run, the winning Erwin Schrott) sings Dr. Dulcamara, the lovable quack who dispenses the supposed elixir of love. Bartlett Sher, whose Met productions can teeter between spirited and frenetic, directs; Maurizio Benini conducts the burbling, effortlessly charming score. Opens Sept. 24. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER The great joy of the society's concerts is the interaction of up-and-coming musicians with established ones: a violinist like Benjamin Beilman, say, on the cusp of a major career, and the veteran flutist Ransom Wilson. Those two, along with a host of colleagues, will play an opening program of serenades by Mozart, Kodaly, Strauss and Dvorak, the introduction to a season that reaches from Bach's keyboard concertos (played by Jeremy Denk as part of the annual Baroque Festival in December) by way of 19th-century classics to the complete Shostakovich string quartets in March. Sept. 24. Alice Tully Hall. (Z.W.)
'DOG DAYS' David T. Little, a percussionist with a composerly predilection for the theater, presents an example, ''Dog Days,'' as part of the Peak Performances series at Montclair State University (with another, ''Soldier Songs,'' to follow from Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now in January). Page 35. Opens Sept 29. Kasser Theater, Montclair, N.J., (973) 655-5112, peakperfs.org. (J.R.O.)
GREEN MUSIC CENTER If ever there was a concert hall worth emulating, it is the Musikverein in Vienna, and the designers of Seiji Ozawa Hall at Tanglewood studied it well. If ever there was an indoor-outdoor concert hall worth emulating, it is Ozawa Hall, and those same designers -- notably the architect, William Rawn and the acoustician Lawrence Kirkegaard -- were recruited to do likewise with a 1,400-seat hall on the campus of Sonoma State University. An infusion of funds from Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of the board of Carnegie Hall, and his wife, Joan Weill, gave it a name, Weill Hall. (So is it Tanglewood West or Carnegie West?) The opening weekend includes a recital by the pianist Lang Lang and a concert by the Santa Rosa Symphony, conducted by its music director, Bruno Ferrandis, and others. Sept. 29-30. Green Music Center, Rohnert Park, Calif., (866) 955-6040, gmc.sonoma.edu. (J.R.O.)
'THE RITE OF SPRING' AT 100 This season-long festival gets a jump on the centennial of the masterpiece that not only defined Stravinsky's career -- more in subsequent performances than in its tempestuous premiere on May 29, 1913 -- but also set the course for much of 20th-century music, on into the 21st. The celebration opens here with ''The Seasons,'' by Dmitri Yanov-Yanovsky commissioned for the occasion and performed by the cellist Y0-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble. Mr. Yanov-Yanovsky adapts folk tunes used by Stravinsky in ''The Rite.'' Later events include multiple staged interpretations of the work, notably the Joffrey Ballet's attempt at a ''literal re-creation'' of the original choreography (March 23-24) and a new Basil Twist rendering with puppets (April 12-13). Valery Gergiev conducts the Mariinsky Orchestra in two concerts, the second culminating in ''The Rite'' (Oct. 29-30, after a scholarly conference on ''Reassessing 'The Rite,''' Oct. 25-28), and Giancarlo Guerrero leads the Cleveland Orchestra in a program featuring Stravinsky's ''Petrouchka'' (March 17). Actually, the festival isn't quite season-long, ending in late April, before the actual anniversary. Sept. 30-Oct. 1. Carolina Performing Arts, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, (919) 843-3333. theriteofspringat100.org. (J.R.O.)
OCTOBER
'THE PRISMATIC DEBUSSY' New York City's major cultural institutions have largely ignored the 150th anniversary of the birth of Debussy, so the Eastman School of Music is picking up the slack with a series of concerts exploring his multifaceted output, held in conjunction with lectures, films and exhibitions. Oct. 1-27. Eastman School of Music, Rochester, (585) 274-1100, esm.rochester.edu/debussy. (Z.W.)
CECILIA BARTOLI ''Steffani's star isn't in the ascendant,'' says the heroine (a musicologist!) of the Venice-based mystery writer Donna Leon's novel ''The Jewels of Paradise,'' to be published by Atlantic Monthly Press in October. Well, the star of Agostino Steffani -- ''composer and bishop, musician and diplomat,'' in Ms. Leon's words -- may soon rise, at least by a blip. As EMI Classics tries to ride the coattails of E.L. James's steamy potboiler ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' with an album of works mentioned in the book (there will be no quotations from that book here, nor any endorsement of that recording), Decca takes a more imaginative approach to a publishing tie-in with Ms. Bartoli's latest project, ''Mission,'' a two-disc set of arias and other works by Steffani. Ms. Leon and Ms. Bartoli are said to be friends, and they evidently shared scholarly groundwork in conjuring Steffani's personage and reviving his music. Ms. Leon's protagonist, hired to sort through newly discovered documents left behind by Steffani, recalls tunes of his that she has heard: ''What was that heartbreaking lament, something about 'Dal mio petto'?'' And Ms. Bartoli sings a good many of them, including that one, from the opera ''Niobe.'' As with her previous album ''Sacrificium: The Art of the Castrati,'' Ms. Bartoli strikes an androgynous pose, this time as a bald-pated, crucifix-clutching (and per Ms. Leon, castrated?) Steffani for the cover art. Oct. 2. Decca. (J.R.O.)
CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA This year the great Chicagoans fill the coveted spot opening the Carnegie Hall season. It is the start of the orchestra's third year under the music director Riccardo Muti, who has had the ensemble playing with characteristic sheen and power through the eclectic programs he favors. The three-night stand at Carnegie veers from Orff's ''Carmina Burana'' on opening night -- no one is better than Mr. Muti at ratcheting up the drama in vocal and choral works -- to music of Wagner, Franck, Dvorak, Martucci, Respighi and the young composer-D.J. Mason Bates. Oct 3-5. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
TWOSENSE All-stars from the All-Stars. The brilliant and searching Lisa Moore was the founding pianist of the Bang on a Can All-Stars, a position she held until 2008, and Ashley Bathgate is the group's current cellist. The two came together in 2010 as a commissioning and performing duo devoted to pairing new works and the classics. This program features premieres by Ryan Brown, Daniel Felsenfeld and Hannah Lash. Oct. 4. Roulette, Brooklyn, (917) 267-0363, roulette.org. (Z.W.)
EMANUEL AX As artist in residence with the New York Philharmonic this season, the beloved pianist makes a move many of us have long been waiting for, taking up music of Bach in concert: here, the Keyboard Concerto in D minor (BWV 1052). In addition, he shows his marvelous versatility by working on an opposite fringe of the standard repertory, with Schoenberg's Piano Concerto. Alan Gilbert conducts the program, which also includes Mozart's ''Linz'' Sympony. Oct. 4-6. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
MINSOO SOHN The Honens International Piano Competition in Calgary, Alberta, which has developed a better track record than most, has been trying to beef up its international presence in recent years. In April, it held quarterfinals in New York for this year's competition, which concludes in Calgary in October. It has also started a record label to feature its winners, and Mr. Sohn, the 2006 prize laureate, made a big impression with a release of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations,'' which he now brings to New York along with variations by Brahms and Webern. Page 35. Oct 6. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
'LA FINTA GIARDINIERA' René Jacobs's recordings of Mozart's operas bring back some of the thrill that must have attended these works when they were new; his ''Nozze di Figaro,'' in particular, truly does make you hear that work as if for the first time. (Who knew that that critical commonplace could ever be deserved?) ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' one of Mozart's earliest operas, has long hovered in semiobscurity -- not a true rarity but not often performed, either -- despite its gorgeous music and acute libretto. Mr. Jacobs and the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra are sure to locate both its uproarious farce and its core of melancholy. The only downside of a new installment in the series is that it gets that much closer to coming to an end. Oct. 9. Harmonia Mundi. (Z.W.)
GREAT MUSIC IN A GREAT SPACE The conductor and organist Kent Tritle, best known for Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, the acclaimed, longstanding series he founded at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, revived a similarly named series presented in earlier years at St. John the Divine, when he moved there during the last season. Here he conducts the Cathedral Choir and Orchestra in Bach's certifiably great Mass in B minor. Oct. 10. Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, (866) 811-4111, stjohndivine.org. (J.R.O)
RENÉE ANNE LOUPRETTE This excellent organist, who like Kent Tritle left her position at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola and is now at Trinity Wall Street, inaugurates another new feature in Trinity's suddenly resurgent music program: Pipes at One, a series of 40-minute midday organ recitals (by her and others) on the beautifully restored Schlicker organ at St. Paul's Chapel. No repertory has been announced yet; trust Ms. Louprette to make it worth your while. Oct. 3. (J.R.O.)
'MOBY-DICK' The first products of the David Gockley leadership at the San Francisco Opera, which began in 2006, showed little of the enterprise that characterized Mr. Gockley's 33 years at the Houston Grand Opera. But this season represents something of a breakthrough for Mr. Gockley and the company. Jake Heggie's adaptation of ''Moby-Dick,'' Herman Melville's masterpiece, had its premiere at the Dallas Opera in 2010 and is the first of three operas by living American composers being presented. (Nolan Gasser's family-friendly ''Secret Garden'' has its premiere on March 1, and Mark Adamo's ''Gospel of Mary Magdalene'' opens on June 19.) These are not the most adventurous composers working in opera today, but taken together their works add up to a considerable and refreshing commitment to the art form's present and future. Opens Oct. 10. War Memorial Opera House, (413) 864-3330, sfopera.com. (Z.W.)
NIELSEN PROJECT One of Alan Gilbert's marquee initiatives as he gets deeper into his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic is a series of concerts and recordings over a number of years exploring the six symphonies and three concertos of the underappreciated Danish composer Carl Nielsen. Having spent time with some of the symphonies, Mr. Gilbert turns his attention this season to the concertos for flute (with the orchestra's principal, Robert Langevin) and violin (with the guest soloist Nikolaj Znaider) in a program with Tchaikovsky's grand Second Symphony, the ''Little Russian.'' Oct. 10-13. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA Some of us recall the founding of this conductorless ensemble as if it were yesterday and still sort of wonder (despite the continuing success of the 62-year-old Prague Chamber Orchestra, among other conductor-free groups) whether the noble experiment will succeed. Well don't look now, but Orpheus, having recorded more than 70 albums, celebrates its 40th anniversary this season. Evidently it is here to stay. Its first program offers Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri'' Overture; ''Earth Echoes,'' a song cycle by Augusta Read Thomas, sung by the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke and the baritone Nathan Gunn; and Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, which the orchestra has performed numerous ... er, never. It's a great piece, Orpheus; you'll love it. Carnegie Hall. Oct. 11. (J.R.O.)
'WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE' There will be a bittersweet quality to this new production of Oliver Knussen's captivating opera based on the beloved, bracing children's book by Maurice Sendak, who died in May. Brilliantly juxtaposed with Ravel's ''Mother Goose,'' it is being presented as part of the Los Angeles Philharmonic's sweeping commitment to new and recent opera under its music director, Gustavo Dudamel, who conducts a cast that includes Claire Booth and Susan Bickley. The production is by the British director and video artist Netia Jones, who will conjure up animations based on Sendak's classic illustrations. (Ms. Jones is well practiced in Mr. Knussen's take on Sendak, having created a version of the operatic ''Higglety Pigglety Pop'' this summer at the Tanglewood Festival in Massachusetts.) Oct. 11-14. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com. (Z.W.)
YANNICK NÉZET-SÉGUIN Finally! Four years after the departure of Christoph Eschenbach as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra and two years after it was announced that Mr. Nézet-Séguin (whom, for obvious reasons, the orchestra has been marketing on a first-name basis) would succeed him, the once fabulous Philadelphians again have a music director. Happily, they had expert musical guidance in the interim from an eminently capable and devoted principal conductor, Charles Dutoit, who maintained a high level of artistic achievement as administrative chaos swirled around him. (That included a period without music director, executive director or board chairman, and a 2011 filing for bankruptcy protection, from which the orchestra emerged in late July.) The delay, it turns out, had a good, or at least opportune, side, allowing the orchestra now to cloak Mr. Nézet-Séguin in the mantle of messiah, since it was just 100 years ago that Leopold Stokowski, who had a huge formative influence on the orchestra, arrived. Let the comparisons begin, in a gala concert featuring the soprano Renée Fleming and anchored by Brahms's Fourth Symphony. Oct. 18. Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, Philadelphia, (215) 893-1999, philorch.org. (J.R.O.)
MINNESOTA ORCHESTRA It has been a tough time financially for American orchestras, and several of them had yet to negotiate new contracts with the players by press time (others including the Cleveland Orchestra, the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra). In addition, the Minnesota Orchestra faces a season of wandering as its Orchestra Hall is being renovated. (New Yorkers can only envy the resolve: what would a year or two of imaginative wandering by the Philharmonic matter if we could solve the Avery Fisher Hall Problem once and for all?) Osmo Vanska has worked artistic wonders as the orchestra's music director, and he can probably be counted on to steer it through these extracurricular shoals as well. He opens the season with a program of Elgar, Rachmaninoff (Piano Concerto No. 3, with Garrick Ohlsson as soloist) and Respighi at the orchestra's temporary home. Oct. 18-20. Auditorium at the Convention Center, Minnesota, (612) 371-5656, minnesotaorchestra.org. (J.R.O.)
WORLD ORCHESTRA FOR PEACE This international assemblage of star players, founded in 1995 by the conductor Georg Solti and conducted here by Valery Gergiev, who is widely active in New York over the next two weeks, celebrates the Solti centennial. The program includes excerpts of operas by Mozart and Verdi, with the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the bass René Pape, Strauss's ''Don Juan'' and Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra (which Solti conducted with a particular, Hungarian flair). Oct. 19. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
LES ARTS FLORISSANTS Before this peerless Baroque-music ensemble and its director, William Christie, bring their production of Marc-Antoine Charpentier's ''David et Jonathas'' to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in mid-April, they offer a teaser of sorts with rare performances of three of Charpentier's impassioned sacred motets. A week later members of the group join the terrific student ensemble Juilliard415 for Handel's glorious oratorio ''Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno'' (''The Triumph of Time and Truth''). Alice Tully Hall. Oct. 19, 27. (Z.W.)
'GLASS AT 75' As we said, no end of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' this season: here the four-hand piano version, played by Maki Namekawa and Dennis Russell Davies, and given historical context between works by Debussy -- ''En Blanc et Noir,'' actually composed two years after ''The Rite,'' in 1915 -- and Philip Glass, the ostensible subject of the program. Oct. 21. Morgan Library & Museum, 225 Madison Avenue, (212) 685-0008, ext. 560, themorgan.org. (J.R.O.)
NEW YORK FESTIVAL OF SONG Celebrating its 25th anniversary, this worthy enterprise opens its season with a program timed with an eye toward the election, ''Mr. Gershwin Goes to Washington.'' It's actually Mr. Gershwins, plural: an evening of satire drawn from George and Ira Gershwin's songs about politics, directed and adapted by Laurence Maslon. The featured artists are the sopranos Anne-Carolyn Bird and Lauren Worsham and the pianists Steven Blier, the festival's artistic director, and Joseph Thalken. A tease in the season announcement promises that ''a distinguished member of the political news media will be the surprise guest narrator.'' We're all a-twit. (And so as not to spoil the surprise when the program itself goes to Washington a couple of days later, the narrator there will be different.) Oct. 20. Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan. Oct. 22. Terrace Theater, Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, (212) 501-3330, nyfos.org. (J.R.O.)
LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Here is Valery Gergiev again, with one of his own orchestras. The London Symphony is making much of the the 100th anniversary of its first North American appearance, claiming that it was ''the first European orchestra to visit the United States and Canada.'' (It was originally booked for the fateful maiden voyage of the Titanic, whose delay forced the players to board a smaller ship; they were already in St. Louis when they learned of the disaster.) Not that the programming particularly reflects the occasion. It is all Brahms: the Symphonies Nos. 2 and 4, the Violin Concerto (with James Ehnes as soloist), the Piano Concerto No. 1 (with Denis Matsuev) and the ''Tragic Overture.'' It might all seem more special if Kurt Masur were not scheduled to conduct two weeks of Brahms (Symphonies Nos. 2-4, Double Concerto) with the New York Philharmonic in the same hall in early November. (Whether an increasingly frail Mr. Masur can endure all of that is another matter.) Oct. 22, 24. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'THE TEMPEST' New York is kept mostly up-to-date with the orchestral and solo piano music of the mercurial English composer Thomas Adès, but his masterly 2004 Shakespeare adaptation, one of the most praised operas of the 21st century, is just now receiving its New York premiere. It is one of the vanishingly few contemporary operas to receive the Metropolitan Opera's imprimatur, and the company is giving it a brilliant, mostly young cast. Mr. Adès conducts. The only element to give pause is the director, Robert Lepage, whose production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle was roundly dismissed by critics. Whether he can return to his roots as a darling of the theatrical avant-garde may be the biggest question of the Met season. Page 33. Opens Oct. 23. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA The brilliant young conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin has so far been best known in New York for his opera performances: memorably galvanic takes on Bizet's ''Carmen'' and Gounod's ''Faust'' at the Metropolitan Opera. For his first Carnegie Hall appearance as music director of the marvelous Philadelphians, he works to his dramatic strengths, offering Verdi's operatic-scale, hellfire-breathing Requiem, with the orchestra joined by the Westminster Symphonic Choir. The soloists are the only real difficulty, since two of the four -- the febrile soprano Marina Poplavskaya and the often ailing tenor Rolando Villazón -- have a way of polarizing opera fans. But this is Mr. Nézet-Séguin's chance to shine and, perhaps, to fuel speculation that he eventually may be a candidate to replace James Levine as the Met's music director. Oct. 23. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
WHITE LIGHT FESTIVAL When this festival began in 2010 as an exploration of transcendence, it seemed more a personal statement by its creator, Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, than any particular sign of the times. But with themes of spirituality having recently taken hold at festivals in Salzburg, Austria, and Lucerne, Switzerland, and elsewhere, Ms. Moss seems to have caught the beginnings of an international wave, to whatever extent she did not herself set it in motion. The festival opens with a free program, ''Without Shadows,'' featuring Kiran Ahluwalia, a Punjabi vocalist, with Indian percussion and contemporary instruments. Oct. 23. David Rubinstein Atrium. (J.R.O.)
ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA Flexibility is a rare commodity in the programming of major orchestras and concert halls, especially when international appearances are involved. Planning is done far in advance, and there are too many moving parts to allow much change. But the Israel Philharmonic and Zubin Mehta, its music director for life, who made a strong showing in the Salzburg Festival's Spiritual Overture in July with two programs based mostly in Judaism, decided to build quickly on that success. They set aside the big pieces originally scheduled for this appearance (Hindemith's ''Mathis der Maler'' and Brahms's First Symphony) and replaced them with works from their first festival concert: Schoenberg's ''Kol Nidre'' and Noam Sheriff's ''Mechaye Hametim'' (''Revival of the Dead''), a Holocaust remembrance. Both are choral works, and the switch was doable because the chorus used in Salzburg was the Collegiate Chorale of New York, and the baritone Thomas Hampson was available (or made himself available) to reprise his roles. The flexibility could not be complete, since the orchestra had a commitment to another soloist, the young pianist Yuja Wang, and few will object to hearing her perform Mendelssohn's First Piano Concerto. But the cost is Mr. Hampson's searing interpretation of Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder'' (''Songs on the Death of Children''), which, though composed as a personal statement 40 years before the Holocaust, made for a better thematic fit. Oct. 25. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
GABRIEL KAHANE An emblem of a generation of composers who work eagerly and beautifully in multiple genres, Mr. Kahane is a noted composer of pop music, concert works and musical theater. (His ''February House'' recently completed a run at the Public Theater.) In ''Don't Even Listen'' he is joined by the vocalist Shara Worden and the young string quartet Brooklyn Rider for a program that encompasses works old and new, including a premiere (''The Fiction Issue'') and songs by Cee Lo Green, Schubert, Schumann, Sufjan Stevens and Mr. Kahane himself. Oct. 25. Zankel Hall. (Z.W.)
'OUT COLD'/'ZIPPO SONGS' Bigger, in the arts, is not lately better. With more and more music, dance and theater conceived on a chamber scale, it is only natural to want smaller spaces for them. This season the Brooklyn Academy of Music unveils its new Richard B. Fisher Building, designed for performances more intimate than those in its older theaters. One of the early offerings is this program of two song cycles by Phil Kline, best known for his widely performed, ambulatory piece for the winter holidays, ''Unsilent Night,'' in which both audience and recorded sound source travel around. ''Zippo Songs'' (2003), with texts from lines inscribed on the sides of Zippo lighters by American G.I.'s in Vietnam, will be heard in a new arrangement for string quintet, piano and percussion, and the new ''Out Cold'' has Schubert's ''Winterreise'' meet some of Frank Sinatra's wintriest recordings for a reflection on introversion and isolation. The longtime Kline collaborator Theo Bleckmann sings alongside the well-regarded American Contemporary Music Ensemble in stagings directed by Emma Griffin. Oct. 25-27. BAM Fisher. (Z.W.)
BRITTEN CENTENNIAL Few enjoy the rote attention that composers tend to get paid in major anniversary years, but the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center seems sincere in its season-long tribute to Benjamin Britten, who was born a century ago, in 1913, and whose chamber music is among the most distinguished parts of his wide-ranging output. In three fascinating programs the Escher String Quartet juxtaposes Britten's quartets with a variety of repertory: first with the Baroque and Beethoven, then with fellow British composers and finally with other quartets composed during and after World War II. A final concert featuring various artists offers a rich selection of Britten's music, including the adorable ''Insect Pieces'' for oboe and piano; the sublime mini-opera canticle ''Abraham and Isaac,'' featuring the countertenor Daniel Taylor and the tenor Anthony Dean Griffey; and the eloquent Cello Sonata, with David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, the society's artistic directors. There are few gifts to the city this year as sweet as the immersion in this music that the society is offering. Oct. 25, Feb. 28, May 2. Rose Studio. May 10. Alice Tully Hall. (Z.W.)
AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA The Philadelphia Orchestra is not the only ensemble celebrating a Stokowski legacy this season. The maestro founded the American Symphony to perform at Carnegie Hall in 1962, after the New York Philharmonic had decamped for Lincoln Center. Now the American Symphony, which returned to Carnegie after a long absence in 2010, is celebrating its 50th anniversary with an outsize concert conducted by its music director of the last two decades, the intrepid Leon Botstein. It opens with the first work Stokowski performed with the ensemble, his own arrangement of ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' and also includes Ives's Fourth Symphony, whose premiere Stokowski and the orchestra presented in 1965, 11 years after Ives's death. The program, also featuring the Collegiate Chorale, is filled out with Mahler's gargantuan ''Symphony of a Thousand,'' typically given as a concert in itself. True the symphonies add up to only 90 minutes in time, but in weight? For this concert, ticket prices are being rolled back to 1962 levels, from $1.50 to $7, and no question, it's a lot of bang for your buck-fifty. Oct. 26. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
MARLIS PETERSEN For her New York recital debut this coolly intelligent soprano, best known to New York audiences for stepping in for Natalie Dessay in a new production of Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet'' in 2010, brings a program focused on Goethe's concept of the eternal feminine. The music ranges from the core of classic lieder -- Beethoven, Schubert, Wolf, Schumann -- to 20th-century masters like Hanns Eisler and Walter Braunfels. She is joined by the pianist Jendrik Springer. Oct. 26. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
DJ SPOOKY And here is the personification of the new concert programming at the Metropolitan Museum: Paul D. Miller, a k a DJ Spooky, That Subliminal Kid, an artist in residence for the season. Here he presents a screening of the 1956 film ''Madame Freedom'' with a rescoring for string quartet. Page 33. Oct. 26. Metropolitan Museum. (J.R.O.)
ANDRAS SCHIFF With this pianist playing Bach, you almost needn't say more. Whereas other pianists perform Bach, some of them magnificently, Mr. Schiff seems to embody him, so thoroughly has he internalized the music and so freely does he let it unfold. Here, beginning a two-season comprehensive Bach Project in various New York halls, he plays ''The Well-Tempered Clavier,'' Books 1 and 2. Page 35. 92nd Street Y. Oct. 27, Nov. 1. (J.R.O.)
ANGELA HEWITT Bachians may think they had died and gone to heaven. To tide them over between Mr. Schiff's ''Well-Tempered'' recitals, Ms. Hewitt, one of those pianists who perform Bach's music magnificently, offers the ''Goldberg'' Variations, and you can listen with beer in hand: in H.L. Mencken's words, Bach's ''natural solvent.'' Page 35. Oct. 28. Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 505-3474, lprnyc.com. (J.R.O.)
ELGAR, CARTER CELLO CONCERTOS Jacqueline du Pré's recording of the Elgar Cello Concerto with her husband, Daniel Barenboim, wasn't her best take on her signature work; that honor goes to the album she made with John Barbirolli. But her collaboration with Mr. Barenboim remains a potent mixture of the personal and the artistic. So it is major news indeed that Mr. Barenboim has now made another recording of the grand, lyrical work, 25 years after du Pré's untimely death, and with another female cellist: the richly gifted Alisa Weilerstein. The orchestra is the Berlin Staatskapelle, and the Elgar is intriguingly paired with another grand cello concerto, Elliott Carter's shivering, heaving, bursting addition to the repertory, from 2000. Oct. 30. Decca. (Z.W.)
MARIINSKY ORCHESTRA And here is Valery Gergiev again, with his other orchestra, fresh from presenting two concerts at the Carolina Performing Arts festival The Rite of Spring at 100, where they performed the title work. No Stravinsky here: Mr. Gergiev and his St. Petersburg troops offer a suite from Rodion Shchedrin's ''Little Humpbacked Horse,'' Shostakovich's Symphony No. 6 and Strauss's ''Heldenleben.'' Oct. 31. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)

'UN BALLO IN MASCHERA' The director David Alden, whose politically charged, vividly theatrical productions have been praised and debated since the 1980s, worked briefly at the Met early in his career, refurbishing productions of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' and Berg's ''Wozzeck.'' But he makes his real company debut with this seething Verdi work about betrayal at a royal court. It was set to star the soprano Karita Mattila, but she pulled out in May, after deciding that the role no longer fitted her voice, and was replaced by Sondra Radvanovsky, a stalwart of the Met's Verdi wing. Marcelo Álvarez, Dmitri Hvorostovsky and Kathleen Kim also star, and the cast is rounded out by the veteran Dolora Zajick as Ulrica. Fabio Luisi conducts. Opens Nov. 8. Metropolitan Opera House. VOX FESTIVAL One of the New York City Opera's signature offerings, this laboratory for full-orchestra readings of excerpts from contemporary American operas has been constricted to just six works on a single day, but it continues nevertheless. CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA These days the orchestra tends to alternate in New York between making big statements -- as with its Bruckner symphonies at the Lincoln Center Festival last year and its concert performance of Strauss's opera ''Salome'' at Carnegie Hall in May -- and slipping in and out relatively modestly. Here it sets down on the way to one of its regular Miami residencies, with Franz Welser-Möst, its music director, conducting works by Beethoven (Symphony No. 4, ''Grosse Fuge''), Matthias Pintscher (''Chute d'Étoiles,'' in its New York premiere) and Scriabin (''Poem of Ecstasy''). Mr. Welser-Möst reserves his big New York statement this season for the Vienna Philhamonic's Carnegie weekend in March. Nov. 13. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
BERNARDA FINK For date night with a sophisticated singing fan, look no further: there are few artists more eloquent and elegant than this Argentine mezzo-soprano, who will sing some of Dvorak's ''Biblical Songs,'' which are included on her astonishingly lovely, spirited recent recording of that composer's songs and duets on Harmonia Mundi. PHILHARMONIA ORCHESTRA In 2009 Esa-Pekka Salonen ended his transformative run as the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic to, he said, concentrate on composing. If anyone can find the sensuality and drama of Berg's pathbreaking score, it is Mr. Salonen. Nov. 18-19. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)

'THE PEONY PAVILION' The latest changes in the Met Museum's concert programming stem largely from a desire to tie it more closely to exhibitions, as with this staging of the 16th-century Chinese opera, presented in connection with the exhibition ''Chinese Gardens: Palace Pavilions, Scholars' Studios, Rustic Retreats.'' Conceived for presentation in a garden in Shanghai, the production will be staged in the small Astor Court and relayed live from there in high definition to the overflow audience in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. Tan Dun, the director, has shaved some 18 hours off the opera -- as presented in all its glory in the stunning production by Chen Shi-Zheng at the Lincoln Center Festival in 1999, and elsewhere in the years following -- bringing it down to a mere 70 minutes, while presumably retaining a goodly measure of that glory. Metropolitan Museum. Nov. 30. (J.R.O.)

OLGA NEUWIRTH This Austrian composer may be part of Melissa Smey's campaign to bring more women into the fold of the Miller Theater's Composer Portraits series, as here. Ms. Neuwirth can do big and brash and bold with the best of them. Page 35. Dec. 6. Miller Theater. (J.R.O.)
SIMÓN BOLÍVAR ORCHESTRA OF VENEZUELA El Sistema, Venezuela's storied music education system, has many success stories but none quite as astonishing as that of the conductor Gustavo Dudamel, who rocketed through the program to stardom and the music directorship of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. He has brought to prominence with him the youthful Bolívar ensemble, whose two-night stand is part of Carnegie Hall's Voices of Latin America festival. The repertory, including works by composers like Silvestre Revueltas, Esteban Benzecry and Heitor Villa-Lobos, is almost never done here, and it is sure to be galvanizing: few conductors draw visceral excitement out of an orchestra -- especially these young charges -- the way Mr. Dudamel does. Dec. 10-11. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
'MESSIAH' There are so many excellent New York performances of this great Handel oratorio at Christmastime that it is impossible to predict which will be best over all, whatever that may mean. But John Scott's is sure to rank high among the contenders, and it is typically the most lovable, with the superbly trained St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys holding forth in festive red cassocks before the church's intricately sculptured altarpiece. (The ailing pipe organ is another story, with pleas for contributions sure to be stuffed into the program.) James Richman's Concert Royal, on period instruments, fills out a sound worthy of the magnificent space. Dec. 11, 13. St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 664-9360, saintthomaschurch.org. (In other notable performances of ''Messiah,'' Julian Wachner conducts the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at Trinity Church on Dec. 9 and at Alice Tully Hall on Dec. 12; Kent Tritle conducts the amateur Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 17 and the professional Musica Sacra, also at Carnegie, on Dec. 20 and 22; and Emmanuelle Haïm conducts the New York Choral Artists and the New York Philharmonic from Dec. 18 to Dec. 22.) (J.R.O.)
'LES TROYENS' James Levine, the Met's ailing music director, has long been a champion of Berlioz's sprawling, shining masterpiece, so his absence from the podium for this revival of Francesca Zambello's production is particularly painful. Fabio Luisi will replace him, leading a cast that includes the deeply sympathetic mezzo-soprano Susan Graham as the spurned queen Dido, the tenor Marcello Giordani in the high-reaching role of Aeneas and Deborah Voigt, fresh from trying out the epic Brünnhilde in Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, as the desperate prophetess Cassandra. But one of the vocal pleasures may be in a minor role: the excellent bass Kwangchul Youn as Narbal. Opens Dec. 13. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)

'MARIA STUARDA' Another New Year's Eve, another starring role for the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato at the Met. Last year Ms. DiDonato led a sterling cast in the Baroque pastiche ''The Enchanted Island.'' Now she takes on the diva role of the embittered Mary Stuart in Donizetti's riveting melodrama, part of that composer's trilogy of operas based, however loosely, on the lives of Tudor queens. The Met's general manager, Peter Gelb, had originally intended for all three of the operas to be directed by David McVicar and to star the soprano Anna Netrebko; Mr. McVicar is still on for ''Maria Stuarda'' and the third, ''Roberto Devereux,'' next season, but Ms. Netrebko decided that ''Anna Bolena'' was it for her, clearing the way for Ms. DiDonato. 'RIGOLETTO' This one might cause a ruckus. For his Metropolitan Opera debut, the director Michael Mayer (Broadway's ''Thoroughly Modern Millie'' and ''Spring Awakening'') places Verdi's great opera in Rat Pack-era Las Vegas, with a set by Christine Jones and the Duke cast as a sleazy Sinatra-type entertainer. Met audiences have tended to be doubtful about such updatings, but the previous production, from 1989, never inspired much affection, and if anyone can sell a difficult concept it is the excellent opening-night cast: the soprano Diana Damrau, the tenor Piotr Beczala and the baritone Zeljko Lucic. OPERA LAFAYETTE Sometimes this intrepid company's wanderings through the thickets of the French operatic repertory can yield great pleasures, and sometimes they remind you that there are reasons obscurities are obscure. Ah, but life's a crap shoot like that. Will ''Lalla Roukh,'' an Orientalist fantasia by Félicien David that wowed the Opéra Comique in 1862, hold up today as any more than a curiosity? We shall see. In any case, Ryan Brown's conducting is always spirited, and the production, by Bernard Deletré, incorporates the acclaimed Indian-dance troupe Kalanidhi Dance. Jan. 31. Rose Theater. (Z.W.)
FEBRUARY
OSVALDO GOLIJOV Mr. Golijov is Carnegie Hall's composer in residence this season, and a concert in its Making Music series, which offers commentary from composers as well as their music, could offer fascinating insights if the right questions are asked and answered. It is a chance to explore the methodology of a composer whose acquisitive methods have recently been called into question, to the point that some have accused him of plagiarism. The program, performed by the St. Lawrence String Quartet, the Zankel Band and others, includes the New York premiere of Mr. Golijov's ''Qohelet'' (more widely known under the spelling ''Koholet''), a Carnegie co-commission and one of the works that was challenged. Mr. Golijov altered it as a result. So what is the whole story? Feb. 4. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S It was a significant coup for this ensemble, excellent though it is, to secure the fast-rising Pablo Heras-Casado as its new principal conductor. He leads the orchestra for the first time at Carnegie Hall since his appointment in a program of the central repertory: Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture, Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 (with Christian Zacharias as soloist), Hans Zender's orchestrations of five Debussy preludes and the lighter, leaner 1841 version of Schumann's Fourth Symphony. All these are distant from the Baroque and new music in which Mr. Heras-Casado has long specialized. The orchestra has bet that his charisma and energy will outweigh his relative inexperience; it may be good for both him and the band that he will get to work with these fine players to refine his interpretations of the standards. Feb. 7. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
ROYAL CONCERTGEBOUW ORCHESTRA Mariss Jansons -- the principal conductor of both this ensemble and the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, and thus a regular commuter between Amsterdam and Munich -- turns 70 in January and seems to have emerged from several health crises of recent decades in fine fettle. Oh, he may still suffer from jet lag, but he certainly doesn't seem fazed. He takes the Bavarians to Tokyo to perform all the Beethoven symphonies in late November. Here he presents good variety in programs well gauged to show off this great orchestra's and Mr. Jansons's own versatility: in one, Bartok's Second Violin Concerto, with Leonidas Kavakos as soloist, and Mahler's First Symphony; in the other, Strauss's ''Death and Transfiguration'' (Mr. Jansons may feel that he has lived it) and Bruckner's Seventh Symphony. Feb. 13-14. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'PARSIFAL' Appearing a bit earlier than its traditional place around the Easter season, Wagner's final and perhaps deepest music drama arrives in New York in a new production by François Girard after a practice run at the Lyon Opera, where its scenic requirements -- a stage-filling sea of blood, for one thing -- strained the company's technical capabilities to the breaking point. Presumably those challenges will be a walk in the park for a Met recently tested by the mechanical headaches of Robert Lepage's Wagner ''Ring'' cycle. And blood aside, the house is fielding a remarkably strong cast: Jonas Kaufmann, seemingly born for the title role, as well as Katarina Dalayman, Peter Mattei, René Pape and Evgeny Nikitin, making his first New York appearance since his withdrawal from the Bayreuth Festival after the bizarre discovery that one of his tattoos resembled, at one point, a swastika. Daniele Gatti's deliberate, expansive take on the opera has polarized audiences in the past, but a little more time spent with singers of this quality wouldn't be too bad a fate. Opens Feb. 15. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'POWDER HER FACE' It's a sign of the composer Thomas Adès's rise to the top of his field that both his operas are being performed in New York this season. The Met's production of his sweeping version of ''The Tempest,'' opening in October, will doubtless grab more attention, but the chamber work ''Powder Her Face,'' about a 1960s sex scandal involving the Duchess of Argyll, has raunchily intimate charm. It's an opera that in content and scale wouldn't make much sense at the Met, so it's an ideal opening act for a New York City Opera, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for two of its four productions, that is trying to define itself artistically after a listless last season. Jay Scheib directs; Jonathan Stockhammer, a specialist in contemporary opera, conducts. Opens Feb. 15. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
'DON CARLO' When Lorin Maazel returned to the Met podium for a run of Wagner's ''Walküre'' in 2008 it was the first time he had conducted at the company since the early 1960s. It's a far smaller gap this time, as he leads Verdi's dark masterpiece and an experienced cast that includes Barbara Frittoli, Anna Smirnova, Ramón Vargas, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, Eric Halfvarson and Ferruccio Furlanetto, who scored a personal coup as Philip II when Nicholas Hytner's production was new in 2010. Opens Feb. 22. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'RADAMISTO' Harry Bicket has that rarest and best of gifts for an early-music specialist: the ability to make regular opera orchestras play with the snap of a period-instrument band. But there is still something special that happens when he leads his own English Concert, which will be joined for one of Handel's lesser-known masterworks by a fine cast that includes the veteran countertenor David Daniels, Brenda Rae, Patricia Bardon, Joélle Harvey and Luca Pisaroni. It is the first in a series of concert performances of Baroque operas at the hall by Mr. Bicket and the ensemble in coming seasons, so there's much to look forward to. Feb. 24. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
'THE TURN OF THE SCREW' The New York City Opera finally has the right idea. This beleaguered company has learned that it's a losing battle to go head to head with the Met in terms of repertory and production style, and smarter to compete with the city's smaller, more nimble companies. To that end, it is opening its season with two intimate-scale operas that would have been naturals from, say, Gotham Chamber Opera: Thomas Adès's ''Powder Her Face'' and this intensely creepy work by Britten, both performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The conductor is the versatile Jayce Ogren; the director is Sam Buntrock, whose Broadway production of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' used lighting and projections with fluid ease. The cast had not been announced at press time. Opens Feb. 24. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. (Z.W.)
MARCH
VIENNA PHILHARMONIC Happiness is conducting two of the world's greatest orchestras at Carnegie Hall in one season. Franz Welser-Möst, having dropped in with his own Cleveland Orchestra in November, now leads an orchestra that -- though proudly independent -- is his in another sense, he being Austrian. The three programs include symphonies by Dvorak (No. 7), Schubert (No. 6) and Bruckner (No. 4); songs by Richard Strauss, sung by the tenor Herbert Lippert; Berg's Violin Concerto, played by Frank Peter Zimmermann; and a work by the contemporary German Jörg Widmann. March 1-3. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
JENNIFER KOH You may see Ms. Koh early in the season, since she is enacting the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing title character of Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's ''Einstein on the Beach'' in some performances (Sept. 14-16) of the Brooklyn Academy production. Here, in the second installment of her three-part multiyear series Bach and Beyond, she occupies the stage alone and presumably without fright wig, playing solo violin works by Bartok and Phil Kline, in addition to Bach. (A recording of the first part is to be released in October by Cedille Records.) March 2. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI' The Met reserves runs of Riccardo Zandonai's infectiously dramatic verismo rarity for divas it really believes in. It was last mounted in the 1980s for Renata Scotto, and this new revival is a major endorsement of the soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek, a favorite in London whose New York career is just getting started. (She also joins the Met Orchestra for Wagner's ''Wesendonck Lieder'' at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 14.) Her co-star, the tenor Marcello Giordani, is ardent but inconsistent, two adjectives that also apply to the conductor, Marco Armiliato. But when Ms. Westbroek is in her groove, she is as thrilling as large stretches of Zandonai's score. Opens March 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
THE BACH VARIATIONS The early-music specialist Masaaki Suzuki and his Bach Collegium Japan and Yale Schola Cantorum join the New York Philharmonic in opening its monthlong festival. The program is built on a lovely idea, juxtaposing works by Bach with near counterparts by his great revivalist, Mendelssohn. (From each comes a Magnificat in D.) March 6-9. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'LA PASIÓN SEGÚN SAN MARCOS' As a sort of belated appendage to its festival Voices From Latin America, Carnegie Hall devotes its choral institute this season to Osvaldo Golijov's magnum opus. In the culminating performance, Robert Spano conducts the Orquesta la Pasión, members of the Schola Cantorum de Venezuela and choruses from area high schools. March 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
LONDON PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, having presented the London Symphony and the Philharmonia Orchestra in the fall, completes its minifestival of major London orchestras. Vladimir Jurowski, the orchestra's principal conductor, presents two programs: first Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. 1, with Vadim Repin as soloist, and Beethoven's Symphony No. 5; then Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4, with Hélène Grimaud as soloist, and Mahler's Symphony No. 5. March 10-11. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
MASS IN B MINOR Happily, major American orchestras have been rediscovering Bach and the Baroque, having largely conceded that repertory to early-music specialists for several decades. The New York Philharmonic had a leg up with Kurt Masur as its music director through the 1990s. Coming from a long tenure in Leipzig, Germany, where Bach spent his last 27 years, Mr. Masur brought Bach's major choral works to the orchestra with some regularity and in 1998 even imported the choir of St. Thomas Church in Leipzig, which Bach had directed, for a ''St. Matthew Passion.'' It is good to see Alan Gilbert pick up the mantle here as part of a major Philharmonic series, the Bach Variations, with the New York Choral Artists and stellar vocal soloists: Dorothea Röschmann, Anne Sofie von Otter, Steve Davislim and Eric Owens. March 13-16. Avery Fisher Hall. (J.R.O.)
'A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE' This season Renée Fleming has a coveted Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, for which she has programmed two recitals, including a battle of the divas alongside the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, and a concert with the New York Philharmonic. But the centerpiece is a semistaged concert performance of this gauzily lyrical André Previn opera, with Blanche DuBois created as a vehicle for Ms. Fleming, first performed in 1998. The work hasn't been heard much since, though it is being revived on March 26 at Lyric Opera of Chicago, where Ms. Fleming is the creative consultant. The Carnegie performance, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's under Patrick Summers, is a test run of sorts for that Chicago stand, featuring the same excellent supporting cast: Susanna Phillips, Teddy Tahu Rhodes and Anthony Dean Griffey. March 14. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY After this gloriously adventurous ensemble's American Mavericks festival last year at Carnegie Hall, which featured work from some of the out-there corners of the repertory, it will be a fascinating shift to hear it in the standards, in which the orchestra and its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, also shine. The first night's program pairs Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4 (with the brilliant Yuja Wang as soloist) and Brahms's First Symphony with the New York premiere of a work by Samuel Carl Adams, and the second concert features the Ninth Symphony of Mahler, a Thomas favorite. March 20-21. Carnegie Hall. (Z.W.)
CARTER BREY New York Philharmonic audiences have been blessed, hearing Mr. Brey regularly since he became the orchestra's principal cellist in 1996. But the pleasure has been mixed, because he had to cut back sharply on his solo career to do it. In a substantial bit of payback, the Philharmonic puts Mr. Brey forward to perform Bach's six unaccompanied cello suites as part of its Bach Variations festival. Expect him to shine. March 27. Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th Street and Central Park West, (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org. (J.R.O.)
LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC At its premiere in Los Angeles in May, John Adams's oratorio ''The Gospel According to the Other Mary'' badly lagged dramatically, but many moments of its protean, searching score showed a mature composer at the height of his powers. The Philharmonic and its music director, Gustavo Dudamel, bring the work to New York with the same excellent soloists -- Tamara Mumford, Kelley O'Connor and Russell Thomas -- and a new element: a staging by the theater artist Peter Sellars, who collaborated with Mr. Adams on the libretto. The next evening's concert features Claude Vivier's ''Zipangu,'' for strings, ''La Mer'' by Debussy and Stravinsky's ''Firebird,'' the kind of vividly dramatic work at which Mr. Dudamel excels. March 27-28. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
'ST. MATTHEW PASSION' Ivan Fischer's conducting appearances in New York invariably yield fine performances, but in recent years they have also become genuine events. In 2010 Mr. Fischer presented all the Beethoven symphonies, half on period instruments, half on modern; in 2011 he offered Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' in his own staging; and in April he led Mozart's Requiem with choristers intermingled among the orchestra to give the players a better feel for the text. Bach's great Passion is to be sure an event in itself, and no unusual twists have been announced -- yet. Mr. Fischer conducts Musica Sacra and the Orchestra of St. Luke's, with soloists including Dominique Labelle, John Tessier and Hanno Müller-Brachmann. March 28. Carnegie Hall. (In other notable performances of the ''St. Matthew Passion,'' John Scott conducts the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and Concert Royal at St. Thomas Church on March 21, and Julian Wachner conducts the Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at Trinity Church on March 24.) (J.R.O.)
APRILIt is
BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA In all the rampant speculation about who might succeed James Levine as the orchestra's music director, the name Daniele Gatti seems to have receded. Mr. Gatti is a gifted and experienced maestro in midcareer and seems not to be overcommitted by the standards of conductors today, despite major posts at the Orchestre National de France and the Zurich Opera. In this series, after a mixed program conducted by Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, a veteran who has given the orchestra yeoman service during its transition, the second and third programs are conducted by Mr. Gatti. Though there is no reason to expect anything but excellent performances, it will be hard not to wonder what Mr. Levine might have done with Mahler's Third Symphony, one of his great specialties, this time around in the second program, or what he might have made of the third, all Wagner. Certainly, on each of these terrains, Mr. Gatti will be held to the highest standard, by orchestra and public alike. April 3-5. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'GIULIO CESARE' It's tough being the final new Met production of the year. With everyone exhausted and attention flagging, you tend, like Rodney Dangerfield, to get no respect. It doesn't help that David McVicar's version of this Handel masterpiece, which puts a colorful colonial-era, Neo-Classical spin on the ancient Egyptian setting, has already been captured on DVD. But the Met's cast -- David Daniels in the title role, Natalie Dessay as Cleopatra and the excellent Alice Coote as Sesto -- is of interest, and the conductor, Harry Bicket, is a pro at this repertory. The Met orchestra plays its heart out for him. Opens April 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'GESUALDO REFLECTIONS' The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is best known for the classics; its concerts are the place to go when you want a Beethoven quartet played with dependable polish. But the society also has a relatively unheralded, consistently creative and excellent new-music series in Lincoln Center's intimate Kaplan Penthouse. The highlight, though it doesn't take place at the penthouse, is a celebration of the 400th anniversary of the birth of the brilliant and murderous composer Carlo Gesualdo featuring the Antioch Chamber Ensemble, the pianist Soyeon Kate Lee and the Brentano String Quartet. In keeping with Gesualdo's experimental music, centuries ahead of its time, the program juxtaposes his work with 21st-century responses -- by Bruce Adolphe, Brett Dean, David Gompper and Wolfgang Rihm -- for various chamber forces. April 4. Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org. (Z.W.)
'DER RING DES NIBELUNGEN' There will be a degree of deja vu as the Met brings back Robert Lepage's version of Wagner's epic masterpiece for the first time as a piece of the repertory, after the rollout of the full cycle last season. For the three cycles Deborah Voigt and Katarina Dalayman still alternate as Brünnhilde; Jay Hunter Morris's bright-voiced Siegfried still gets his turn, as does Hans-Peter König's memorably rich Hagen; and the enormous planks of Mr. Lepage's machine still rotate impassively. The question will be whether and how the spectacle suffers without the intensity provided by some of last season's stars: Bryn Terfel, Jonas Kaufmann, Eva-Maria Westbroek and Waltraud Meier. Fabio Luisi conducts. Cycles open on April 6 and 25 and May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
'MOSÈ IN EGITTO' Rossini's serious operas still don't receive the productions they deserve; they are long and not easy to cast. But they have irresistible grandeur. Now the New York City Opera offers a super-rare staging of the Italian original at City Center, the company's original home. The production is directed by Michael Counts, the visually eclectic creator of City Opera's ''Monodramas'' evening; we'll see how he handles the climactic parting of the Red Sea. (Projections, credited to Ada Whitney/Beehive, will presumably play a role.) Jayce Ogren, City Opera's man for all seasons, conducts. Opens April 14. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
DRESDEN STAATSKAPELLE It will be fascinating to catch up with this orchestra and itsprincipal conductor, Christian Thielemann, in view of the jockeying for power going on at European festivals. After Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic announced that they would leave the Salzburg Easter Festival next spring in favor of an event in Baden-Baden, Germany, Mr. Thielemann and the Staatskapelle were quick to move in. The Berlin Philharmonic sounded in splendid shape at Carnegie in February, and this season, just weeks after that Salzburg appearance, it is the Staatskapelle's turn in programs of Brahms (''Academic Festival Overture''; Violin Concerto, with Lisa Batiashvili as soloist; Symphony No. 4) and Bruckner (Symphony No. 8). April 17, 19. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
'TRISTAN UND ISOLDE' The acclaimed Swedish dramatic soprano Nina Stemme, who set Carnegie Hall ablaze as Strauss's Salome with Franz Welser-Möst and the Cleveland Orchestra in May, has said that her way in life is ''to hurry slowly.'' She has held back in establishing a career in the United States, and she will take up Wagner's Isolde at the Met only in the 2016-17 season. American Wagnerites will undoubtedly flock to Houston to hear her do it sooner. Ben Heppner is scheduled to sing Tristan, but you may recall that he gave the Met fits in the role in 2008, claiming illness and showing up for only the last of six planned performances. Christof Loy directs, and Patrick Summers conducts. If it all comes together, it should be worth the trip. Opens April 18. Houston Grand Opera, Wortham Center, (713) 228-6737, houstongrandopera.org. (J.R.O.)
'LA PÉRICHOLE' Christopher Alden's dreamlike production of Mozart's ''Così Fan Tutte'' was the bright spot in the New York City Opera's uninspired last season, the latest in a series of memorable shows the director has made for the company in recent years. He now turns his attention to a seemingly unlikely work: this farcical operetta by Offenbach about a Peruvian street singer who triangulates between her true love and a Spanish official. (Another frothy opera, Johann Strauss's ''Fledermaus,'' is also on Mr. Alden's agenda this year, with a production opening in October at the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto.) Mr. Alden has a gift for bringing out the darkness and sophistication in the unlikeliest of places and pieces. Opens April 21. New York City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 870-5600, nycopera.com. (Z.W.)
'WAR REQUIEM' Of the many commemorations of Benjamin Britten's centennial here in 2013, this performance of a consummate masterpiece, a pacifist statement mingling the text of the Requiem Mass with poetry of Wilfred Owen, will undoubtedly be one of the more imposing, with Kent Tritle conducting the 200-voice Oratorio Society of New York, itself celebrating its 140th anniversary. The vocal soloists are the excellent Emalie Savoy, soprano; John Matthew Myers, tenor; and Jesse Blumberg, baritone. April 22. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
SWEDISH CHAMBER ORCHESTRA New York admirers of the Swedish soprano Nina Stemme who cannot catch that ''Tristan und Isolde'' in Houston must content themselves with this catchall concert, in which she will perform songs of Berlioz, Brahms, Wagner, Grieg, Sibelius, Strauss and Weill. In addition, Thomas Dausgaard conducts the fine ensemble in works or parts of works by Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Elgar, Sibelius and Ravel. April 25. Alice Tully Hall. (J.R.O.)
STRAVINSKY SACRED WORKS Julian Wachner continues his emphasis on more or less contemporary fare this season with the Trinity Choir and Novus NY devoting a weekend to the complete sacred works by a restless master. Stravinsky essentially announced modernism in music with his ''Rite of Spring'' in 1913, then looked back over his shoulder with a Neo-Classicism largely of his own invention and finally found his way to the spare, serialist aesthetic that dominates in many of the works here. Rightly, the majestic ''Symphony of Psalms'' crowns the affair. April 26-27 at Trinity Church. April 28 at St. Paul's Chapel. (J.R.O.)
YALE IN NEW YORK This four-concert series concludes with a commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the death of Paul Hindemith, ''Prankster and Master'': a Yale professor for the 13 years before his death and an astonishingly prolific composer and champion of useful music (Gebrauchsmusik) most of whose works have largely fallen into disuse. The current faculty members Boris Berman, pianist, and Ettore Causa, violist, and members of the Yale Philharmonia perform works of Hindemith including the sure-to-be-immortal ''Overture to 'The Flying Dutchman' as Played at Sight by a Second-Rate Concert Orchestra at the Village Well at 7 O'Clock in the Morning,'' for string quartet. April 28. Zankel Hall. (J.R.O.)
MAY
'DIALOGUES DES CARMÉLITES' Some critics, including Anthony Tommasini in The New York Times, have called for the Met to appoint a director of productions, who would work with the general manager, Peter Gelb, and the music director, whoever that may be, to plot the company's theatrical direction. (S0 far Mr. Gelb has resisted the idea.) The last time something like that happened was when John Dexter filled the position in the late 1970s and early '80s. Audiences are periodically reminded of that brief golden age for theater at the Met when Dexter's productions are revived; though more than 30 years old, their elegance and intelligence shine through, as in his spectacular yet subtle take on Britten's ''Billy Budd,'' performed last season. One of Dexter's finest shows was his ''Dialogues des Carmélites,'' as unadorned and inspired as Poulenc's score. This revival has a fine cast, including Isabel Leonard, Patricia Racette, Erin Morley, Elizabeth Bishop and Paul Appleby, conducted by Louis Langrée. Opens May 4. Metropolitan Opera House. (Z.W.)
EARLY MUSIC NEW YORK The fascinating program ''London's Musical Bridge: The Enlightened English'' pairs works by 18th-century native English composers with counterparts by Germans who had settled in London: thus, suites by John Avison and Handel, overtures by William Boyce and Johann Christian Bach, and sinfonias by Thomas Arne and Frederick William Herschel. Herschel, in his day job as astronomer, discovered the planet Uranus: enlightened indeed. May 4. First Church of Christ, Scientist, Central Park West at 68th Street, (212) 280-0330. earlymusicny.org. (J.R.O.)
SPRING FOR MUSIC This annual festival of North American orchestras, conceived by top music professionals to encourage and reward adventurous programming, has in its first two seasons effectively filled what it has shown to be a valuable niche: giving Carnegie Hall-exposure to ensembles showing initiative, several of which might otherwise never have found their way there. Carlos Kalmar and the Oregon Symphony -- who made the biggest splash in 2011 with a program they have since recorded for the Pentatone label, ''Music for a Time of War'' -- present a wide-ranging collection of works by Schubert, Ravel, Schoenberg, Kurt Weill and the Thai composer Narong Prangcharoen (May 9). Also returning to the festival, which mandates a year off between appearances, are David Alan Miller and the Albany Symphony Orchestra, who presented a program centered on spirituals in 2011 and now play another American program, with works by Gershwin, Morton Gould and John Harbison (May 7). In addition, Marin Alsop conducts the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra; JoAnn Falletta, the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra; Leonard Slatkin, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra; and Christoph Eschenbach, the National Symphony Orchestra. May 6-11. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
DETROIT SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA To single out the oddest of the Spring for Music programs: Leonard Slatkin conducts Ives's Symphonies Nos. 1 through 4, a notion utterly logical on its surface yet, given the ear-twisting complexities in much of the music, utterly bizarre. Not even counting however many intermissions and stage changes, the program runs well over two hours. But will Mr. Slatkin be able to resist adding an encore: say, Ives's attempt at a monster sequel, the ''Universe Symphony,'' which the Nashville Symphony performed in the completion by Larry Austin at Spring for Music this year? May 10. Carnegie Hall. (J.R.O.)
TOKYO STRING QUARTET Though the personnel has shifted in recent years, it was still quite a brand, established over 43 years of excellent performance (and kudos to Kazuhide Isomura, the violist, who saw it all). Now the quartet has decided to quit while still near the top. It has picked excellent collaborative works to go out with, both in this concert (Schubert's resolutely sunny String Quintet, with the cellist Lynn Harrell) and in its penultimate recording (Brahms's late, mellow Clarinet Quintet, with the clarinetist Jon Manasse), to be released by Harmonia Mundi in November. But the quartet takes final leave on its own, both here on stage, with works by Haydn and Bartok (the Sixth Quartet, his last), and on disc, with works of Dvorak and Smetana, scheduled for release in 2013. May 11. 92nd Street Y. (J.R.O.)
'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO' Looking around and noting the decided paucity of quality opera in its city, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, never an ensemble to rest on its laurels, is improbably turning itself into a de facto opera company. It is focusing on new and recent works but also unveiling a series of staged performances of Mozart and Lorenzo Da Ponte's three classic operas, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel and featuring sets and costumes by noted architects and fashion designers. Last year ''Don Giovanni'' was promising, but the logistics, with the orchestra far above and behind the singers, were a work in progress. For this year's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' the setup will be adjusted for a production designed by Jean Nouvel and Azzedine Alaïa and starring Christopher Maltmann and Dorothea Röschmann. May 17, 19, 23, 25. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com. (Z.W.)
'GILBERT'S PLAYLIST' If four programs in May and June are being put forward as Alan Gilbert's playlist, you have to wonder what that implies about the rest of his season with the New York Philharmonic. Rote? Required? But questions about the marketing strategy don't detract from the quality and creativity of the work he is offering under that unfortunate title. First come jazz-inflected works by Stravinsky, Shostakovich, Copland and Wynton Marsalis, played alongside the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, then Dallapiccola's stark one-act opera ''Il Prigioniero'' (featuring Gerald Finley and Patricia Racette), sharing a bill with Lisa Batiashvili in Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1. Mr. Gilbert offers his new arrangement of Wagner, ''A Ring Journey,'' with Christopher Rouse's ''Seeing,'' featuring the pianist Emanuel Ax. Finally, to close the season, Doug Fitch, who has collaborated with Mr. Gilbert and the orchestra in recent seasons, directs and designs an evening of Stravinsky ballets (''The Fairy's Kiss'' and ''Petrouchka'') with Karole Armitage creating choreography for the New York City Ballet dancer Sara Mearns. May 31-June 29. Avery Fisher Hall. (Z.W.)
JUNE
STOKOWSKI CELEBRATION Now the gloves are off. Mr. Nézet-Séguin, for all practical purposes, embodies Stokowski, as the Philadelphia Orchestra returns to its treasured but acoustically flawed old home, the Academy of Music. In three days of intensive programming, he conducts Brahms's First Symphony and Dvorak's Ninth, Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Scheherazade'' and works by Ippolitov-Ivanov and Wagner, an audience-choice program and repertory from the animated Disney film ''Fantasia.'' But in the film, Stokowski got to shake hands with Mickey Mouse. How do you replicate that, Mr. Nézet-Séguin? June 21-23. Academy of Music, Philadelphia, (215) 893-1999, philorch.org. (J.R.O.)
